Made you finally stand up to your parents. My mom kept borrowing money from my savings account without asking. Started small when I was 15, 20 here, 50 there. Always promised, I'll pay you back next week, sweetheart. I was saving for my first car, working weekends at Scoops Ice Cream downtown. The job absolutely sucked. Sticky floors covered in melted ice cream, screaming kids having sugar meltdowns and my chain smoking manager, Derek, who reeked of cigarettes. After two grueling years of scooping rocky road and mopping chocolate spills every night, I'd saved almost $3,000. Then I checked my balance at the ATM. 8, 47, 32, my heart stopped. I drove straight home, found mom making fancy curried coffee with expensive pods she claimed we couldn't afford. Mom, where's my money? She didn't look. Oh, honey, I needed it for groceries. Things are tight since the divorce. You'll get it back. But groceries don't cost $2,000. I started watching her spending. New coach purse from the outlet mall, weekly salon appointments for highlights, fancy dinners with club friends every Friday, all while telling me we had to tighten our belts and couldn't afford name brand cereal I liked. I felt sick. This was my money from my job dealing with brain freeze headaches in that walk in freezer every single night. When I confronted her again, she got defensive. I'm your mother, Jessica. I've spent way more than 3,000 raising you over 17 years. Consider this paying me back. For all those diapers and formula. That comment made my blood boil. That's when I knew I had to be smart about this. During lunch break, I went to First National Bank and asked to speak with someone about my account to tell her. Margaret pulled up my statements, her face changing as she scrolled through months of transactions. Your mom's been withdrawing money almost weekly for six months, I whispered. Since you're a minor, this is technically a joint account, so it's legal. But you can open your own when you turn 18 next month. She leaned closer. Until then, you could withdraw everything and keep it somewhere safe. That night, I didn't confront mom. Instead, I went back the next day and withdrew every penny except $1, opened a new account at Community Credit Union across town that only I could access. For three days, I acted completely normal, went to work, came home, did chemistry homework, watch Netflix with mom like nothing had changed. She had no idea I'd moved my entire life savings. Then Friday night, I heard her giggling on the phone with her friend Linda, planning their weekly book club dinner at that expensive steakhouse downtown. Don't worry about splitting the chat, she laughed. I'll just grab some cash from Jessica's account tomorrow morning. She never checks it anyway. Twenty minutes later, she knocked on my door wearing silk pajamas. Hey, sweetie, I'm running to the ATM before book club. Need anything from CVS? I smiled innocently. No.

Girlfriend pointed an unloaded gun in my face. It happened last Tuesday around nine PM. I was at my girlfriend Emma's apartment watching Netflix when she randomly got up and went to her bedroom. I thought she was just going to the bathroom or something, but then she came back holding her dad's old hunting rifle. The thing looked ancient but well maintained. Check this out, she said, pointing it directly at my forehead from maybe three feet away. My dad taught me how to use this when I was 12. I literally froze. Like, completely stopped breathing for a second. The barrel was staring me right in the face, and all I could think was how massive it looked from that angle. My heart started pounding so hard I could hear it in my ears. Emma, what the hell are you doing? I managed to say, trying not to move. She laughed like it was the funniest thing ever. Relax, it's not loaded. See? She pulled the trigger and nothing happened except for a loud click. But hearing that click while looking down the barrel made my stomach drop into my shoes. Are you insane? You never point a gun at someone, loaded or not. I was practically yelling at this point. She rolled her eyes. God, you're such a baby. It's empty. I checked. My dad always kept the ammo locked up separately anyway. But here's the thing. I grew up around guns, too. My uncle took me Hunting every fall since I was 10, and the first rule he drilled into my head was, you never, ever point a firearm at anything you don't intend to destroy. Look, loaded or unloaded? Doesn't matter. It's like gun safety 1:01. Emma, this isn't a joke. That's literally the most dangerous thing you can do with a gun. I said, standing up slowly with my hands visible. Even if you think it's empty. She was still holding it casually, like it was a toy or something. You're being dramatic. I've handled this gun a million times. That's when I decided to prove my point. I asked her to hand me the rifle, and she did. Still thinking I was overreacting, I pointed it toward the ground. And. Work.

To talk to your parents anymore. My parents discovered I wasn't their biological child when I was 16, not through some dramatic DNA test, through my little sister's science project. She was doing genetics homework, mapping out eye colours and couldn't make our family tree work. Brown eyes plus brown eyes can't make blue eyes, he said, pointing at me. Mom went white. Dad started stuttering about recessive genes. That night I heard them screaming through the walls. Mom admitted she'd had an affair 17 years ago. Dad wasn't my father. The man who raised me, taught me to ride a bike, helped with homework for 16 years, suddenly looked at me like I was a stranger. The change was immediate and brutal. Dad stopped coming to my baseball games. I tried talking to him. He'd respond with one word answers or just leave the room. Mom kept insisting nothing had changed, but she'd flinch whenever dad was cold to me. Then came the comparisons. Every family dinner became a catalog of how my sister and I were different. Look how naturally athletic Sophie is, dad would say, watching her throw a ball. She gets that from me. The implication hung in the air like poison. They started treating me like a house guest. My curfew got earlier while my sister stayed the same. My allowance got cut because money is tight. But Sophie got new clothes whenever she asked. When I brought it up, mom said I was being Dramatic. The worst part was watching them rewrite history. Photos of me got moved to the back of albums. My baby pictures disappeared from the mantle. Dad started telling stories about Sophie's milestones while pretending mine never happened. It was like they were erasing 16 years. My breaking point came during Christmas. Extended family was over and Uncle Mike asked about my college plans. Dad said, well, he's not really academic like Sophie. Different genetics, you know, he said genetics like it was a dirty word. That's when it clicked. They didn't just learn I wasn't blood related. They decided I wasn't family. So I made a choice that destroyed them. I found my biological father. His name was John Sins. He lived three states away, had no idea I existed. When I called him, he cried, actually cried. Said he'd wondered about my mom for years, hoped she was happy. Two weeks later, John drove 400 miles to meet me. He brought photo albums of his family, told me about my half brother who played baseball like me, showed me pictures of my real grandmother who had died the year before. But here's what broke my parents. John didn't just accept me, he celebrated me. Within a month, he'd driven back twice more. He came to my games, met my friends, took me car shopping. For my 17th birthday, my parents watched this man give me everything they'd taken away. Dad became obsessed, calling John a stranger, trying to Steal his son. Mom begged me to stop seeing him, said it was destroying our family. I told them they'd already destroyed it. The night they decided biology mattered more than 16 years of love, the final blow came at graduation. Both my family showed up. John sat in the front row cheering.

50 pound gym bro picked a fight with me to impress a girl, not knowing I was a taekwondo black belt. At 5 7 and 140 pounds, I wasn't exactly the most intimidating. Drunk guys at bars always picked me when they wanted to look tough in front of women. So when I saw this 6 2 gym bro marching over to where I was chatting with a pretty brunette, I already knew how this would go. He wedged himself between us, his massive frame completely blocking me out. Didn't even look at me, just turned his broad back like I was furniture. Let me get you a real drink, beautiful, he said. Flag down the bartender, not whatever this little guy was boring you with. She glanced around his shoulder at me, clearly uncomfortable. Actually, we were just. Trust me. He cut her off, placing a protective hand on the bar in front of her. Eating a wall. You need someone who can actually take care of you. He ordered her a martini without asking, then finally acknowledged my existence with a dismissive glance. You can go now, buddy. When I didn't move, he shifted his weight, using his size to push me further down the bar. The edge of the counter dug into my ribs. Still, I stayed put, sipping my beer. He'd expected me to scurry away by now. He turned to me fully for the first time, looking me up and down with theatrical disgust, asked If I I was deaf or something. When I calmly said I was just finishing my drink, his hand shot out and swiped my glasses off my face. They clattered across the bar. Everything went blurry. He made jokes about me not being able to see up to his height. Told the girl maybe that's why I hadn't gotten the hint. I stayed still, breathing normally. 10 years of training had taught me the most important lesson real fighters don't fight in bars. Much liability. Too much to lose. My instructor certification, my gym, potential lawsuits, all gone over some drunk idiot. I reached for my glasses with measured movements. He slid them further away with one finger, told me to leave them. I walked around him to retrieve them, keeping everything neutral. When I sat back down with my glasses, he spun around to face the entire bar and announced loudly that we had a creeper situation. His voice boomed over the music as he pointed at me with his beer bottle, claiming I've been bothering this nice lady for an hour. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch. Told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school. He grinned and turned to the bartender, suggesting I should be carded again because I looked about twice. The brunette pulled Away from his hand, but he kept talking over her, telling her she didn't have to be polite anymore. Half the bar was watching now, some people whispering, shooting me, suspicious looks. My reputation at this place where I've been a regular for two years, was being destroyed in real time. Then he decided to demonstrate my weakness. He grabbed my wrist, suddenly, holding it up for the bar to see, while comparing it to his 12 year old nephew's arms. I didn't resist, keeping my breathing steady as he squeezed harder, his thumb pressing into the pressure point. He yanked me off the bar stool, effortlessly, spinning me around to show the girl what would happen if real danger showed up, then shoved me back against the bar. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. He turned to the girl, explaining this was why she needed someone like him around, painted scenarios of what could happen with me just standing there, doing nothing if he was actually dangerous. The brunette stood up, said she was leaving. He grabbed her wrist, immediately, insisting he'd walk her to her car because the streets weren't Safe. Her voice was firm, but I could hear the fear underneath. When she told him to let go, he tightened his grip slightly, still smiling, saying he was just trying to help. She tried to pull away, but he held firm, told her to relax. He was just being a gentleman. His grip tightened enough to make her gasp. She was getting genuinely scared now, panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.

What family tradition ruined your family? My mother is the most baby obsessed psycho I've ever met. Starting when I was 8 years old, she made me and my sister Daniela wear these pregnancy simulation suits for hours every single day. 20 pounds of sand strapped to our stomachs while we practice breathing exercises and watch birthing videos. If we complained about back pain, she'd add more weight and tell us, real mothers don't whine. She even made us practice breastfeeding with these baby little dolls that would cry if you didn't hold them right. While I spent every session plotting my escape, Daniela embraced it as if it was her one true purpose. She'd waddle around the house with perfect posture, rubbing in her fake belly and talking to it out loud. By the time she turned 16, she was begging mom to let her be a practice surrogate for her infertile work friends. And when she turned 18, Mom threw her a massive party, not for graduating high school, but for signing her first surrogacy contract. Everyone was calling her a blessing and an angel, while I sat in the corner feeling like I was at a livestock auction. Within three years, Daniella had carried three babies for three different couples. Each time she came home from the hospital, mom would parade her around town like she'd won a Nobel Prize. Look at my generous daughter giving the gift of life. Meanwhile, I was getting a biomedical degree. Volunteering at women's shelters and learning about bodily autonomy. But none of that mattered. Such a waste of a perfectly good uterus. Mom would tell anyone who'd listen. Her sister has blessed three families, while this one hordes her fertility for herself. The most terrifying part was watching Daniela deteriorate after her fourth pregnancy. At 22, she could barely walk without pain, her hips were destroyed, she had constant infections, and her hair was falling out in chunks. When I tried to talk to her about it, she grabbed my hands with tears in her eyes. Maria, this is what I was made for. My body is a vessel for miracles. Why can't you understand that? That's when I knew she was gone. So I played along just enough to keep mom off my back. Told her I was considering pregnancy, wore looser clothes to family events, even googled fertility clinics in front of her, all while secretly taking the LSAT and applying to law schools across the country. Lol. I specialized in reproductive rights and medical ethics, spending years helping women escape forced pregnancy situations. By 28, I was finally making a difference. So when mom invited me to Daniela's Celebration dinner, I figured it was just another pregnancy announcement. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out it was an effing intervention. Sweetie, you're not getting any younger, mom announced while Daniela sat beside her belly swollen with pregnancy. No. 5. So I've taken the liberty of starting your fertility Treatments. Before I could respond, she pulled out a syringe filled with hormones. Just a little boost to get those eggs flowing. I jumped back, but Daniela grabbed my arms from behind. Please, Maria, just try it. I've already found the perfect couple for your first baby. I screamed and fought, but mom was already coming at me with the needle. That's when I noticed the other syringes on the table. They've been planning this. Mom punched the needle into my thigh. I felt the cold liquid burn through my muscle. Within minutes, my vision blurred, and my ovaries felt like they were on fire. Through the haze, I heard mom on the phone. Yes. Started the protocol. She'll be ready for harvest in two weeks. That's when I realized this wasn't just about family pressure anymore. This was trafficking. I woke up in the ICU with ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome so severe, they nearly had to remove everything. My mom stood towering over me. We only brought you here because we wanted to save your womb, was the first thing she said. I pressed the red button for the nurse. We took one look at my mom and escorted her out to perform private examinations. As soon as we were alone, I felt even worse because she wrapped her arms around me and asked if I was okay. I broke down crying because the whole thing.

At restaurants, they'd split the Bill evenly, even though I always ordered the cheapest thing because I was broke from college. The final straw was my birthday last month. Emma had a family thing. Tyler forgot he had to work, just said her car wouldn't start. But here's the kicker. I saw Tyler's Instagram story later that night. He was at some house party with people from our group, including Jess, whose car had mysteriously started working. That's when I decided to test them. I crafted this message about how my mom was in the hospital after a car accident and I was scared and needed someone to drive me there because I was too shaken up to drive. I sent it to our group chat at seven PM on a Thursday. First response came from Emma an hour later. Oh, no, hope she's okay. Keep us updated. No offer to help. Tyler hearted the message. That's it. Just hearted it like it was a funny meme or something. Just texted me privately saying she would help but her boyfriend had the car. Brad said he was at work until late. Two others never even responded. Six people I'd called my best friends for four years and when I needed them most, they all had excuses. But here's where it gets interesting. I have this coworker named Alex who I'd only hung out with a few times outside work. He barely knew me beyond small talk about weekend plans. I decided to text him the same message just to see what would happen. This guy dropped everything, called me immediately, said he was leaving his girlfriend's apartment right then to pick me up, showed up at my door 20 minutes later with snacks and a phone charger, asking which hospital and if I needed anything else. I felt so bad I almost came clean right there. Instead, I told him my mom was okay, that it was just a Scare and false alarm. He was genuinely relieved and said he was glad to help anytime. Meanwhile, my so called best friends were still posting TikToks and Snapchat stories like nothing happened. The next day in our group chat, everyone asked how my mom was doing. I said she was fine. Thanks for all the support. The sarcasm went right over their heads. Emma even had the nerve to say that's what friends are for with a heart emoji. I started pulling back after that, stopped initiating conversations, stop suggesting plans. Guess what happened? Nothing. They literally didn't notice I was gone. Three weeks passed before anyone texted me directly and it was only because Tyler needed someone to cover his shift at the pizza place where we both worked. Last weekend was the breaking point. I saw on Instagram they all went to this escape room place we talked about going to for months, the same place I'd suggested multiple times and got shut down. There they were, all six of them posting stories with captions like squad goals and best friends forever. So I made my decision. I started a new group chat called Real Friends Update with just Alex and two other people who'd actually shown they cared. I posted about moving on from fake friendships and finding people who actually value you.

voice_to_text: 50 pound gym bro picked a fight with me to impress a girl, not knowing I was a taekwondo black belt. At 5 7 and 140 pounds, I wasn't exactly the most intimidating. Drunk guys at bars always picked me when they wanted to look tough in front of women. So when I saw this 6 2 gym bro marching over to where I was chatting with a pretty brunette, I already knew how this would go. He wedged himself between us, his massive frame completely blocking me out. Didn't even look at me, just turned his broad back like I was furniture. Let me get you a real drink, beautiful, he said. Flag down the bartender, not whatever this little guy was boring you with. She glanced around his shoulder at me, clearly uncomfortable. Actually, we were just. Trust me. He cut her off, placing a protective hand on the bar in front of her. Eating a wall. You need someone who can actually take care of you. He ordered her a martini without asking, then finally acknowledged my existence with a dismissive glance. You can go now, buddy. When I didn't move, he shifted his weight, using his size to push me further down the bar. The edge of the counter dug into my ribs. Still, I stayed put, sipping my beer. He'd expected me to scurry away by now. He turned to me fully for the first time, looking me up and down with theatrical disgust, asked If I I was deaf or something. When I calmly said I was just finishing my drink, his hand shot out and swiped my glasses off my face. They clattered across the bar. Everything went blurry. He made jokes about me not being able to see up to his height. Told the girl maybe that's why I hadn't gotten the hint. I stayed still, breathing normally. 10 years of training had taught me the most important lesson real fighters don't fight in bars. Too much liability. Too much to lose. My instructor certification, my gym, potential lawsuits, all gone over some drunk idiot. I reached for my glasses with measured movements, slid them further away with one finger, told me to leave them. I walked around him to retrieve them, keeping everything neutral. When I sat back down with my glasses, he spun around to face the entire bar and announced loudly that we had a creeper situation. His voice boomed over the music as he pointed at me with his beer bottle, claiming I've been bothering this nice lady for an hour. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch. Told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school, grinned, and turned to the bartender, suggesting I should be carded again because I looked about 12. The brunette pulled away. From his hand, but he kept talking over her, telling her she didn't have to be polite anymore. Half the bar was watching now, some people whispering, shooting me suspicious looks. My reputation at this place where I've been a regular for two years, was being destroyed in real time. Then he decided to demonstrate my weakness. He grabbed my wrist, suddenly, holding it up for the bar to see, while comparing it to his 12 year old nephew's arms. I didn't resist, keeping my breathing steady as he squeezed harder, his thumb pressing into the pressure point. He yanked me off the bar stool, effortlessly, spinning me around to show the girl what would happen if real danger showed up, then shoved me back against the bar. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. He turned to the girl, explaining this was why she needed someone like him around, painted scenarios of what could happen with me just standing there doing nothing if he was actually dangerous. The brunette stood up, said she was leaving. He grabbed her wrist, immediately, insisting he'd walk her to her car because the streets weren't safe. Her voice was firm, but I could hear the fear underneath. When she told him to let go, he tightened his grip slightly, still smiling, saying he was just trying to help. She tried to pull away, but he held firm, told her to relax. He was just being a gentleman. His grip tightened enough to make her gasp. She was getting genuinely scared now, panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.

voice_to_text: What family tradition ruined your family? My mother is the most baby obsessed psycho I've ever met. Starting when I was 8 years old, she made me and my sister Daniela wear these pregnancy simulation suits for hours every single day. 20 pounds of sand strapped to our stomachs while we practice breathing exercises and watch birthing videos. If we complained about back pain, she'd add more weight and tell us, real mothers don't whine. She even made us practice breastfeeding with these creep be little dolls that would cry if you didn't hold them right. While I spent every session plotting my escape, Daniela embraced it as if it was her one true purpose. She'd waddle around the house with perfect posture, rubbing her fake belly and talking to it out loud. By the time she turned 16, she was begging mom to let her be a practice surrogate for her infertile work friends. And when she turned 18, Mom threw her a massive party, not for graduating high school, but for signing her first surrogacy contract. Everyone was calling her a blessing and an angel, while I sat in the corner feeling like I was at a livestock auction. Within three years, Daniella had carried three babies for three different couples. Each time she came home from the hospital, mom would parade her around town like she'd won a Nobel Prize. Look at my generous daughter giving the gift of life. Meanwhile, I was getting a biomedical degree. Volunteering at women's shelters and learning about bodily autonomy. But none of that mattered. Such a waste of a perfectly good uterus. I would tell anyone who'd listen her sister has blessed three families, while this one hoards her fertility for herself. The most terrifying part was watching Daniela deteriorate after her fourth pregnancy. At 22, she could barely walk without pain, her hips were destroyed, she had constant infections, and her hair was falling out in chunks. When I tried to talk to her about it, she grabbed my hands with tears in her eyes. Maria, this is what I was made for. My body is a vessel for miracles. Why can't you understand that? That's when I knew she was gone. So I played along just enough to keep mom off my back. Told her I was considering pregnancy, wore looser clothes to family events, even googled fertility clinics in front of her, all while secretly taking the LSAT and applying to law schools across the country. Lol. I specialized in reproductive rights and medical ethics, spending years helping women escape forced pregnancy situations. By 28, I was finally making a difference. So when mom invited me to Daniela's Celebration dinner, I figured it was just another pregnancy announcement. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out it was an effing intervention. Sweetie, you're not getting any younger, mom announced while Daniela sat beside her belly swollen with pregnancy No. 5. So I've taken the liberty of starting your fertility Treatments. Before I could respond, she pulled out a syringe filled with hormones. Just a little boost to get those eggs flowing. I jumped back, but Daniela grabbed my arms from behind. Please, Maria, just try it. I've already found the perfect couple for your first baby. I screamed and fought, but mom was already coming at me with the needle. That's when I noticed the other syringes on the table. They've been planning this. Mom punched the needle into my thigh. I felt the cold liquid burn through my muscle. Within minutes, my vision blurred, and my ovaries felt like they were on fire. Through the haze, I heard mom on the phone. Yes. Started the protocol. She'll be ready for harvest in two weeks. That's when I realized this wasn't just about family pressure anymore. This was trafficking. I woke up in the ICU with ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome so severe, they nearly had to remove everything. My mom stood towering over me. We only brought you here because we wanted to save your womb, was the first thing she said. I pressed the red button for the nurse. We took one look at my mom and escorted her out to perform private examinations. As soon as we were alone, I felt even worse because she wrapped her arms around me and asked if I was okay. I broke down crying because the whole thing.

When I calmly said I was just finishing my drink, his hand shot out and swiped my glasses off my face. They clattered across the bar. Everything went blurry. He made jokes about me not being able to see up to his. I told the girl, maybe that's why I hadn't gotten the hint. I stayed still, breathing normally. 10 years of training had taught me the most important lesson. Real fighters don't fight in bars. Too much liability. Too much to lose. voice_to_text: Off my toxic friend group by creating a fake emergency to see who would actually show up. So I've been feeling like the backup friend for months. It started when I got really sick with the flu last winter. I'm talking fever, can't get out of bed sick. I texted our group chat, asking if someone could bring me soup or medicine from the store. Radio silence for three hours, and finally, Emma responds with, Oof. Feel better. And that's it. But two days later, when Brad wanted people to come help him move his couch, four of them showed up immediately. I started paying attention after that. When I'd suggest hanging out, I'd get excuses. When anyone else suggested something. Suddenly, everyone was free. During conversations, they'd talk over me or just ignore what I said completely. At restaurants, they'd split the Bill evenly, even though I always ordered the cheapest thing, because I was broke from college. The final straw was my birthday last month. I planned this whole thing at Dave and Buster's. And invites two weeks early. The day of, I'm sitting there alone at a table for seven. One by one, the cancellations rolled in. Emma had a family thing. Tyler forgot he had to work. Jess said her car wouldn't start. But here's the kicker. I saw Tyler's Instagram story. Later that night, he was at some house party with people from our group, including Jess, whose car had mysteriously started working. That's when I decided to test them. I crafted this message about how my mom was in the hospital after a car accident, and I was scared and needed someone to drive me there because I was too shaken up to drive. I sent it to our group chat at seven PM on a Thursday. First response came from Emma an hour later. Oh, no. Hope she's okay. Keep us updated. No offer to help? Tyler hearted the message. That's it? Just hearted it like it was a funny meme or something. Just texted me privately saying she would help, but her boyfriend had the car. Brad said he was at work until late. Two others never even responded. Six people I'd called my best friends for four years, and when I needed them most, they all had excuses. But here's where it gets interesting. I have this coworker named Alex, who I'd only hung out with a few times outside work. He barely knew me beyond small talk about weekend plans. I decided to text him the same message just to see what would happen. This guy dropped everything. Called me immediately, said he was leaving his girlfriend's apartment right then to pick me up. Showed up at my door 20 minutes later with snacks and a phone charger, asking which hospital and if I needed anything else. I felt so bad. I almost came clean right there. Instead, I told him my mom was okay, that it was just a Scare and false alarm. He was genuinely relieved and said he was glad to help anytime. Meanwhile, my so called best friends were still posting TikToks and Snapchat stories like nothing happened. The next day in our group chat, everyone asked how my mom was doing. I said she was fine. Thanks for all the support. The sarcasm went right over their heads. Emma even had the nerve to say that's what friends are for with a heart emoji. I started pulling back after that. Stopped initiating conversations, stop suggesting plans. Guess what happened? Nothing. They literally didn't notice I was gone. Three weeks passed before anyone texted me directly, and it was only because Tyler needed someone to cover his shift at the pizza place where we both worked. Last weekend was the breaking point. I saw on Instagram they all went to this escape room place we talked about going to for months, the same place I'd suggested multiple times, and got shut down. There they were, all six of them, posting stories with captions like squad goals and best friends forever. So I made my decision. I started a new group chat called Real Friends Update with just Alex and two other people who'd actually shown they cared. I posted about moving on from fake friendships and finding people who actually value you.

With measured movements, he slid them further away with one finger, told me to leave them. I walked around him to retrieve them, keeping up everything neutral. When I sat back down with my glasses, he spun around to face the entire bar and announced loudly that we had a creeper situation. His voice boomed over the music as he pointed at me with his beer bottle, claiming I've been bothering this nice lady for an hour. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch, told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school. He grinned and turned to the bartender, suggesting I should be carded again because I looked about twice the brunette. Pulled away from his hand but he kept talking over her, telling her she didn't have to be polite anymore. Half the bar was watching now. Some people whispering, shooting me suspicious looks. My reputation at this place where I've been a regular for two years was being destroyed in real time. Then he decided to demonstrate my weakness. He grabbed my wrist, suddenly holding it up for the bar to see while comparing it to his 12 year old nephew's arms. I didn't resist, keeping my breathing steady as he squeezed harder, his thumb pressing into the pressure point. He yanked me off the bar stool, effortlessly spinning me around to show the girl what would happen if real danger showed up. Then shoved me back against the bar. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. He turned to the girl explaining this was why she needed someone like him around, painted scenarios of what could happen with me just standing there doing nothing if he was actually dangerous. The brunette stood up, said she was leaving. He grabbed her wrist immediately insisting he'd walk her to her car because the streets Weren't safe. Her voice was firm, but I could hear the fear underneath. When she told him to let go, he tightened his grip slightly, still smiling, saying he was just trying to help. She tried to pull away, but he held firm, told her to relax. He was just being a gentleman. His grip tightened enough to make her gasp. She was getting genuinely scared now. Panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.

Off my toxic friend group by creating a fake emergency to see who would actually show up. So I've been feeling like the backup friend for months. It started when I got really sick with the flu last winter. I'm talking fever, can't get out of bed sick. I texted our group chat asking if someone could bring me soup or medicine from the store. Radio silence for 3 hours. Then finally, Emma responds with, Oof, feel better. And that's it. But two days later, when Brad wanted people to come help him move his couch, four of them showed up immediately. I started paying attention after that. When I'd suggest hanging out, I'd get excuses. When anyone else suggested something, suddenly everyone was free. During conversations, they talk over me or just ignore what I said completely. At restaurants, they'd split the Bill evenly, even though I always ordered the cheapest thing because I was broke from college. The final straw was my birthday last month. I planned this whole thing at Dave and Buster's and invites two weeks early. The day of, I'm sitting there alone at a table for seven. One by one, the cancellations rolled in. Emma had a family thing. Tyler forgot he had to work, just said her car wouldn't start. But here's the kicker. I saw Tyler's Instagram story later that night. He was at some house party with people from our group, including Jess, whose car had mysteriously started working. That's when I decided to test them. I crafted this message about how my mom was in the hospital after a car accident and I was scared and needed someone to drive me there because I was too shaken up to drive. I sent it to our group chat at seven PM on a Thursday. First response came from Emma an hour later. Oh, no, hope she's okay. Keep us updated. No offer to help. Tyler hearted the message. That's it. Just hearted it like it was a funny meme or something. Just texted me privately saying she would help but her boyfriend had the car. Brad said he was at work until late. Two others never even responded. Six people I'd called my best friends for four years and when I needed them most, they all had excuses. But here's where it gets interesting. I have this coworker named Alex who I'd only hung out with a few times outside work. He barely knew me beyond small talk about weekend plans. I decided to text him the same message just to see what would happen. This guy dropped everything, called me immediately, said he was leaving his girlfriend's apartment right then to pick me up, showed up at my door 20 minutes later with snacks and a phone charger, asking which hospital and if I needed anything else. I felt so bad I almost came clean right there. Instead, I told him my mom was okay, that it was just a Scare and false alarm. He was genuinely relieved and said he was glad to help anytime. Meanwhile, my so called best friends were still posting TikToks and Snapchat stories like nothing happened. The next day in our group chat, everyone asked how my mom was doing. I said she was fine. Thanks for all the support. The sarcasm went right over their heads. Emma even had the nerve to say that's what friends are for with a heart emoji. I started pulling back after that, stopped initiating conversations, stop suggesting plans. Guess what happened? Nothing. They literally didn't notice I was gone. Three weeks passed before anyone texted me directly and it was only because Tyler needed someone to cover his shift at the pizza place where we both worked. Last weekend was the breaking point. I saw on Instagram they all went to this escape room place we talked about going to for months, the same place I'd suggested multiple times and got shut down. There they were, all six of them posting stories with captions like squad goals and best friends forever. So I made my decision. I started a new group chat called Real Friends Update with just Alex and two other people who'd actually shown they cared. I posted about moving on from fake friendships and finding people who actually value you.

voice_to_text: What family tradition ruined your family? My mother is the most baby obsessed psycho I've ever met. Starting when I was 8 years old, she made me and my sister Daniela wear these pregnancy simulation suits for hours every single day, 20 pounds of sand strapped to our stomachs while we practice breathing exercises and watch birthing videos. If we complained about back pain, she'd add more weight and tell us real mothers don't whine. She even made us practice breastfeeding with these creep be little dolls that would cry if you didn't hold them right. While I spent every session plotting my escape, Daniela embraced it as if it was her one true purpose. She'd waddle around the house with perfect posture, rubbing her fake belly and talking to it out loud. By the time she turned 16, she was begging mom to let her be a practice surrogate for her infertile work friends. And when she turned 18, mom threw her a massive party, not for graduating high school, but for signing her first surrogacy contract. Everyone was calling her a blessing and an angel while I sat in the corner feeling like I was at a livestock auction. Within three years, Daniela had carried three babies for three different couples. Each time she came home from the hospital, mom would parade her around town like she'd won a Nobel Prize. Look at my generous daughter giving the gift of life. Meanwhile, I was getting a biomedical degree. Volunteering at women's shelters and learning about bodily autonomy. But none of that mattered. Such a waste of a perfectly good uterus, I would tell anyone who'd listen. Her sister has blessed three families, while this one hordes her fertility for herself. The most terrifying part was watching Daniela deteriorate after her fourth pregnancy. At 22, she could barely walk without pain. Her hips were destroyed. She had constant infections and her hair was falling out in chunks. When I tried to talk to her about it, she grabbed my hands with tears in her eyes. Maria, this is what I was made for. My body is a vessel for miracles. Why can't you understand that? That's when I knew she was gone. So I played along just enough to keep mom off my back. Told her I was considering pregnancy, wore looser clothes to family events, even googled fertility clinics in front of her, all while secretly taking the LSAT and applying to law schools across the country. Lol. I specialized in reproductive rights and medical ethics, spending years helping women escape forced pregnancy situations. By 28, I was finally making a difference. So when mom invited me to Daniela's Celebration dinner, I figured it was just another pregnancy announcement. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out it was an effing intervention. Sweetie, you're not getting any younger, mom announced while Daniela sat beside her belly, swollen with pregnancy No. 5. So I've taken the liberty of starting your fertility Treatments. Before I could respond, she pulled out a syringe filled with hormones. Just a little boost to get those eggs flowing. I jumped back, but Daniela grabbed my arms from behind. Please, Maria, just try it. I've already found the perfect couple for your first baby. I screamed and fought, but mom was already coming at me with the needle. That's when I noticed the other syringes on the table. They've been planning this. Mom punched the needle into my thigh. I felt the cold liquid burn through my muscle. Within minutes, my vision blurred and my ovaries felt like they were on fire. Through the haze, I heard mom on the phone. Yes, started the protocol. She'll be ready for harvest in two weeks. That's when I realized this wasn't just about family pressure anymore. This was trafficking. I woke up in the ICU with ovarian hyper stimulation syndrome, so severe they nearly had to remove everything. My mom stood towering over me. We only brought you here because we wanted to save your womb, was the first thing she said. I pressed the red button for the nurse. We took one look at my mom and escorted her out to perform private examinations. As soon as we were alone, I felt even worse because she wrapped her arms around me and asked if I was okay. I broke down crying because the whole thing.

voice_to_text: 50 pound gym bro picked a fight with me to impress a girl, not knowing I was a taekwondo black belt. At 5 7 and 140 pounds, I wasn't exactly the most intimidating drunk. Guys at bars always picked me when they wanted to look tough in front of women. So when I saw this 6 2 gym bro marching over to where I was chatting with a pretty brunette, I already knew how this would go. He wedged himself between us, his massive frame completely blocking me out. Didn't even look at me, just turned his broad back like I was furniture. Let me get you a real drink, beautiful, he said. Flag down the bartender, not whatever this little guy was boring you with. She glanced around his shoulder at me, clearly uncomfortable. Actually, we were just, trust me. He cut her off, placing a protective hand on the bar in front of her, creating a wall. You need someone who can actually take care of you. He ordered her a martini without asking, then finally acknowledged my existence with a dismissive glance. You can go now, buddy. When I didn't move, he shifted his weight, using his size to push me further down the bar. The edge of the counter dug into my ribs. Still, I stayed put, sipping my beer. He'd expected me to scurry away by now. He turned to me fully for the first time, looking me up and down with theatrical disgust, asked If I, I was deaf or something. When I calmly said I was just finishing my drink, his hand shot out and swiped my glasses off my face. They clattered across the bar. Everything went blurry. He made jokes about me not being able to see up to his height, told the girl maybe that's why I hadn't gotten the hint. I stayed still, breathing normally. 10 years of training had taught me the most important lesson, real fighters don't fight in bars. Much liability, too much to lose my instructor certification, my gym, potential lawsuits all gone over some drunk idiot. I reached for my glasses. With measured movements, he slid them further away with one finger, told me to leave them. I walked around him to retrieve them, keeping up everything neutral. When I sat back down with my glasses, he spun around to face the entire bar and announced loudly that we had a creeper situation. His voice boomed over the music as he pointed at me with his beer bottle, claiming I've been bothering this nice lady for an hour. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch, told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch, told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school. He grinned and turned to the bartender, suggesting I should be carded again because I looked about twice the brunette. Pulled away from his hand but he kept talking over her, telling her she didn't have to be polite anymore. Half the bar was watching now. Some people whispering, shooting me suspicious looks. My reputation at this place where I've been a regular for two years was being destroyed in real time. Then he decided to demonstrate my weakness. He grabbed my wrist, suddenly holding it up for the bar to see while comparing it to his 12 year old nephew's arms. I didn't resist, keeping my breathing steady as he squeezed harder, his thumb pressing into the pressure point. He yanked me off the bar stool, effortlessly spinning me around to show the girl what would happen if real danger showed up. Then shoved me back against the bar. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. He turned to the girl explaining this was why she needed someone like him around, painted scenarios of what could happen with me just standing there doing nothing if he was actually dangerous. The brunette stood up, said she was leaving. He grabbed her wrist immediately insisting he'd walk her to her car because the streets Weren't safe. Her voice was firm, but I could hear the fear underneath. When she told him to let go, he tightened his grip slightly, still smiling, saying he was just trying to help. She tried to pull away, but he held firm, told her to relax. He was just being a gentleman. His grip tightened enough to make her gasp. She was getting genuinely scared now. Panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.

Have a friend who used to be your everything. Y'all were always talking, laughing at dumb stuff, venting, being weird together, making the most unhinged inside jokes that nobody else would get. And now they're just gone. Not even gone like we grew apart, but, like, replaced. Like they found a new group and suddenly forgot you existed. And they swear they still care. But the I'm going to sleep early is getting old. Especially when I see you online, in games, in calls with your new little friend group. Like, bro, I'm not stupid. I see the green dot. I see the whole friend list active. Don't lie to me and say it's nothing. You just stopped choosing me. And what hurts more is feeling like I'm just a backup now. Like I'm being kept around just in case the new group drops you or switches up. Like I'm the in case of emergency friend. I'm not a fostering safety net. You used to need me. Now I'm just convenient when you're bored. And I see it, I feel it, and it sucks. But you know what? I'm done begging for space in your life. I'm done waiting for a text back just to see you on Facetime with the new crew. I'm done being loyal to someone who already left me without saying a word. So, yeah, it hurts. It hurts like hell. But I'm not gonna sit here and cry over someone who doesn't miss me. I'm Gonna wipe my tears, put on lip gloss or chapstick, whatever. And remind myself I'm not the problem you fumbled. I was a real one. And when that new group starts acting funny, when you remember what it felt like to have someone who actually cared, just know this friendship doesn't do returns.

School thought they were geniuses when they made the Wi-Fi password impossible to crack. They didn't realize they just declared war on 2,000 bored teenagers with nothing but time and spite. It started when Principal Morrison announced the new policy. Students caught sharing the school Wi-Fi password will face immediate suspension. The password was 47 characters long, randomly generated every week and only given to teachers. My friend Marcus was the first to strike back. He brought a 30 foot Ethernet cable to cool and plugged directly into the computer lab wall. When Mr Morrison walked by, Marcus was sitting in the hallway, laptop connected, cable snaking under the door. Marcus, what are you doing? You using wired internet? Sir? The policy only mentions Wi-Fi. That cable is a tripping hazard. I put up caution sign. Marcus had indeed played tiny yellow wet floor signs every three feet along the cable. Mr Morrison updated the policy. No Ethernet cables over six feet. So Marcus brought six separate six foot cables and five friends. They formed a human chain, each person holding a laptop connected to each other, passing internet from the lab to the cafeteria like a digital bucket brigade. This is ridiculous, Mr Morrison said. This is compliance. Marcus replied, each cable is exactly six feet. New rule, no daisy chaining connection. That's when Jennifer got involved. She noticed the smart TV in the library was connected to Wi-Fi. She screen mirrored her phone to the TV, then used The TV's browser to create a hotspot that broadcasted her laptop. Jennifer, you're using the school Wi-Fi? No, sir, I'm using the TV's connection. The TV isn't a student. The TV doesn't need suspension threats, she added sweetly. Mr Morrison banned using school devices as intermediary. Alex took a different approach. He stood outside the teacher's lounge with a clipboard claiming he was conducting a password security audit for his computer science project. He'd ask teachers to write their password down to test memorability. Pattern 3 teachers actually did it before word spread. Alex, this is deception. This is social engineering research, sir. Very educational. Did you get the password? That would be unethical to reveal. Meanwhile, Sarah had noticed something beautiful. The attendance system auto connected to Wi-Fi when teachers logged in. She volunteered as an office aide and memorized the password as it briefly appeared on screen during setup. She didn't share it though. Instead she sold a service. Bring her device, she'd connect it for you, then change your Mac address so it looked like a printer. By week 3, half the school was showing up as HP Laserjet on the network. Why? Why do we have 400 printer? Mr Morrison asked AIT. Those aren't printers, I t replied. Then what are they? Creative student. The arms race escalated. figured out the password was always posted in the teacher's bathroom. Thinking students wouldn't see it there. He used a drone with a camera during lunch when The bathroom was empty. The footage was shaky but readable. Ryan, you flew a drone into school property into the courtyard. Sir, the bathroom window was open. I was investigating ventilation efficiency for my environmental science project. Mr Morrison put curtains on the bathroom window. But the man masterpiece came from quiet Emily. She noticed the school's old Wi-Fi routers were still broadcasting, just hidden from the network list. They'd forgotten to change those password. She connected to school Wi-Fi 2,015 with a password admin 1, 2, 3 and had faster internet than the teachers. Emily, that network was supposed to be decommissioned. Supposed to be isn't the same as was. Sir, how did you even find it? I didn't. My phone did. I have very aggressive auto connect setting. The breaking point came during standardized testing week. The online test required internet, so they had to give all students the password. Within minutes, someone had shared it on a paper airplane that flew across the gym. Then another student wrote it in chalk on the trap. A third person trained the morning announcements kid to say it phonetically while reading the lunch menu. Chicken Tenders, W1 f 1 p at SF, mashed Potatoes, w 0 r d, green Bean 2 dash 0 dash 2 dash 4 chocolate milk, exclamation point, hashtag dollar sign. Mr Morrison called an emergency assembly. Fine, you win. We're going back to open Wi-Fi with content filter. The auditorium erupted. Marcus raised his hand. Mr Morrison about those content filters, don't just don't already found 17 ways around them. Of course you have. The next day, the Wi-Fi password was, please just use salt responsibly, 2,024. Someone changed it to we promise, wink, 2,024. Within an hour, Mr Morrison pretended not to notice. He was tired. The students had won, and honestly, their grades had improved from all the technical research they've been doing. Sometimes the best victory is knowing when you've been outsmarted by 2,000 teenagers who turned your security system into their favorite class.

Wife asked why I wasn't fighting for our marriage anymore. Should I tell her? After three months of her girls nights turning into therapy sessions about how marriage was just a trap, I was done fighting. She'd come home at 2:00am, reeking of wine, telling me about her divorced friends, authentic lives, how they were finally free and living their truth. Last week, she and maybe I should have listened when they warned me about settling down. So I stopped trying. Yesterday, she noticed. You're not fighting for us anymore. If you really loved me, you'd wanna fix this. I looked at her calmly. You want me to fight for our marriage? Yes. Obviously. Okay. I pulled out my phone and called her best friend, Janet. The twice divorced one who'd been coaching her. Hey, Janet, it's James. Quick question. Do you think my wife should stay married to someone she regrets being with? My wife's face went white. That's what I thought. Thanks for the honest advice. I hung up and looked at my wife. Janet says you should definitely leave me. Congratulations. Your advisor just made the decision for you. She started crying. That's not what I wanted. Funny, because three months ago you said Janet's advice was the best thing that ever happened to you. But I wasn't done. I called Crystal. Next one who spends weekends bar hopping, crying about how all men are trash. Crystal, hey, my wife's been telling me about your amazing single. Life. Should she join you? Live that authentic truth you guys talk about through the phone? Crystal's voice got quiet. Well, I mean, maybe you two should work it out. Work it out? But you told her marriage was a prison last Tuesday. At least that's what she came home saying. I put the phone on speaker so my wife could hear Crystal back petaling. I was just venting about my own situation. I didn't mean. Oh, so when you said, dump his ass and live for yourself, you were just venting? Silence. Then I called Debbie, the twice divorced one living with her parents at third 5. Debbie, great news! My wife's finally ready to take your advice about leaving me. When can she move in with you and your mom? Move in? I. There's not really room here. But you said independence was worth any sacrifice. My wife was pale, watching her support system crumble in real time. After I hung up, she whispered, they were just trying to help. Debbie's eating cereal for dinner because she can't afford groceries. Crystal hasn't had a second date in two years. Janet's on antidepressants because she's so lonely. You don't understand their situations. I understand perfectly. Three miserable women convinced you to throw away a good marriage so you could be miserable with them. She sat down hard, but they said I deserved better. Better than what? A faithful husband who works two job so you can go to Yoga class. Better than someone who's never lied to you or cheated. The silent stretch. They said marriage kills your soul. Whose soul got killed? Mine. Listening to you repeat their poison every night. Or yours, because you let strangers reprogram you. She started crying again. I don't know what I want anymore. I do. You want their approval more than my love. You got it. The irony. Her friends are now panicking, realizing they pushed to too hard. Janet called later, begging me not to divorce her because she didn't really mean it. Crystal sent flowers with a card. We were just having girl talk. Debbie showed up at our door crying about how sorry she was. Turns out they wanted to live vicariously through her drama, not actually destroy her marriage. They wanted her to flirt with freedom, not actually choose it. Too late. The papers are filed. She's getting exactly what they convincing her she wanted. And now they're stuck watching their project fall apart, knowing they pushed their friend off a cliff just to see if she'd fly. She didn't. She's crashing, and I'm not catching her. This time yesterday, she asked if we could take a break from the divorce proceedings, just until I figure things out. I showed her the apartment listings I'd bookmarked for her. All in Janet's neighborhood, all way above her budget. Your girls can help with rent, right? Since they're so invested in your freedom? She stared at the prices. Video apartments for two thousand eight hundred dollars. One bedrooms for thirty five hundred dollars. I can't afford any of these. That's weird. Janet said money wasn't important when you're living your truth. Her phone buzz. Text from Crystal. Can you cover drinks tonight? I'm broke until payday. Another Buzz. Debbie, mom says I need to find my own place by Christmas. Then Janet, my ex, stopped paying alimony. Know any good lawyers? My wife looked at her phone, then at me. They're all struggling. No kidding. Almost like their advice came from desperation, not wisdom. She put her head in her hands. What have I done? You chose your sisterhood. Enjoy the membership fees. The moving truck comes tomorrow.

Bro, everybody's got that one disrespectful demon friend in class who simply cannot handle serious shit. Like we'll be sitting there minding our business and the teacher suddenly drops a bomb like my aunt passed away this morning. Whole class goes silent. Shit gets colder than a funeral home in Antarctica. And just as everyone's processing it respectfully, here go this bitch sitting next to me biting their lip, cheeks puffed up like a balloon, trying to hold in the most disrespectful giggle of all time. You look over and this fools got their hoodie pulled up, shaking violently like they got hit with a damn Taser, wheezing like a broken vacuum. And this disrespectful bastard keeps whispering, bro, imagine she died trying to twerk. I almost threw my chair. Meanwhile, the teachers up front with tears in her eyes clutching a picture frame and we over here looking like we trying to survive an exorcism. He still has the nerve to say, damn, she dead, dead. At this point my stomach is making satanic noises. I'm squeezing my legs so tight trying to hold in this demon fart that I might have caused a blood clot. But that's not even the worst part. The teacher starts showing a slideshow of her aunt like a full ass memorial Powerpoint and this motherfucker goes, why she look like a GTA character on Slide 3? I look at him like you going to hell and dragging me with you.

Every friend group has roles. Like there's no official title, but we all know who's who. First, the short one. They're always mad for no reason. They're 5 2, but got the aggression of a WWE wrestler. You try to joke with them and suddenly it's, say it again, I dare you. Small in height, large in rage. Then there's the tall one, built like a skyscraper, always asked to grab stuff off shelves, walks too fast, never fits in photos. Bruh. When you take a group pic, they're just a floating head in the back and somehow still slouching. The funny one, that's the one who roasts everyone equally. Heart full of love, mouth full of disrespect. You'll be having a serious convo and they'll say, you kind of look stupid today. Oh, hell no, man. Thanks. Then there's the delusional one. Thinks everyone's in love with them. Someone breathes in their direction and they're like, they want me get out. No, they ask for the time. Chill. The fashion one shows up to 7, 11 like it's Paris Fashion Week. Whole groups in hoodies, they're in rings, chains, flared pants, sunglasses. At night, bruh, they always say something like, it's just something I threw on. No, it's not. You planned that fit three weeks ago. The smart one, the walking calculator, the one we all copy during tests. They'll be like, I didn't even study and then get 98%. Oh, hell no. Meanwhile, we're out here failing with Notes open. But that's the squad. Unmatched, unstable, and somehow it just works.

Friends think I'm the innocent one. Wait till they find out what I do for a living. Seven years since graduation, and these women still had me mentally catalogued as the virgin who cried during health class. Lena took it upon herself to arrange a reunion for our high school friend group. I was curious what everyone had been up to, so I went. Big mistake. Second I walked in. Oh, my god. You look exactly the same. Still our innocent baby. They handed me an actual juice box while they opened three bottles of wine. We got you apple juice since you probably don't drink, Ashland said. Like I was 12. Sit here, sweetie. She pointed to the floor. All of them took the couch and chairs. Every single seat except the floor. So there I was, 25 years old, sitting cross legged on Lena's carpet, holding a juice box while they clinked wine glasses above my head. They really thought I was the same shy bookworm from high school. Sure, ladies. Whatever helps you sleep at night. They started playing Never Have I Ever. But stopped. Actually. Wait. She won't have done anything. Ashley nodded to me, and they all laughed. I sipped my juice box. They told relationship stories, then caught themselves. Oops, forgot innocent ears were here. More laughing. Lena actually covered my ears during one story about her honeymoon. I'm 25 years old, and this grown woman covered my ears. They asked me to grab More wine from the kitchen. We need to discuss something real quick. I knew what this was. I walked slow, came back to sudden silence. They've been talking about me, obviously. We were just saying you'd be perfect for Lena's cousin. He's also. Ashley paused. Inexperienced. They all nodded like they'd solved world hunger. But wait, it got worse. Lena took my phone. No phones during Girls Night. You're always so anti social, reading your little books. My phone literally had 57 unread Instagram notifications. But sure, Lena, I'm anti social. We're going to Ashland's Bachelorette next month, April said. But it might be too much for you. The stripper stuff would make you so uncomfortable. They all agreed I'd be traumatized. Remember when she didn't even know what a thong was? That was freshman year. Eleven years ago. I leaned over to grab my juice box from the side table and saw Ashland's phone lit up next to it, the notification preview at the top. Adults only. No Virgin Mary. April. She actually believes the cousin thing. LMAO. I was about to say something when Lena's boyfriend Mark came home with one of his friends, Cooper. Ashlyn practically ran to stand next to Cooper. Nice to see you again. I wondered how often she was invited over, if she recognized him. Lena introduced me as the most innocent person she knows. Mark barely looked at me. Then his neck snapped to look again. His eyes went wide. Really wide. He pulled out his phone. Type something quick, and his face went from confused to shocked. Holy. Mark showed Cooper his phone. The girls stopped talking. What's wrong? Lena asked. Mark looked at me, then at Lena, then back at me. Your innocent friend is. He couldn't finish. Just turned his phone around. Whatever was on that screen made Cooper's jaw drop. No way. No way. He started frantically googling something. The girls tried to see, but Mark pulled the phone back. She. There's a special guest at Denver Con and Seattle. And Cooper kept scrolling, eyes getting wider. This can't be her, Lena said, trying to grab Mark's phone. She doesn't even wear makeup. But Mark and Cooper were having their own conversation now. Both staring at their phones, then at me, then back at their phones. The one from TikTok, Cooper whispered. 3 million views, Mark confirmed. His eyes went huge. Is that. The girls were getting angry. What are you looking at? Ashlyn demanded. Cooper turned red. Did faking it actually work out for you? I pretended to be my cousin, the substitute teacher for a day and accidentally got my dream job. I was 19, broke as hell, and still waiting to hear back from community college. My cousin Tyler was a substitute teacher who sometimes paid me to drive him around since his car was trash. One Tuesday morning, he calls me, freaking out. Dude, I just rear ended someone. I'm supposed to be at Westbrook Middle School in 20 minutes. If I miss another day, they'll cut me from their sub list. I was eating cereal in my pajamas. That sucks, man. Wait, he said you still have my school I D. From when you helped me move those boxes last month? Yeah, why? I'm serious. Let's go pretend to be me. Take attendance. Keep them quiet. It's just study hall. I laughed. You're insane. Please. They won't even check. Most subs just sit there anyway. It's one period. Something about the desperation in his voice got to me. Plus, I needed money. I threw on Tyler's spare button down shirt that was way too big and drove to the school with his laminated badge. The front desk lady barely looked up. You must be the sub for Miss Peterson's class. Room 2 13. Here's your clipboard. I walked down that hallway trying to look confident while my heart was pounding. The kids were loud, but not crazy. I took attendance, reading names off The roster. When they asked where their teacher was, I said she had a family emergency and today was independent study. Can we work on homework? This girl asked, absolutely, I said, having no clue what else to tell them. For an hour, I just walked around pretending to supervise while they did whatever. Some kid asked me about math, and I said I'd get back to him. Another wanted to use the bathroom, and I let, like, five kids go because I didn't know the rules. The bell rang, and a whole new group of kids walked in. Nobody had told me there were multiple periods. I panicked, but tried to play it cool. Same routine independent study day. The projector wasn't working, so sorry, no video today. I made them read silently and told them I'd be grading papers instead. I just stared at Tyler's lesson plan book, trying to figure out what I was supposed to be doing. Third period came, then fourth. I was making it up as I went. When kids got too loud, I'd say stuff like, remember, this affects your participation grade, even though I had no idea how grading worked. During lunch, I hid in an empty classroom and texted Tyler updates. He kept saying, you're doing great. Just get through the day. Fifth period, this kid asked me about the Revolutionary War assignment. I panicked and said, what do you think the most important battle was? Then I made them debate It. While I googled stuff on my phone under the desk. By sixth period, I was actually getting comfortable. These kids weren't that different from my little brother and his friends. I started a trivia game about random stuff, and they were actually into it. Then the assistant principal walked in. My

Younger sister begged me to stop treating her like a baby and leave her alone, but one night made her instantly regret it. Gabby slammed the door shut and crossed her arms, glaring at me. It's freaking nine PM and you pick me up from a party? I placed the car in first gear and drove off, ignoring her snarky attitude. I've told you this before. That neighborhood, those parties there, they get sketchy after 10. She rolled her eyes and placed her feet up on the dash. I'm 16, not 6. I'm an adult. You need to stop treating me like a kid. I sighed. You are a kid, and I'm trying to keep you safe. Why not just enjoy it? She burst out into a harsh laugh. Enjoy it? How can I when you've always got to stick up your bum every time I go to a party? It's so stupid. But ever since mom and dad died, you act like I'm made of glass. News flash, that was seven years ago. All I want is a normal sibling relationship, not a fake parent to replace them. I felt my blood boil at her comment. I pulled over on the side of the road, fighting back my anger. Fine, fine. You know what? You want freedom? Then you can have it. From that moment on, I just left her alone. No more checking in, no more taking care of her. When she asked to go to parties, I Just shrugged. Whatever. Her eyes lit up. She went out that night and didn't come home until 2:00am. At first, she bragged to everyone. My brother finally chilled out. He doesn't even ask where I'm going anymore, but sometimes I'd see her chat bubble open, typing to me before disappearing. When she got the flu, instead of taking off work like usual, I just left Gatorade and Tylenol on the counter, only to come home at midnight to find her sobbing, crawling to the bathroom. We also stopped eating together, stop talking all together. Even. For her birthday, I stayed in my room while she set up and cleaned everything herself. No gifts, no birthday greetings. After a few weeks, she stopped bragging to her friends, looking lonelier than ever. Then that Saturday morning, she came into the kitchen while I was making coffee. There's a part party tonight at that really dangerous neighborhood you told me to stay away from. Cool, I said, stirring my coffee. She stared quietly like she was waiting for a longer answer, then finally snapped. That's it? Just cool? You're not gonna tell me to come home early or pick me up at 9 p m. Like a psycho? I glanced at her. Yep. Can't you at least show you care? Like a brother? Ugh, forget it. I don't need you anyway. Yeah, I said, sipping my drink. You made that pretty clear. She grabbed her jacket and

Secret ruined your friendship. I was 15 when my crush, Lucia, pulled me aside after chemistry class. We've been close since sixth grades. I need you to promise me something, she whispered. Her pretty eyes not meeting mine. For a moment, I thought she was going to ask me to the dance. I've been working up the courage for weeks. But something in her voice made my chest tighten. Anything I said, that's when she told me about Friday, how she'd been planning it for months. The teachers who ignored her cries for help, her parents who only cared about her grades. She taking her mom's gun from the locked drawer. The next day she was going to publicly end her life. She planned it all out, a live stream during third period when Miss Lillian would be teaching, when Mister Cole would be in the faculty lounge, when everyone who'd failed her would be watching. She'd make sure they'd see, make sure they'd carry it forever. But not you, she said, squeezing my hand. Don't watch. You're the only one who ever really saw me stood there frozen, feeling her fingers intertwined with mine. Something I dreamed about for months, but not like this. Never like this. Lucia, you can't, I whispered. It's the only way they'll learn. She's the only way things will change. That night, I didn't sleep. I stared at her Instagram, scrolling through photos where her smile never quite reached her eyes. Had I missed It the way she'd stopped eating lunch, how she wore long sleeves even when it was warm. The poem she'd started posting, beautiful but dark. So dark I thought about Miss Lillian who was tough but had three kids at home. Mr Cole who was new and trying his best. The other students who'd see it happen live. The trauma that would ripple through our school like a stone dropped in still water. But Lucia trusted me. She'd held my hand. She'd chosen me to confide in. Wasn't that worth something? By the time three a. M. Hit, I was typing and deleting texts to. What if I was overreacting? What if she hated me forever? What if I lost the only girl who'd ever made me feel like I mattered? Then I imagine the alternative, her empty desk and chemistry. Her parents at a funeral instead of graduation. A live stream that could never be unseen, all because I stayed silent. 5:00am, I called the sewer's light prevention hotline. They connected me to the police. My voice cracked as I explained everything. The officer's tone grew urgent asking for details. I wished I didn't have. Lucia's full name, her address, the exact time she'd mentioned you're saving her life, the officer said it felt like I was ending it. They got to Lucia at 7:00am just as she was setting up her phone in her bedroom. Pills were already laid out. The note was already written. The local news Called it a mental health crisis intervention. They interviewed our principal, who promised better resources, more counselors, real change. They never used our names, but Lucia knew. She didn't come back to school for two months. When she did, she wouldn't look at me, wouldn't answer my texts. Her new friends formed a protective wall around her in the hallways. I heard whispers that I betrayed her, that I violated her trust, that I only did it because I couldn't handle rejection. The school did change. They hired two new counselors, started a peer support program, trained teachers on warning signs. Everyone said I'd done the right thing, but I felt like I'd lost everything. Three years later, on graduation day, I found a note in my locker. I instantly recognized Lucia's handwriting. What I read made my heart drop full.

When Jake and I got engaged, she tried to announce her own engagement at our party. When we bought our first house, she suddenly started house hunting, too. And I'm so excited you finally decided. Maya took the bait. Over the next few weeks, she started casually bringing up the name Aurora in random conversations, testing how we'd react. Aurora is such a beautiful name, don't you think? She'd say. Watching our faces carefully, I played along perfectly, acting slightly uncomfortable whenever she mentioned it, like she'd stumbled onto our secret. Two weeks later, Maya went into labor. She actually had the audacity to say, I hope you don't mind that we ended up using Aurora when she was born. It just felt so right for our daughter. I know you guys were considering it, too. Scariest thing a family member has ever told you. I was 23 when my family decided it was time for me to collect my first wife. They already had her picked out.
