I took everything that's mine when my roommate asked me to move out. So I was living with this girl, Megan, who I thought was my friend. We'd known each other since freshman year. And when she said she found this perfect apartment and wanted me to sign the lease with her, I jumped at it. Five months of splitting everything, 50 50, doing dishes like good little roommates, never fighting over anything. Then one random Tuesday, I get this text while I'm at my job at the campus bookstore. Hey, we need to talk when you get home. That's never good, right? So I'm driving back thinking maybe she wants to talk about whose turn it is to buy toilet paper or something stupid like that. But when I walk in, she's sitting on our couch with this weird serious face she starts with. So I've been thinking and I already know I'm screwed. She tells me she doesn't think living together is working out and that she already talked to our landlord about me moving out by January 1st. I'm just sitting there like, what the hell? Because we literally never fought. I paid my half of everything on time. I cleaned up after myself and I even bought all the good stuff for our place. But she's acting like I'm some nightmare roommate who's been making her life miserable. I don't argue because honestly, why would I want to live with someone who doesn't want me there? So I tell her, fine, I'll start looking for a new place. She seems relieved like she was expecting me to throw a fit or something. That night I'm lying in bed thinking about how I need to pack everything and that's when it hits me. I look around our apartment and realize I bought literally everything that makes it nice. 50 inch TV mounted on the wall. Mine, the leather couch were always watching Netflix on. I saved up three paychecks for that thing. The coffee maker, the good plates instead of paper ones, the router for our internet, even the freaking shower curtain. Next morning I tell Megan I'll be taking all my stuff when I move out. She just says, okay, like it's no big deal. I don't think she really thought about what that meant. I spent the next two weeks apartment hunting and found this decent one bedroom across town. On moving day, I rented one of those big U Haul trucks because I knew I'd need it. Megan wasn't even home, which was probably for the best. I started with the obvious stuff like my clothes and my desk. Then I unplugged the TV and carefully took it down from the wall. I wrapped up the coffee maker, packed all the dishes I'd bought from target and loaded the couch onto the truck with help from my buddy Jake. The router was the last thing I grabbed. I unpacked all the Ethernet cables and took The whole setup. As I'm walking out with it, I realised she's going to have zero internet until she gets her own. But here's the thing that really made me laugh. When I was packing up the kitchen stuff, I realised I'd bought all the cooking supplies too, the pans, the good knife set, even the can opener. I left her with basically nothing except a mini fridge and some random cups she had from high school. By the time I finished loading everything, the apartment looked like nobody had ever lived there, just empty rooms with some random junk scattered around that wasn't worth taking. I drive to my new place. Feeling pretty good about myself. I'm unpacking when my phone starts blowing up. First it's texts, then calls. Megan is absolutely losing it. What the hell did you do to the apartment? She screams. When I finally pick up, it's completely empty. I tell her calmly that I took everything I paid for, just like I said I would. She she starts yelling about how she looks like an idiot because her friends were supposed to come over that night and now there's nowhere to sit and nothing to watch. You can't just take everything, she says. How am I supposed to explain this? I remind her that she literally said okay when I told her I was taking my stuff. She hangs up on me.

A guy touched my dad while he was about to hurt him and it was so funny. It worked. My sister Ava was off limits. That wasn't a discussion. It was law in our house. According to dad, when she turned 13, she already had boys from school calling our house and he'd answer with, she's not available until she's 30. My brother Tom and I fell in line naturally. We'd been through the teenage guy phase ourselves, so we knew exactly what went through their heads. When Ava started high school, we all watched her like Hawks. We'd always make sure no guys were bothering her at school. Dad kept a baseball bat by the front door for emergencies for whenever Ava mentioned a boy's name. We weren't crazy, just protective. When Ava was 15, some senior asked her to prom. The three of us dropped her off at his house at ten PM just to introduce ourselves. He ended up staying home that night. Ava cried for a week, but we told her we were just keeping her safe. Then out of nowhere, she had a boyfriend, Jackson. Ava brought him home for Thanksgiving. She gave us exactly 12 hours notice, probably hoping we wouldn't have time to prepare. She was wrong. When Jackson arrived, he was everything we expected, clean cut, nervous, kept calling dad sir out of respect. We circled him like sharks. Tom crushed his hand during the handshake, holding on three seconds too long. I asked him about his intentions while flipping a kitchen knife between my fingers. Dad just sat there silent, occasionally glancing at the baseball bat. Jackson stuttered through dinner, dropped his fork twice. This one would break easy. But then something shifted. By dessert, Jackson had stopped stuttering. When Tom made another comment about protecting what's ours, Jackson just nodded and said, I'd expect nothing less. She's lucky to have you all. When I tried to corner him about his career prospects, he calmly explained his five year plan, then asked about mine. Even Dad's silence didn't rattle him anymore. He just sat there occasionally touching Ava's hand under the table like we weren't three large men plotting his demise. Tell dad didn't like this at all. Who did this kid think he was? We talked in the garage while Ava showed him her old room. He's not scared yet. We need to do more. For three days, we made Jackson's life hell. Tom would accidentally wake him up at 5 a. M. With his workout music, took him on a hiking trip that was basically a death march through the woods, hoping he'd tap out. Dad made him help rebuild the deck in freezing weather, giving him the wrong tools on purpose. But Jackson just kept showing up, kept smiling, kept holding Ava's hand. By day four, we were furious. On his last night, Ava ran to the store for ice cream, leaving Jackson alone with us. This was It. We all walked up to him, surrounding his chair. Tom cracked his knuckles. I crossed my arms. Dad loomed over him, all 6 foot 3 of angry father. We could tell he was nervous. Finally, a real reaction. We stared him down, hoping he'd crack. But then Jackson did something none of us expected. He stood up slowly, looked dad straight in the eye, reached out.

I didn't go to my brother's wedding over a bridesmaid dress. My brother Jake was getting married to this girl who seemed super sweet at first. She was all smiles and hugs whenever I was around. But when it came time to pick bridesmaid dresses, her true colors started showing. She wanted everyone to wear this specific coral pink dress that cost $800, not including alterations. I'm a college student working part time at a coffee shop, making barely enough to cover my rent and ramen noodles. $800 might as well have been 8,000. I politely told her I couldn't afford it and asked if there was maybe a cheaper option or if I could get something similar in the same color. She literally laughed at me and said if I couldn't afford to be in her wedding, maybe I shouldn't be in it at all. But then she quickly backtracked when she realized how that sounded and suggested I could just borrow money from my parents. Here's the thing, my parents died in a car accident when I was 17. Jake knew this. His fiance knew this. I've been on my own since then, working my way through school with student loans and whatever jobs I could find. I explained my situation again, thinking maybe she forgot. She rolled her eyes and said I was being dramatic and that everyone has to make sacrifices for weddings. Then she suggested I could sell some of my stuff or pick up Extra shifts to make it happen. I was already working 30 hours a week on top of full time classes. I had nothing left to sell except my laptop, which I needed for school and my car, which I needed to get to work. The whole thing made me feel like absolute garbage. Jake wasn't much better. When I went to him for help, he said his fiance was just stressed about wedding planning and that I should try to understand. He offered to lend me the money, but I'd have to pay him back within six months with interest because they were saving for a house. Interest from my own brother, for a dress I'd wear once to watch him marry someone who clearly thought I was beneath her. That's when I realised this wasn't really about the money. It was about respect. She could have easily picked a less expensive dress or worked with everyone's budgets. Instead, she chose to make it a test of who really wanted to be there for her special day. I told Jake I couldn't make it work and wouldn't be in the wedding party. He got angry and said I was being selfish and trying to ruin his big day. His fiance jumped in and said she wasn't surprised because I'd always been jealous of their relationship and was probably looking for an excuse to cause drama. The whole thing blew up. Jake said if I couldn't support him as a bridesmaid. Then maybe I shouldn't come at all. I said fine, and didn't go to the wedding. I spent that Saturday working a double shift at the coffee shop, making the money I would have blown on a dress I'd never wear again.
NA

What's the fastest you've seen a harmless joke turn fatal? I'll never forget seeing the new kid, Ben, sitting alone at his desk at Tuesday morning, tears streaming down his face, while the entire their class erupted in laughter around him. He was almost completely deaf and had been an easy target every single day since he transferred to our school. A few guys stood behind him, their mouths moving in exaggerated yells that Ben couldn't hear. Making obscene gestures and mimic king sign language, while Ben just saw everyone laughing at him and pointing. Gabe would take it to the next level, as he'd go as far as to scream right behind him, knowing he wouldn't react. The math teacher had stepped out to make copies, and in those five minutes, they'd already reduced Ben to tears. His eyes darted around the room, desperately trying to understand what was so funny, what he'd done wrong this time. But he just couldn't understand. I tried to help him, but every attempt just made things worse for both of us. When I stood up and told them to stop in lunch last week, he just laughed and said I had a crush on the stupid deaf kid. Which became another joke that followed me through the halls. At least three or four incidents every single day, always when teachers weren't looking. Always calculated to make Ben feel the biggest loser in our whole school. I reported it to the principal twice. But she just said, boys will be boys, and that Ben needed to learn to stand up for himself. How could he stand up to harassment he couldn't even hear? Gabe was a literal monster, but I had no idea how far he was about to go. I made one last attempt to handle this the right way by going directly to the guidance counselor with my documented evidence. I showed him three weeks of detailed notes explaining how the bullying was escalating, how Ben had started eating lunch in the bathroom, how his grades were dropping because he was too anxious to focus in class. I told her all about how Gabe had been harassing him daily, making his life a living hell. She looked at my notebook side and said that I should focus on my own education. I thought she was joking at first, but then I realized the guidance counselor was friends with Gabe's mom, and I knew she didn't believe any of it. Ben needs to learn to communicate better with his peers. Communicate better? How the hell was he supposed to communicate with people he couldn't even hear? I was about to say that, but then a loud ringing sound went off in my ear. The fire alarm started blaring right next to me, and everyone filed out in the usual chaos of an unexpected drill. I was already outside when I noticed those same guys huddled together, laughing nervously but trying to play It cool. They were talking about something, but I had too much on my mind to listen. The building was actually smoking. I'd never seen this before, because this wasn't actually a drill. We all stood outside watching it. When I heard one of them say, yo, we should probably tell someone now. I was listening. Gabe told them to be quiet, but another guy said, guys, we can't just leave him there. That fire is huge. I knew who him was immediately. I asked what they meant. Gabe had tears in his eyes. Ben still in there? We left him as a joke because he couldn't hear the alarm. The building was now engulfed in flames, windows shattering from the heat.

While I delivered a baby, the mother asked, where's your nearest trash can? Why, it's in the corner of your room. I gestured toward the small medical waste bin while cradling the Newborn, who was struggling to breathe. Go ahead and toss it for me, please. She said it so casually, like she was asking me to throw away a tissue. What? Ma'am, this is your baby. I held the infant closer to my chest protectively. Look at it. The little turd is hardly alive. He can barely breathe. Just do us all a favor and throw it out. Her pupils were dilated and she kept scratching at her arms. Absolute not. I turned away from her and started checking the baby's vitals. I'd seen the track marks on her arms during delivery. The baby was born premature and underweight, with clear signs of neonatal abstinence syndrome. His little body was already going through withdrawal from whatever substances his mother had been using during pregnancy. He needed immediate medical intervention, not a trash can. The mother started getting agitated when I didn't comply. She sat up in the bed, despite having just given birth 20 minutes ago. Her hospital gown was soaked with sweat and blood, but she didn't seem to notice or care. The way she looked at her own child like he was garbage made my stomach turn. I knew I had to get this baby to the NICU immediately. His breathing was shallow and his skin had A bluish tint that worried me. Every second counted. But I also couldn't just walk out without following protocol. I needed to document everything and alert social services about the mother's request to dispose of her child. I'm going to take your son for treatment now. He needs oxygen and monitoring. I kept my voice calm and professional. The mother's eyes narrowed. She looked around the room like she was calculating something. Then her whole demeanor changed. Her face contorted into fake panic, and she started screaming at the top of her lungs. Help me! This woman is trying to hurt my baby! Her voice echoed down the hospital corridor. Within seconds, three other doctors rushed into the room. Doctor the Peters and Doctor Burton looked between me and the screaming mother, trying to assess the situation. Behind them, Nurse Melendez appeared, looking concerned. They all knew me, but they also had to respond to a mother's distress call about her Newborn. Put the baby down and return it to the mother. Doctor Peters used his authority voice. No! I'm trying to save this baby's life! She asked me to throw him in the trash can. She's not in a state to care for him. I held the infant tighter. The mother's performance escalated. Tears streamed down her face as she reached toward me with shaking hands. She's insane. Why would anyone want to throw out their baby? I looked desperately at my colleagues. They had to see through this. Act. The baby in my arms was barely breathing and needed immediate care. His mother was clearly high and had just asked me to dispose of him like medical waste. But the other doctors were looking at me strangely. Doctor de Burton stepped closer with his hands up, like he was approaching a dangerous animal. Gabriella, did you take your medication today? When we hired you, you promised to never miss a day of your medication. My heart sank. They thought I was having an episode. Five years ago, I'd had a brief mental health crisis. During my residency, I've been properly diagnosed and treated for bipolar disorder. I've been stable on medication ever since. But that history would always follow me. Now this manipulative woman was using it against me. I never
NA

My family staged an intervention over our McDonald's wedding. So we're three months from the wedding, and I make the mistake of telling my family we finally booked our venue. A big mistake. My mother in law immediately goes into interrogation mode. What's the theme? Is it rustic beach? I say it's a surprise, and she literally follows me to the bathroom door, going, I carried that boy for nine months. I deserve to know if I need waterproof mascara for three weeks. It escalates. My sister in law creates a group chat called Wedding Venue Detectives. My cousin starts checking venue parking lots for our cars. My mother in law accidentally opens our mail claiming she was looking for coupons. My aunt shows up at three different venues with my photo, asking if we have a reservation. The breaking point is this family dinner where my mother in law ambushes us with a laminated list saying, these are all possible venues within 50 miles. Just point. My sister adds, we need to know. I look at my husband, who mouths, just tell them like a broken man. I look at his mother with her Office Depot laminated list. My sister recording for Instagram, my cousin, who's been stalking parking lots. Something in me breaks. You want to know so badly? Fine. I stand up slowly and make eye contact with everyone. We're having our reception at McDonald's. I let that hang for three full seconds, watching their brains buffer Someone drops their fork. The one on Main Street with the Play Place. It goes that's not funny, but I'm stone faced. We already put down the deposit. My husband catches on, immediately nod seriously, the manager, Gary, is really excited. My sister's wine glass shatters on the floor. My mother in law asks about dinner and I go everyone gets Happy Meals, nuggets or Big Mac. No substitutions. My aunt starts crying you cannot feed my friends nuggets at your wedding! Meanwhile, my uncle practically throws his wallet at us asking if it's about money. I do a quick Google and show them someone did this already in 2,015. First dance under the golden arches, I say wistfully. My sister in law shrieks about her two hundred dollar shoes and how they just cannot touch a McDonald's floor. My husband commits fully. Instead of cake, we're doing an apple pie tower. Ronald McDonald is officiating. I add we're registered at McDonald's for gift cards. My mother in law looks at me with pure betrayal. What will Father Michael think when he finds out you're getting married by a clown next morning? My mother in law shows up with menu brochures. This barn is available! I'll pay for everything! I pull out the fake McDonald's catering menu I made at 3:00am. Too late. We customized our Mcflurry Bar. Oreo for my side, M&M for his. She grips the door frame. By day three, my cousin reveals they had an emergency Family meeting and created a Powerpoint to convince my husband and I to call off the McDonald's disaster. They called it Operation Real Venue with Slide 7 titled signs they've lost their Minds. Week two, my aunt calls crying that she can't tell her book club my knee.
NA
NA

What's the most delusional thing someone has said to you with a straight face? My best friend asked me to quit my 180,000 dollar V P. Position to watch her kids because daycare is for people who don't have friends with maternal instincts and she could not miss her wine tasting certification course. Madison told me for years that I was meant to be a stay at home mom and a natural mother while dumping her children at my door every single day. Madison and I met at our first corporate jobs, where we both swore we'd be C E O s by 30. Then I had twins at 28 and everything changed for me overnight, while Madison kept climbing that ladder until she married a cardiac surgeon and retired at 20 9 to live her best life. The morning I told her I was leaving work to raise my kids, she hugged me and whispered, you're going to be such an amazing mother because you actually have those maternal instincts, unlike women like me who need more stimulation. When my husband got laid off and money got tight, she was the first to say staying home was still the right choice since I was so naturally nurturing and some women were just meant to be mothers. By the time my twins were two and I had my third baby, Madison had her first kid with her surgeon husband. Three weeks postpartum, she showed up at my door at six In the morning with her Newborn still covered in spit up, and announced, why would I pay strangers when my best friend is literally the best mother I know? Before I could answer, she was already backing out of my driveway in her new Range Rover, leaving her screaming baby in my arms while texting her personal trainer. Every morning became a hostage situation where Madison would ring my doorbell before dawn with her daughter and whatever emergency made it impossible for her to parent that day, from Pilates to brunches to urgent manicures that couldn't be rescheduled. When I suggested the elite daycare that her husband could definitely afford, she laughed and said, those places are where lazy parents abandon their children. But I have you. Why would I traumatize my baby with strangers? When Madison had her second baby, she didn't even pretend to consider childcare. You're literally glowing when you're surrounded by all these babies while I just feel trapped. So really, I'm doing you a favor by giving you more purpose in life. She dropped both kids with ear infections and stomach bugs while she attended charity luncheons where she'd complain about how exhausting motherhood was to women who actually watched their own children. She sent me midnight texts saying she needed me to take the kids for three days because her husband was at a medical conference and she absolutely had to join him, which I'd later see on Instagram was her at a Miami Spa resort while he worked while she posted champagne selfies. I was managing five kids through stomach flu and when I texted that her son had a fever of 103, she replied with a thumbs up emoji and asked if I could handle the weekend too since she booked a couple's massage. She threw elaborate birthday parties, taking credit for the Pinterest perfect decorations while telling other moms blessed she was to be so hands on even though I was doing everything while she got Botox. For six years, this was my life. While Madison remodeled her third house and posted about the struggles of being a stay at home mom. Her village that made it all possible, as she said in her posts, was literally just me watching her kids for free, including Christmas morning when she flew to Aspen because she desperately needed a break from the holidays. Everything shifted when my youngest started kindergarten and I had seven hours of freedom every weekday for the first time in six years. I updated my resume and started interviewing while Madison acted like I'd personally betrayed her by even suggesting I might want something beyond her childcare.

While filling her cavities, my eight year old patient asked, do grown UPS at your house play the statue game, too? I smiled. I haven't heard of that one. Her words slurred from the laughing gas. It's when I hear daddy's car and everyone freezes like statues. My hygienist, Sierra, raised an eyebrow. That sounds interesting. How do you play? When we hear the garage, Mommy says statue time and we all freeze wherever we are, Isabella explained drowsily. Even if I'm eating or playing, everything stops. That's when I noticed the faint yellow marks on her upper arm, mostly hidden by her sleeve. Sometimes I'm really good at it. Last week I held my spoon in the air for 20 whole minutes. She seemed proud. Mommy said I was the best statue ever. Twenty minutes is a long time, I said, gently adjusting her sleeve to see better. Fingerprint bruises? Old ones. Can you raise your arm for me, sweetie? I need to adjust the chair. As she raised both arms, her shirt rode up. Linear marks crossed her lower back, some scarred, some fresh. What happens if someone moves during statue time? I kept working, acting like I was just doing my job. That's losing. Daddy doesn't like when we lose. Excuse myself to get a different tool, stepping to my computer to pull up our mandatory reporting protocols. When I returned, I asked casually, and if you win the statue game? If we're all good statues, daddy, Walks through and goes to his room. Then we can breathe normal again. Sometimes he even says good job and we get to eat dinner. You get to eat dinner? Only if we win. Losers don't deserve dinner. But mommy sneaks me crackers later. I made a show of checking Isabella's chart while secretly measuring the bruise patterns with my pen light. 3 2 cm spread on the grip marks. Adult male hand size. Isabella, what other games does your family play? I asked oceaning my hygiene to discreetly check on the father. The listening game, where he asks questions and we have to answer exactly right. I pulled out my light open wide again. What kind of questions? Like who's the most important person in this house? The answer is always daddy. The light revealed slight scarring on her inner cheek, likely from biting during stress. Happens when someone gets the answer wrong. Sometimes no breakfast or lunch. My tummy hurts so bad, but crying makes it worse. My least favourite one is the quiet room. I set down my tools. Tell me about this quiet room. While I set up this X ray. I positioned the lead apron, noting how she winced when I touched her shoulders. It's the closet under the stairs. No light. We stay until we're sorry enough. I count to know how long I lasted. My record is 10,000 seconds. What's yours? The excitement in her voice broke my heart. That was over two And a half hours. That's a lot of counting, Sierra returned, mouthing her dad's asking how much longer you'll be. Mommy went in there last week, Isabella continued. He had to fold up real small cause she's bigger. Daddy said she forgot who pays the bills. Sometimes I hear her crying in there, but I can't help or I go in too. We Learned that rule the hard way. I took the X rays, handed her some stickers, and said, I need to develop these. Sierra will stay with you in the hallway. I called CPS from my cell. Active abuse case. Child has physical marks. Describes systematic torture disguised as games. Father is in waiting room. Returning, I pretended to review her chart. Isabella, has anyone else seen you play these games? No, silly. It's a family secret.

My daughter wanted me to be the mom who never punished her, so I became that mom. Amelia threw herself onto her bed, still wearing the clothes I'd caught her in when she climbed back through her bedroom window at 2:00am. Two weeks grounded. Are you actually serious right now? She grabbed a pillow and screamed into it. I was just at Tyler's party. Everyone was there. Everyone except you because you weren't allowed to go. I. I stood in her doorway, exhausted from waiting up. You snuck out. That's the issue. She sat up, mascara smeared under her eyes. Sadie's mom would never do this. She literally called the school last week and lied about Sadie being sick. When she skipped, Amelia kicked off her shoes. She trusts Sadie to make her own choices. She doesn't treat her like a prisoner. That's not trust, Amelia. That. That's being a cool mom who actually has her daughter's back. She stood up, fists clenched. All I want is a mom who covers for me sometimes instead of punishing me for being a normal teenager. Why can't you be like her? That night, I couldn't sleep. Amelia's words kept echoing in my head. Maybe I was too strict. Maybe kids did need freedom to figure things out. Her dad had been the lenient one before the divorce and she'd always loved him more. Was I pushing her away? The next morning, I knocked on her door. School today, if you want, I'll Call you in sick. Amelia's jaw dropped. Wait, what? You said you wanted me to have your back, so I'm having your back. She skipped three days that week. I called the attendance office, each time faking a cough. Amelia has the flu. Friday night she stumbled home at 1:00am, clearly drunk. The old me would have lectured her until sunrise. Instead, I helped her to bed, left water and Advil on her nightstand. I mumbled, thanks, mom, before passing out. I'd lay awake terrified, but kept repeating what I read online. Teenagers need autonomy. Natural consequences teach better than punishment. The lies got easier. Amelia would text she was at the library, but her Instagram showed her at the mall. I'd see beer cans in her backpack and pretend not to notice natural consequences. I reminded myself she'll learn on her own. Amelia started coming home with hickeys, peoples dilated, smelling like weed. Her sweet friends stopped coming around. Now it was kids with tattoos and vape pens who never came inside, just honked from the driveway at midnight. But Amelia seemed thrilled with the new me. She kissed my cheek randomly, bragged to friends on the phone about how chill I was. My mom literally doesn't care what I do, I heard her say proudly. Those words should have been my wake up call. Instead, I smiled, thinking I'd finally gotten parenting right. Thursday night, Amelia texted at ten PM, sleeping over at Sadie's to study for bio Test. Her dad called immediately, voice tight with concern. School night sleepovers. Since when I kept my voice casual. She needs freedom. Remember, I already said yes. But at eleven PM, Sadie's mom called. Is Sadie at your house? She said she was studying with Amelia. My stomach dropped, but I heard myself lying. No, haven't seen her. Maybe they went to another friends. I hung up knowing both girls were lying. But I committed to this path. At 1:00am, Amelia texted again. Actually at a party staying with a friend from school. Her dad was at my door in 10 minutes demanding we get her. She's being honest with us now. We have to trust her. God, I was an idiot. At 3 a. M, my phone rang. Amelia's voice was tiny, terrified. Mom, please come get me. Please. She was sobbing so hard she could barely speak. I'm at this college party. These guys said they were seniors, but they're like 25. One won't let me leave his room. He keeps giving me drinks. I locked myself in the bathroom when he tried to. Her voice broke. Mom, I'm scared. I flew out the door speeding.
NA

Why did my dad's no closing doors rule get him arrested? We had the weirdest rule in probably the entire state. No closed doors while changing clothes, ever. Not my bedroom door, not the bathroom, not even the closet. Teenagers hide tattoos all over their body if we let them, dad would say. Or they could be hiding pills in their pockets. My friends were horrified when they heard about it. Mickey came over once and watched me change from school clothes to normal ones right in the middle of our living room while dad sat there with his newspaper, glancing up every few seconds. That's so creepy, she whispered, and I wanted to disappear. My older brother had already escaped to college, partly because of rules like this. I counted days until I could leave, too. Mom tried to help without directly challenging dad. She couldn't change his mind about the rule, but she found ways around it. The shower has frosted glass, I mentioned one day while folding towels. You're only visible as a shadow. She also helped me rearrange my room, putting my full length mirror at an angle where it looked like you could see everything from the doorway, but there was actually a blind spot. Perfect for 30 second wardrobe changes. I got really good at it, too. I kept spare clothes in the bathroom and changed when dad was busy watching TV. Mom would create distractions, calling dad to fix something right when I Needed to change for school. For weeks, this worked perfectly. Dad thought he was enforcing his rules since doors stayed open. He even bragged to his co workers about how his visibility system kept me safe. But then one weekend, everything exploded. And ways I never imagined. Dad's colleague Rob came by to drop off work files. Dad was on a video call in his office. Mom was grocery shopping, and I just gotten home from track with my entire body sweating. I couldn't wait for Dad's call to end, so I ducked behind my mirror. Blind spot, like always. But Rob didn't know our house layout. He was looking for Dad's office and saw what looked completely wrong from his angle. A teenage girl hiding behind furniture to undress. He looked away immediately, but asked me a question that sounded oddly serious. Where's your father? I pointed to Dad's office, and he took off through the door. I heard him say, Jim, your daughter was hiding behind furniture to change clothes. Combined with these visibility rules you mentioned. Dad came out confused at first. She knows the rules about doors. Rob shook his head. Jim, she was hiding behind furniture to change. That is not okay. You're making her feel unsafe. The way he said it made Dad's face go pale from realization. By the next morning, everything was chaos. Rob, being a mandated reporter, had called CPS overnight. Two social workers showed up before breakfast asking to speak With me. Privately, they separated us into different rooms. Dad in the kitchen, me in the living room, mom in the bedroom. Can you explain the rules about changing clothes in your house? The woman asked gently. I'm just not allowed to close doors, I said. Not even while changing clothes? She wrote something down. So you felt the need to hide behind furniture because your dad doesn't give you privacy? I tried explaining the mirror trick, but it sounded worse out loud. So you developed evasion strategies to change clothes. She kept on writing in her notepad. Then they brought dad in. Sir, can you explain why your daughter cannot have privacy while changing? Dad's voice shook. It's just not closing doors for her safety. Kids hide all kinds of stuff. It's her body, the woman finished. And you think watching her prevents her from what? Being a delinquent? Dad nodded frantically. You require visual confirmation of your 16 year old

What's the worst parenting you've witnessed? I was dating this guy Mark for about six months when he finally introduced me to his 8 year old daughter Emma. He'd always made excuses about why I couldn't meet her. She was shy, going through a phase staying with grandparents. Red flags I ignored because I was falling for him. The first time I went to his house, Emma answered the door. She was this tiny, timid little thing who immediately apologized for existing. Sorry, sorry. I'll get daddy. Sorry for bothering you. Mark came to the door and didn't even acknowledge her. No hug, no how was your day? Nothing. She just disappeared upstairs like a ghost. During dinner, Emma asked quietly if she could have some ketchup. Mark exploded. You always want something. Can't you just eat normal food like a normal kid? This is why your mother left. I watched this little girl's face crumble. She whispered, sorry, daddy, and ate her plain chicken in silence while tears rolled down her cheeks. I tried to lighten the mood, asking Emma about school. Mark cut me off. She's not good at talking to people. Emma, go to your room. Adults are trying to have a conversation. She vanished again. I didn't see her the rest of the night. Over the next few weeks, I started noticing a pattern. Emma would try to exist quietly, but Mark treated her like an inconvenience he was stuck with. One day I came over. Early and heard him screaming at her upstairs, just like your worthless mother, nothing but problems. I found Emma sobbing in her room, which was basically a storage closet with a mattress on the floor. No decorations, no toys, no signs a child lived there. The breaking point came during Emma's birthday. Mark forgot completely. When I reminded him, he got annoyed and said birthdays are just made up holidays to make kids feel special. She needs to learn the world doesn't revolve around her. I couldn't take it anymore. I secretly bought Emma a small cake and a stuffed animal. When I gave them to her, she started crying and hugging the toy like it was the most precious thing in the world. Nobody ever gave me a present before, she whispered. Daddy says presents make kids spoiled. That night, Mark found the gifts and flew into a rage. He threw the stuffed animal in the trash and screamed at Emma for manipulating me into feeling sorry for her. She's got you fooled. She puts on this act to get attention. Her mother did the same thing, played victim until she got what she wanted. I watched him destroy this little girl's only source of joy while she stood there taking it like she deserved it. That's when I realised Mark wasn't just a bad parent. He was systematically breaking his daughter's spirit. The next day while Mark was at work, I went back to see Emma. She was Home alone. Apparently, he'd been leaving her by herself since she was 6. I sat down with her and said, Emma, you know none of this is your fault, right? You deserve love and kindness and presents on your birthday. She looked at me like I was speaking a foreign language. But daddy says I'm bad. Daddy says Mommy left because I cried too much as a baby. My heart shattered. This man had convinced his daughter that her own mother abandoned her because she was defective. That evening when Mark came home, I confronted him. I told him I'd seen enough and that how he treated Emma was emotional abuse. He laughed in my face. You don't know anything about parenting. Emma needs discipline, not cuddling. Her mother turned her into a weak, needy brat. I looked him dead in the eye and said, you're right. I don't know about parenting, but I know about basic human decency. Then I called Child Protective Services right in front of him. He went ballistic, screaming that I was destroying his family, that Emma would end up in foster care because of me. But Emma ran to me and hugged my leg.

What's the most obvious lie someone told you? I was working at a phone shop when this mom stormed in with her 15 year old daughter, demanding I fix her iPhone that broke for no reason. The girls yelling at me about how I sold her a piece of junk and wants a full refund on a phone she bought four months ago. Mom's backing her up, saying her responsible daughter always uses a case and this is clearly a defect product. I take the phone to examine it. The screen is completely shattered, there's sand in the charging port, and it smells like chlorine. This has water damage and impact damage. I explained. The warranty doesn't cover dropping it in a pool. Girl loses it. I never dropped it. It just stopped working. Mom demands my manager immediately. He's at lunch, I said. But I can call the district manager if you want. The daughter smirks at her mom. B there's scared. They know they're wrong. Mom pulls out her credit card. Just give us a new phone and we'll dispute the charge later. I shake my head. Ma'am, I can't exchange a phone that's been damaged by the customer. Customer? The girl laughs. More like victim of false advertising. She starts loudly complaining to other customers in the door. Don't buy anything here. They sell broken phones. The mom joins in. This is going straight to corporate. What's your name? I point to my name tag. It's right There! Well, you just cost yourself a job. The mom says, my husband's a lawyer. The daughter's getting older. Yeah, and my dad's gonna sue this whole company! She grabs the broken phone from my hands. This is evidence of your defective products! I try to stay calm. Please don't handle the device. Sharp glass could cut you. Don't tell me what to do! She snaps. You work retail! I'm the customer! The mom nods. Exactly. The customer is always right. Not when they're lying, I said quietly. The girl gasps dramatically. He just called me a liar, mom! Did you hear that? Mom's face turns red. I want your manager now! Call him back from lunch! And I want a new phone plus compensation for emotional distress! The daughter adds she's waving the broken phone around. This thing could have exploded and killed me! I notice other customers starting to stare. The mom notices too and speaks louder. This employee is harassing my daughter and refusing to honor your warranty! The daughter feels bold. I just wanted my phone fixed and he's being so mean to me! The mom hugs her. It's okay, sweetie. We'll get this resolved. She turns to me with fury in her eyes. You've made my daughter cry. I hope you're proud. I'm calling corporate right now. She continues dialing on her phone. The daughter whispers something to her mom, who nods and hangs up. Actually, we're going straight to the news. This is a Story they need to hear. The girl notices my own damaged phone on the counter. What's
NA

Toddler saw a bride taking photos at the park and screamed, don't do it. The bride stopped mid pose. Her photographer looked confused and about 30 wedding guests turned to stare at my three year old daughter Emma standing by the playground swings. I was mortified. Emma had this habit of saying random things loudly at the worst possible moments, but this was next level embarrassing. Ma, honey, let's go play on the slides, I whispered, trying to drag her away from the wedding party, but she wasn't having it. She broke free from my grip and marched right up to the bride, tugging on her dress. Lady, don't marry the mean man, Emma said, pointing directly at the groom. He's gonna hurt you. Everyone went dead silent. The groom's face went red and he started walking toward us looking angry. Hey, what kind of kid says something like that? What are you teaching her? I started apologizing, explaining that Emma was just 3 and had an active imagination. But then the bride knelt down to Emma's level and asked quietly, sweetie, why do you think he's mean? Emma pointed to a bruise on the bride's wrist that was barely covered by her dress sleeve. My mommy had marks like that when the bad man lived with us. She cried at night, too, just like you smell like tears under your makeup. My heart stopped. This kid had been through way too much for her age, but she developed this Weird ability to spot things adults tried to hide. When my ex was still around, Emma would always know when I've been crying, even if I thought I'd covered it up perfectly.

My mom checked our location 14 times a day until it destroyed our family. Mom's eating breakfast scrolling through Facebook while Dad's counting out quarters for gas money when she announces we're all downloading Life 3, 60. We're two months behind on the electrical, but her friend says this app is the only way to keep family safe and honest. I'm 17 and work hard time at target while my dad does construction. We don't have time to be anything but safe and honest, she says. If we have nothing to hide, we have nothing to fear, which sounds like something a dictator would say. But whatever. She makes us install it right there at the table and checks that everyone's location is on. And I realize immediately what she doesn't understand about this app. Life 3, 60 doesn't just show where you are, it shows your speed when driving, your phone battery and sends notification for everything, including when someone checks someone else's location. Mom works from home doing medical billing and has nothing but time to watch that app all day while dad and I are actually out in the world. Perfect. Now I'll know everyone's safe, she says. But what she means is now she can watch us like the musical jolly chimp from Toy Story. Her phone buzzes and she glances at it. Oh, shoot, I have a doctor's appointment in an hour. Dad offers to drive her, but she says, no, she needs the car. All day for errands. After months ago, my mom asked me to start covering for her when she goes out saying she shopping or at the doctors. Whenever dad asks where she is, men lose interest when you mention women. Things she tell me she doesn't realize she just set herself up. Day one and my phone buzzes every 10 minutes with mom, check your location. While I'm at school, dad text me she checked me 14 times this morning and we both realize she's literally sitting there refreshing the app constantly instead of working. Day three, mom calls me screaming because the app says I was going 67 in a 65 and threatens to take my keys. So I start driving under the speed limit, which means I'm late to work and my manager writes me up. Dad gets stuck in traffic, won't go even 1 mile per hour over because mom will see shows up 30 minutes late to his job site and loses a client worth $2,000. Week 2, she sees I stopped at McDonald's for 3 minutes and lectures me about wasting money, which is rich considering she was at the grocery store for 4 hours yesterday and came back with just milk saying nothing good on sale. Dad checks the app and asks her 4 hours at one store? And mom stares at me like I should have warned her he was checking, but how can I when she's watching my every move? She used To text me to cover for her. Now she can't without dad seeing our messages about her lies. Week three, she's at a medical plaza until eleven PM Dad mentions that's your fourth appointment this week. You okay? She snaps. Women's health is very thorough but I've been to that clinic. They close at 6 that night. Dad asks me privately, does your mom seem sick to you? I pull up her location history, all those medical building visits and we're both hoping it isn't true. However, the electric Bill arrives marked final notice and dad slams it on the counter so hard the salt shaker falls over. I gave you $400 for that and mom says processing delay. It's fine. Dad and I are both staring at her location pins on the Week 5 and dad texts me, I'm leaving work early. Something's not right. Meet me at the Medical Plaza. We both see Mom's been there since 11:00am and it's now six PM I tell my manager I'm sick. Drive over, Dad's already there in the parking lot looking at life. 3, 60 zoomed in. Her car is not here, I say and dad points across the street where the pin actually is. We both see it at the same same time. Royal Flush Casino. Dad's face goes white. No way. We walk in together. She's at the penny slots with a bucket of coins, empty drink cups stacked everywhere. She's been here all day. She's talking to Another woman. My family thinks I'm at the doctor. It gives me all day here. She puts a 20 in the machine. This is from my daughter's paycheck. She'll never know. I step forward. I know now. Mom spends around seeing us both and dad holds up life. Three, 60, doctor appointment. She starts stammering, but her casino friend makes it worse. Just tell them about your system. You're due for a big win after last month's losses. Dad's voice cracks. Last month, how much? Now Mom's crying, saying 8,000, maybe more. I realized why she's been watching our location so obsessively. She needed to know we weren't coming home while she gambled away our money. I feel sick realizing this is where she went. All those times I told dad she was at appointments. I helped her lie so she could sit here feeding our rent money into slot machines. Mom admits she's been going every day for three.

My sister told me I was uninvited from our family reunion, so I took my barbecue and all the drinks with me. I was marinating ribs at 6:00am when Lexi texted me, you're uninvited. We don't want you there. No explanation, just a cold dismissal from the person who never lifted a finger for these reunions. For eight years, I've been the backbone of every family gathering. I brought the smoker, bought all the alcohol, coordinated everything. Lexie just showed up and took credit while I did the actual work. She'd waltz in wearing some designer dress, pose for photos and act like she organized everything. While I was sweating over a hot grill, I stared at that text, hands covered in marinade, and typed back, fine, I'm taking my barbecue and drinks with me. An hour later, my phone exploded, 15 missed calls from cousins, uncles, everyone panicking. Wait, you're not coming? What about the food? Lexi said you bailed on us. My voicemail was completely full. Text after text rolled in. Please tell me you're joking. The reunion won't be the same without your brisket. What happened? That's when I realized Lexi's fatal mistake. She never told them she uninvited me. She just announced I canceled, left them scrambling with no backup plan. Classic Lexi, creating problems and expecting everyone else to solve them. I texted my cousin Matthew, Lexi uninvited me, but you're welcome at my place. I've got everything we need. Matthew immediately called back. Absolutely Furious. She did what? That's completely insane. I'm coming over and bringing everyone I can convince. Within minutes, half the family was choosing my backyard over Lexi's disaster. Even the neighbours wanted in. When word spread about the impromptu cookout happening on my street, my phone kept buzzing with acceptances. Uncle Hank on my way with the cornhole boards and my famous hot sauce. Cousin Liz bringing my potato salad and the good folding chairs. Even my elderly Aunt Diana said she'd rather come to mine because that girl has no business running anything important. By 10:00am, I had people showing up to help set up. My neighbour Jeff brought his outdoor speakers and string lights. The kids from down the street asked if they could use my pool. This was turning into something way bigger than any family reunion we'd ever had. Lexi started calling around noon, completely panicked. Where is everyone? Only six people showed up and I ordered food for 30. I could hear the desperation and anger in her voice. She tried to exclude me but ended up excl including herself from the real party. By one PM, I had 43 people at my house, the biggest party I'd ever thrown. The ribs were falling off the bone. The beer was ice cold and everyone kept thanking me for saving their weekend. Kids were splashing in the pool. Adults were playing cards and the whole neighborhood smelled like heaven. Meanwhile, Aunt Diana called me laughing, Lexi's Reunion is a complete disaster. She ordered pizza for 30 people and only has six there, including herself. She's blaming everyone but herself and having a complete meltdown in front of what's left of the family. The best part, three more family showed up uninvited because they heard through the neighborhood Grapevine about the legendary barbecue happening on Maple Street. Even people who weren't family wanted to join the.

video_description: what is the saddest fact you know that most people will not know#ask #askreddit #learnontiktok #reddit #story #redditbysubs#satisfying #relaxing
voice_to_text: What is the saddest fact you know that most people will not know? 1. The astronauts likely survived the challenger explosion. They were falling for nearly three minutes. Some of them had activated their emergency oxygen. Supposedly, there are audio recordings of their last moments. 2. A successful marriage ends with watching your spouse pass away. 3. The amount of abandoned pets that know they've been abandoned. 4. Very few people in your life would actually drop what they were doing to help you cherish the ones that would. Five. There's a recording of the last kawaii oo bird singing before it went extinct. It was a mating call sung by a male bird. The song has breaks for the female bird to respond. There's no response because the male kawaii oo is the last of its kind. 6. Your loved one didn't say any last words. For context, I worked in a nursing home. People always ask, did they say anything? And the truth is no. We obviously don't say that to the family, but it is not like in the movies. Also, a weird thing that happens sometimes is that 24 hours before passing away, they get a sudden spike of energy, which may look like they're getting better. So it confuses the family members. Sometimes working with old people broke me a little bit. 7. It took my dog a couple years to realize he was here to stay. I was his seventh owner. I am his Last he was returned to the shelter multiple times for behavioral issues, and when he acted out, he would immediately get depressed, thinking he was going back. Very good dog. Very happy now and has turned into quite an entitled princess. 8 whales never die of old age. They just become too weak to surface for air. 9 we abandoned the pigeons. We spent centuries domesticated them, being friendly to them, and as a result, they moved to our cities and relied on us. Then we decided they were pests. 10 the nurse by Einstein's bed when he passed noted that he said something sounding profound. Unfortunately, she didn't speak German, so we'll never know what his final words were.

voice_to_text: What was your I'm dating married to a fucking idiot moment? One girl I dated in college broke my laptop because she kept trying to get a USB drive in. Instead of, you know, flipping it, she just pushed harder and harder until it broke my port and motherboard. 2. My boyfriend refused to eat basil I had bought from the grocery store because it was a full plant. I was keeping it outside and he insisted that he would not eat dirty food. I asked where he thought farmers kept produce, and he said that they had special areas for food to grow that was sterilized, but my plant was not food grade. I just looked at him with a dumbfounded look. I didn't know how to respond. Three. On a camping trip, she was worried about parking the car on the grass because she thought the grass was going to grow, puncturing and flattening the tires. Four. My husband thought people whistled when they set off fireworks. He didn't realize the fireworks themselves whistles, though. That was one of his more harmless stupidities. Five. He thought potatoes never go bad because his mom always kept a bag in the pantry. I asked him if they ate a lot of potatoes and he said yes. They have a large family with six kids and it still didn't click. Six. I bought fresh broccoli and my husband asked why it was so big. He thought broccoli grows in small bite Size pieces

I announced that my dad's not paying my college tuition. my dad has always been the super cheap guy who acts like he's loaded but penny pinches everything. Like we're talking about a man who buys generic cereal and then pours it into name brand boxes so the neighbors think we eat the good stuff. He drives a BMW that's literally held together with duct tape and prayers. He parks it at the front of the driveway so everyone can see it anyway. I'm a senior in high school and college application season is here. All my friends are talking about where they're applying and their parents are stressing about tuition costs. Meanwhile, my dad keeps making these weird comments about how I better figure out my future because money doesn't grow on trees. But he never actually said he wouldn't pay for college, so I just assumed he would. Big mistake. I applied to my dream school and got accepted with a partial scholarship. I was so pumped and ran downstairs to tell my parents. My mom was excited and started crying happy tears, but my dad just looked at me and said, that's nice, honey. Hope you can afford it. I was confused and asked what he meant. He shrugged and said college was my responsibility now that I was becoming an don't. I felt my stomach drop. This man had literally never told me I'd be paying for college myself. We'd never had that conversation. I Was so angry and hurt that I decided to be petty about it. If you wanted to embarrass me, I'd return the favor. The next week was my 18th birthday party at our house. All my relatives were there, plus some family friends and neighbors. My dad loves showing off in front of people, so he was in his element, talking about his successful business and giving everyone financial advice. That's when I struck. During the cake cutting, I stood up and tapped my fork against my glass like I was making a toast. Everyone got quiet and looked at me. I smiled real big and said, thanks, everyone, for coming to celebrate with me. I just wanted to share some exciting news about my future. My dad looked proud, probably thinking I was about to thank him or something. I got into my dream college with a scholarship, which is amazing, because my dad just told me he's not helping pay for my education at all.

Who is a good person who turned out to be shockingly evil? 1. Bill Cosby. He was untouchable. He was the silly uncle we all wanted. Turns out he was a monster. 2, subway's Jared. 3, Jimmy Saville. The guy raised millions upon millions of pounds for charity, some places listing it at £45 million, nearly $60 million, and set up a £5 million charity fund before he died. But it was all a facade to hide what he really was. To call him an evil piece of shit would be an insult to shit. 4, Jim Jones was a prominent figure in support of the civil rights movement. He contributed significantly to desegregation activism in Indiana. He also performed a lot of charity work, establishing soup kitchens and providing food and clothing to the poor. 5, King Leopold of the Belgians. He presented himself as a humanitarian who was motivated by a desire to improve the lives of Africans. He was allowed to establish personal rule over what was then the Congo Free State. In reality, his regime caused the death of millions of Congolese inhabitants, including children. They were worked to death at gunpoint, systematically mutilated, murdered or starved to death. 6. In my small rural Indiana hometown, we had this well respected dare officer who later became mayor, who later was convicted of soliciting minors and possession of CP.

What is the most insane Reddit post you've ever seen? One? Probably the one where a man sought advice on how to handle his cheating wife, was advised to file for divorce, followed through and then news broke in the real world of a mother murdering her two children to prevent her soon to be ex husband from taking custody of them. The op later confirmed the news story was indeed about his wife and children. Horrendously sad. 2, the one where a dying mother told her teen that she was the product of an affair. Reddit encouraged the girl to tell her dad the truth. She took the advice and he kicked her out. Since he was the legal father, the state made him take her back in and he reacted by making life really difficult for the girl who by this point had no one else. She posted one last time on a sub about suicide saying that she'd taken something to end her life. 3, that dude that shot his dick off, cooked it and ate it, you slash worthless. 3, 19. 4 I don't remember the sub. There was this post by a woman who said she was worried about getting raped while out at night in the city. She was asking the area she should avoid and what would have to happen for someone to get away with raping her. People figured out the post was written by a guy trying to rape someone and Get away with it.

When did you realize you married the wrong person? 1. We were in the bathroom getting showered and dressed for a friend's wedding. I was in the best shape of my life at the time, feeling good about myself, and I thought I looked good in that suit. She was finishing her makeup and I remarked at how beautiful she looked. I waited for her to say something nice in reply, but she didn't. And it just hit me. I couldn't remember a single time that she complimented me on my appearance. So I said that to her. I said, you know, I always tell you how beautiful you are and how attracted to you I am, but I never recall you ever saying that I look good or that I look handsome. She stopped applying her mascara long enough to dismissively roll her eyes at me. So I made the mistake of asking her, do you even find me attractive? And she flatly said no. I asked, why did you marry me then? And she said, I didn't think it was important at the time. I never felt so ugly and unloved. And it hurt even more when I've been feeling so good about myself for once in my life 30 seconds earlier. 2, when I realized if we weren't dating, I wouldn't have wanted to be his friend. 3, I realized that I was hiding good news from her because I knew she would make me feel bad. About it. I hope she was going to grow up and stop being selfish and childish. She never did.

What criminal committed an almost perfect crime and what was the thing that messed it up? One, Robert Durst. He was caught while being interviewed for an HBO series to which he initially agreed on to clear his name. Went to bathroom and mumbled to microphone which he thought was off. What the hell did I do? Kill all of them. Of course, this was later presented to the court as evidence. You can still watch it on HBO. Two, the Dunbar armored robbery, the largest cash heist in US history. A six man inside job to rob an armored cash depot. They set up a house party as an alibi, use the keys to get into the cafeteria and waited in there until all employees came in on break, ambushed and subdued them without firing a shot or raising an alarm. They then loaded the money bags with over $18 million into a U Haul, destroyed the CCTV tapes and returned to the party. Then they sat on the money for six months before hiring a crooked lawyer to set up a real estate money laundering scheme to avoid suspicion. Two years after the robbery, one of the men paid a real estate broker with a stack of money still wrapped in the original currency strap. The broker immediately reported it to the police. After being arrested, he cracked under interrogation, confessed to the robbery and ratted out his partners. All the men have since finished their prison sentences. And most of the money was never found. So there's a chance they still won in the end.

What piece of history is deliberately being erased from existence? 1, when the allies liberated the concentration camps in Germany at the end of World War 2, they did not release the homosexual prisoners. 2, during World War 2, many people in France were generally receptive to Nazi ideals. And under occupation, some even participated in sending people to camps. However, after the war, history was often rewritten to glorify the resistance, which was actually made up of a small group of individuals opposing Nazi occupation. 3, the business plot. Yes, a group of powerful Wall Street figures tried to raise an army of 500,000 men to seize the White House, overthrow FDR, and install a fascist government. And yes, Congress investigated it under seal and concluded that the plot was real, but never named the conspirators. It's somewhat similar to what happened with Epstein. 4. There were more countries in the axis powers than just Germany, Italy and Japan. 5, Expansionist Japan and the atrocities they committed during the 1930s are completely skipped over in most school curriculum, even though it was less than 100 years ago. I've always found that baffling.

What is a scary science fact? 1. If the ozone layer ever disappeared, it's actually been healing. We would see the most beautiful auroras fill the entire sky. Then everything on earth would die. 2. Your eyes are in a different immune system. If the two immune systems found out about each other, they try to attack each other. 3. Not only are there more stars in the universe than grains of sand on earth, there's actually 10,000 stars per grain of sand. 4. You literally never touch anything. You're pretty much just floating around out here. 5. A human stomach can't digest another human stomach, as it contains the same mucus that actually made multiple cannibalistic murderers get caught because they went to doctors with stomach issues. 6. They're putting chemicals in the water and making the frogs gay. 7. If you were to leave earth at the age of 15 in a spaceship going at the speed of light and spent five years in space, you would come back 20 years old. But because of a phenomenon called time dilation, all of your friends who were 15 when you left would be 65. 8. The chance of me finding the person reading this and unaliving them is low, but never zero.

What's something people romanticize but is actually incredibly tough in reality? One war. Two. Living in Japan as a foreigner. There's a certain subset of people that really romanticize Japan and Japanese culture as highly advanced technologically and socially. It's not that Japan is actually particularly a bad place to live, but they still utilize antiquated technology, have dated social mores and brutal work life balance, and are quite xenophobic and openly turn away foreigners from many services, even medical care. It's not some anime Utopia where everything is perfect. It's quite a challenging place to live for foreigners. It seems Japan welcomes the visitor, but does not always welcome the immigrant. 3. Birthing and raising a baby. People will acknowledge that it's not easy, sure, but it's so much harder than imagined, especially if you don't have a good support system. 4. Not moving on from a partner like I still love you after years of not being together. That's super sad and unhealthy actually. Frown. 5. Farming. It's usually passed down from generation to generation because the startup costs would never meet the profits.

What's something fucked up you witnessed during your childhood but didn't realize the severity of until you were older. 1. My dad and I used to play spaceship and to get the spaceship started, I'd have to blow into a tube to hear the electronic beep. It was his DUI test to start the car before they started putting cameras in the cars. Glad he's sober these days. 2. I remember cuddling up with my mom when she had a brace on her nose. It's the kind you have after a surgery. And we talked about her nasal surgery. It took like 10 years later before I realized that the reason for that corrective surgery was my dad's fist. 3. I was sitting on the couch at when my parents started arguing and my mom threw a red book at my dad. Just thought it was a fight. Turns out it was their pre divorce fight after my dad caught her cheating. Didn't learn about the cheating until I was 16 and only recently Learned it was a brick that she threw at him. 4. This thread is dark and only gonna get darker. My mom strangled me when I was 11. My takeaway for a long time was how kind she was because she wrapped a folded towel around my neck before taking me to X ray. Kids will do anything to protect their image of their parents as good guys.

What's the creepiest thing a member of your family has ever said? 1, I had an uncle buy me silk underwear for my 16th birthday and when I opened it said you should try it on right now. Two, I was babysitting my nephew overnight and he told me there was people on the stairs. 3, my grandpa asked me if I was going to breastfeed when I was pregnant. I said I was absolutely going to try. He then gave one of my boobs a little jiggle and said with these little things, good luck. I was left with my jaw on the floor. 4, my grandfather cared for his handicapped daughter after she was hit by a drunk driver at 21. When he was super old, he said something like he deserves some sort of award, accolade for never sexually abusing her. Excuse me, what? 5, my alcoholic uncle at my 12th birthday party. You grew up real nice. If we're ever alone, I'll take it as a yes. I had no clue what he meant until I was older. 6, my 33 year old cousin tried to subtly convince me to have sex with him the night before his wedding when I was 15. When I was 17, I was at my family reunion and on the phone with my boyfriend and the same cousin grabbed my phone and said, why should she go across the street when she can go across the hall?

What is a disturbing fact you wish you could unlearn? One, Jeffrey Dahmer drilled a hole into some victim's skulls and tried pouring different toxic liquids into the hole. He was trying to make a sex slave that could eat and drink but could in no way fight back or escape. The worst fact is that victims might survive the first hole with all brain function intact and live long enough to be fully aware they were going to get a second or third hole drilled. Two, surgeons used to operate on infants without anesthesia, including open heart surgery. They have stopped this, however, in the 1980s. 3, manatees have vaginas that are the most anatomically similar to humans. Manatees may also be the inspiration for myths about mermaids, beautiful half fish women that lured sailors to their deaths. Connecting those dots has been mentally scarring. 4, that a dolphin committed suicide after falling in love with its handler that used to jerk the dolphin off. 5. When the challenger exploded in 1986, the astronauts didn't die from the explosion, nor did they die from depressurization as NASA has initially claimed. There is some evidence they turned on their personal oxygen supply. They died from impact. When they hit the surface of the Atlantic Ocean, they were in free fall for two and a/2 minutes.

He realized someone was all bark and no bite. My older brother Jacob ruled our house with terror. At 17, he was built like a linebacker and had everyone walking on eggshells. He'd corner me in hallways, shoving me against walls over nothing. Once he threw my laptop down the stairs because I used his bathroom. Mom would find me with split lips and black eyes. But Jacob always had an excuse ready. She fell off her bike again, he'd say, ruffling my hair like some caring big brother. You know how clumsy little sis is. The worst part, everyone believed him. Teachers, neighbors, even our grandparents thought Jacob was this amazing kid who looked out for his accident prone sister. He played varsity football, got decent grades and charmed adults with his fake smile and perfect manners. At home, though, I lived in constant fear. He'd wait until mom left for her nursing shifts, then make my life hell, holding my head underwater in the bathtub until I saw stars, locking me in the basement for hours, feeling my birthday money and laughing when I cried. I Learned to hide in my room the second I heard his chuckle up. The physical stuff was bad, but the mind games were worse. He'd break my things and blame me, tell mom I was lying about homework to get me grounded. he convinced her I was doing drugs by planting a joint in my backpack. I spent three months in Counseling. Because of that lie, everything changed. The night of his championship game, our whole extended family came to watch Jacob play. Aunts, uncles, cousins, grandparents, even mom's boss showed up. Jacob scored the winning touchdown and everyone went crazy cheering his name. After the game, we all met at Denny's to celebrate. The whole back section was reserved for us. Jacob was soaking up the attention, telling war stories about his epic plays while everyone hung on every word. I was picking up my fries in the corner trying to stay invisible when my five year old cousin Lily started crying. She spilled chocolate milk all over her new pink dress and was having a complete meltdown. The sticky mess was everywhere. Other diners were staring. Mom was trying to clean it up while Aunt Grace dug through her purse for wet wipes. Without thinking, Jacob snapped. Shut up, you little brat, he screamed, grabbing her tiny wrist hard enough to leave marks. Stop being such a crybaby. You're ruining everything. The whole restaurant went dead silent. Conversation stopped mid sentence. Even the kitchen seemed to quiet down. But here's the thing, Lily wasn't me. She wasn't trained to take it quietly and apologize. She looked Jacob dead in the eye, her face red with tears and said.

What is the most disturbing deathbed confession you've ever heard? One, a nurse once shared that an old man confessed to sabotaging his brother's parachute during World War 2 because they were in love with the same woman. His brother died and the woman married someone else. Anyway, he said he lived with the guilt every single day. 2. I had an elderly patient in his 80s who shared something devastating with me during transport to the emergency department. He told me that as his wife was dying, she confessed to having multiple affairs throughout their nearly 60 year marriage. She went so far as to tell him she had never loved him and that his only son wasn't biologically his. This man, who likely had only months left to live himself, felt compelled to share this burden with me during what was probably one of his final trips to the hospital. That conversation has stayed with me. I think about it often. 3. I wouldn't call this a confession exactly, but it happened just before a patient died. I was volunteering at a hospice caring for a man with severe dementia. In his final hours, he began reliving memories from his time as a Vietnam draftie. He mistook me and another volunteer for his old war buddies and started recounting what seemed to be a murder he'd been involved in after returning from service. According to his account, they had intended to kill only one man, but the situation escalated. And they ended up killing the man's entire family, his wife and her parents as well. What struck me most was his eerily calm demeanor as he described it. He wasn't distressed or panicked, just methodical and calculating. He was completely unreachable, lost in that memory. Despite our attempts to redirect him, he was in the middle of detailing how they plan to dispose of the bodies when he suddenly snapped back to the present and refused to speak to anyone for the rest of the day. He passed away that same evening just before dinner.
NA

The entire gym stopped working out when I walked in wearing my new sports bra. So I bought this cute new sports bra from target last week. Nothing fancy, just black with some pink stripes. I was excited to wear it to the gym because my old one was falling apart and I felt good about myself for once. I walked into my usual gym around six PM when it's always packed with college kids and people getting off work. The second I stepped inside, something felt weird, like really weird. Everyone just stopped what they were doing. The guy doing bench press literally let the bar rest on his chest and stared. The girl on the treadmill almost tripped because she turned her head so fast. Even the front desk worker stopped scanning membership cards. I thought maybe I had toilet paper stuck to my shoe or something embarrassing like that. Checked my reflection in the mirror wall and everything looked normal. Sports bra, leggings, sneakers, hair in a messy bun, same as always. But people kept staring and whispering to each other. I tried to ignore it and went to grab a yoga mat from the rack. That's when I heard this girl behind me whisper to her friend, oh my god, does she not know? Her friend shushed her really loud and they both walked away quickly when they saw me looking. Now I was getting paranoid. I went to the bathroom to check myself again. Maybe I had a huge stain or my bra was see through under the gym lights. But nope, everything looked fine. Sports bra was actually really cute and supportive. I felt confident in it. When I came back out, more people were staring. This older woman on the elliptical kept looking at me and shaking her head with this disgusted expression. A group of guys by the weight rack were pointing and laughing. I was starting to feel sick to my stomach. I decided to just start my workout and ignore everyone. I got on a treadmill and started jogging. The girl next to me kept glancing over every few seconds. Finally, she leaned over and said, hey, I don't wanna be rude, but do you know what that symbol means? I had no idea what she was talking about. What symbol? I asked. Pulling out my earbuds, she pointed at my chest area. On your sports bra, that's not just a design. I looked down at the pink stripes I thought were cute. But now that she mentioned it, they weren't just random stripes. They formed a shape I hadn't noticed before. My stomach dropped when I realized what it was. The pink stripes made a perfect swastika right across my chest. I felt my face turn bright red. Oh, my god. I had no idea. I just thought it was a geometric pattern. I was mortified. No wonder everyone was staring at me like I was some kind of Monster. The girl nodded sympathetically. Yeah, I figured you didn't know. You seem way too nice to be wearing that on purpose. But like everyone in here thinks you're making some kind of statement. I immediately stopped the treadmill and grabbed my towel to cover my chest. I practically ran to the locker room, feeling everyone's eyes on me. A few people were taking pictures with their phones. I wanted to disappear into the floor in the locker room. I called my roommate, Emma, freaking out. She drove over in like 10 minutes with one of her overs.

voice_to_text: What's something you can't tell your partner for fear of upsetting them? One. The first piece of jewelry I bought my wife was a necklace. We went on holiday and she lost it. I said I would replace it, but it wasn't the same. She was upset that she'd lost it for sentimental reasons. I emailed the hotel, and of course, they hadn't found it. So I bought a replacement and told my wife they found it. 2. Not me, but my parents. If my mom wants to hide literally anything from my dad, no matter what it is, she just puts it somewhere where he would have to bend over to see it. Doesn't matter if it's something like a package of ore. If my dad has to bend over to find it, he's never going to find it. I've tested it with my own snacks when I was still living with them to confirm it works. He'd be mad if he knew how many snacks we'd hidden from him simply because he doesn't bend over low enough to see it in the cabinet. 3. I wanted my husband to quit wearing denim shorts because they made him look old. He had gained a bit of weight, so I kept buying his shorts in his old size 34. And I bought khaki shorts in a 38. He will never read a label for any reason. He would put on the jorts and then lay on the bed and lift And spread his legs to stretch out the shorts a bit. He blew out the back seam of two pairs in the same day, then ended up putting on the khaki shorts. Since then, almost 20 years, he has insisted that khaki shorts are made better and fit more comfortably than denim shorts of the same size. Four the remote didn't disappear. I accidentally put it through the washing machine and destroyed it and threw it out in a panic. 5. I only put spiders outside when she sees them. If they're only noticed by me, I let them continue hunting bugs, sometimes with a few soft words of encouragement. You're doing a great job, little guy.
