Far would you go for your dog? Last month at the dog park, this couple approached me while I was throwing a tennis ball for my dog waffle. The woman immediately started sobbing when she saw him. Her husband had his arm around on her shoulders and explained through his own tears that I had their dog, their baby, who'd escaped from their backyard, and they'd been searching everywhere since I'd found waffle wandering around the parking lot behind my apartment building six months ago. No collar, ribs showing through his matted fur, and figured someone had dumped him. Husband pulled out his phone, showing me dozens of photos that definitely look like waffle. Playing in their backyard, swimming in their pool, sleeping on their couch. He said his name was Cooper, and when he called that name, Waffle's ears perked up and he barked, which made my stomach drop because I've been so sure he was abandoned. The wife was crying into Waffle's fur while he licked her face, and her husband pulled out his wallet and started counting hundred dollar bills. We'll give you five thousand dollars for him, he said, his hands shaking as he held out the cash. I know you've been taking care of him, and we want to reimburse you for everything, food and vet bills and your time, because you saved our baby's life. We thought our lives were over when he got out. I stared at the money feeling sick because I Didn't want their money, and I definitely didn't want to give up waffle. This dog had been my only friend through the worst breakup of my life, sleeping next to me every night when I couldn't stop crying about my ex forcing me to go outside when I wanted to rot in bed forever. But watching this woman sob while showing me more photos of their family vacations with him made my chest hurt. These people were destroyed by losing their dog. And here I was keeping him from his real family when I just been the person who found him. If they were willing to pay $5,000 just to get him back, he must mean everything to. I told them to keep their money and just take him, that I was glad he had people who loved him that much. The woman hugged me so tight I couldn't breathe while thanking me over and over. Waffle kept looking back at me as I handed his leash to the husband, probably confused about why I wasn't coming with them. The woman coaxed him toward their car with an excited voice, telling him they were going home. I told myself he'd be happier with his real family, with a yard and another dog to play with, like in their photos. The husband shook my hand and said, you're a good person. Not many people would do this. And I stood there in the empty dog park trying not to cry. But I couldn't stop myself. Waffle was such a good dog, and I had no idea when we woke up that that was my last day with him. The next three weeks were exactly as horrible as I expected. I kept looking for waffle every time I opened my door, kept saving bacon scraps before remembering he wasn't there to beg for them. I bought a goldfish just to have something alive in my apartment, but it wasn't the same as having someone genuinely excited to see me exist. I started taking different routes home to avoid the dog park, and threw out his bed because looking at it made me want to scream. But I told myself at least he was back where he belonged. I kept hoping I'd hear from his family, that maybe they'd send me a picture of him all settled in, but they never did. Then yesterday, I was scrolling through next door looking for a used coffee table when I saw a post that made me drop my phone. Someone had written warning dog kidnappers active in our neighborhood with a blurry security camera photo attached. The post explained that criminals were stealing purebred dogs from yards and dog parks and selling them to puppy Mills and collectors overseas for massive profits. They worked in pairs, usually a couple, and used fake sob stories about losing their beloved pet to guilt owners into giving up their dogs. My hands were shaking as I clicked on The photo to enlarge it. Even with the terrible quality, I could see it was them. The same couple from the dog park leading someone else's German bird into the same car waffle had climbed into. The post said golden retrievers like mine were especially valuable, particularly the English cream variety, which could sell for $20,000 to collectors in China. I hadn't even known waffle was anything special, just thought he was a regular golden retriever who needed a home. They'd stolen my dog by pretending to love him, using my own decency against me. And we're probably selling him to some.

Oh, if I had £1 for every time you asked me for hotspot I wouldn't even need to pay for data anymore I'd be rich I could buy an unlimited plan and still have spare change for snacks like why are you always out of data every single time we go out you're standing there like yo bro let me just borrow your hotspot real quick I just need to send one message one message turns into five Snapchats three TikToks a full blown Facetime and now your PS five is updating from my SIM card and you're out here watching YouTube in 4K like this is your plan like why is my phone overheating? Why is my battery on 12% and why is my service lagging when you're the one scrolling TikTok and then I try to cut you off and you hit me with it's just for a sec bro I'll turn it off in a minute you never turn it off in a minute my phone's still beaming Wi Fi to you while I'm asleep and you never have the courtesy to warn me you just assume I got data to spare like I'm a mobile network provider meanwhile, I'm out here rationing my 20 gigabyte like it's 1943 turning off background apps reducing video quality texting instead of calling but you you're out here on Spotify streaming full albums like I'm your personal tower and don't let them say bro just use your unlimited unlimited who Has unlimited. You think I made a signal in 5G? That stuff is expensive. I'm out here on a budget and you're running up data like you're mining bitcoin. But I'll give you credit. You always act surprised when I say no. Like, wait, what? You can't hot spot me? Yes, I can't. I'm broke. I have bills. I need data too. You're not the main character in this friendship, my guy. If you're that friend, get a new plan or at least come with snacks to pay for the inconvenience. Data isn't free just because we're friends.

My grandmother asked me, do you wear that bracelet I sent you every day? My stomach sank. What bracelet? She pulled out her phone and showed me a receipt. 3,000 dollar custom gold bracelet with your birthstone delivered four months ago. I'd never seen it in my life. My mom suddenly got very interested in her coffee cup. Dad started scrolling through his phone like nothing happened. The air in the restaurant felt thick with tension. Mom, I said slowly, did you, you sign for a package addressed to me? Her face went red. We thought it was a mistake. Grandma sends so many things. A mistake? Grandma's voice could cut glass. I had it engraved with his name. And track the delivery myself. I watched my parents exchange that look, the same guilty look they've been giving each other for months. Whenever grandma brought up gifts or money, I thought I was being paranoid. But now everything was starting to make sense. Show me the tracking information. Dad interrupted, trying to sound authoritative. Grandma scrolled through her phone. Delivered to your front door on March 15th at two forty seven PM signed for by Leora Hensley. She looked directly at my mom. That's you, isn't it, Leora? My mom's hands started shaking. I, I don't remember every package that comes to the house. You don't remember a 3,000 dollar piece of jewelry? Grandma's eyebrows shot up. That's when I noticed my sister's new tennis bracelet sparkling on her wrist. The Same design, the same stones, the same everything. My stomach dropped. I'd seen Alara wearing it for weeks, bragging to her friends about how she'd treated herself after getting good grades. The Alara's idea of treating herself was usually a five dollar coffee, not luxury jewelry. Alara, I said, staring at her arm. Where did you get that? She yanked her sleeve down faster than I'd ever seen her move. I, um, saved up for it. Alara works part time at a smoothie shop making $12 an hour. She spends most of her paycheck on makeup and clothes. There was no way she had $3,000 saved up. How long did you save? I pressed, feeling my anger building. Like a few months, she mumbled, not making eye contact. A few months of smoothie shop money bought to a 3 thousand dollar bracelet. Mom jumped in. Alara's been very responsible with her money lately. Really? I turned to my parents because last month she asked me for 20 dollars for gas money. The month before that she needed 50 dollars for textbooks. Just last week she was complaining about being broke. Dad cleared his throat. Warren, you're being dramatic. Maybe Alara got a bonus or from a smoothie shop. I cut him off. Lara, what's the most expensive thing you've ever bought with your own money? She fidgeted with her napkin. I don't know, maybe my phone case, which cost like $30. The math wasn't mathing. And everyone at the table. Knew it. Grandma leaned forward, her eyes locked on Alara's bracelet. Show me that bracelet now. I don't wanna take it off, Alara said, her voice getting smaller. It might fall.

The one thing you don't talk about in your family. Back when I was 14, my dad and I were cleaning off his workbench. I found what I thought was a melted piece of metal wrapped up in a cloth. I asked him what it was and he said something along the lines of, wow, I didn't think I still had that. He told me that one day when I was over 18, he tell me what it really was. For four years, that thing consumed my thoughts. I'd sneak into the garage during family barbecues, Christmas mornings, random afternoons just to stare at that wrapped object in Dad's toolbox. The cloth was old and stained. Sometimes I pick it up, feeling its weight, trying to guess what could require an 18th birthday revelation. My friends thought I was crazy. Just unwrap it when he's not home, they'd say. But something about Dad's tone that day stopped me. I tried everything to get him to crack, bribery, guilt trips, bargaining. What if I get straight A's? What if something happens to you before I turn 18? Nothing worked. He'd just get that same distant look and say, when you're 18, son. The mystery drove me insane. I'd lie away creating elaborate theories, each more dramatic than the last. Uncle Mike used to be Dad's business partner and best friend. Small construction company, always laughing. At family gatherings, Mike was like a second father, teaching me football, sneaking me extra dessert. When mom wasn't looking. Then when I was 8, Mike just disappeared. No goodbye, no explanation. When? When I'd ask, mom would get this weird look and change the subject. Dad would mumble about Mike moving to Arizona. Our house changed after Mike left. Dad started locking the garage at night. He'd get jumpy whenever someone knocked on the door. Mom would find him staring out the kitchen window at 3:00am just watching the street. They thought I didn't notice, but kids pick up on everything. Years passed. No Christmas cards, no phone calls, like he'd vanished. But sometimes I'd catch dad staring at old photos of them together. The morning after my 18th birthday, I cornered him in the kitchen. Today's the day, dad. He sat down, his coffee with shaking hands. You sure you wanna know some things? Once you know them, you can't unknow them. I nodded. Heart pounding. He disappeared into the garage and came back with that familiar bundle. We sat at the kitchen table as he slowly began unwrapping it. His hands were trembling. This is about Mike, he said quietly, about why he really disappeared. The cloth fell away, revealing something jagged and twisted. Mike and I were doing well with the business, but Mike started getting greedy, skimming money from job sites, overcharging clients. I kept covering for him, thinking he'd straighten out. Dad's voice got quieter. One night, Mike showed up here completely drunk, eyes wild. Your mom?

Have you ever taught someone a new language only to have it backfire horribly? The most gorgeous boy in our school, Parker, slid a signed Taylor Swift vinyl across the cafeteria table and asked me, so, can you teach me Japanese? I nearly choked on my apple juice. Parker was the guy every girl wanted. Soccer captain, perfect smile, the kind of handsome that made teachers forget what they were saying mid sentence. And he was talking to me, the girl who spent lunch reading. Why do you need Japanese? I told Akira I lived in Tokyo for a year. He rubbed his neck. Stupid first day lie. Now she keeps speaking Japanese to me, and I just nod like I understand. Akira Suzuki, of course. The exchange student who'd basically become our school's Akira in character. She had Disney princess eyes and a smile that made every guy melt. Her cousin's birthday party is in three weeks. She invited me. He pushed the vinyl closer. This is signed from the heiress tour. It's yours if you help me. His brown eyes actually looked panicked. Not like other girls. She cares about real things. I can't mess this up. I held the vinyl up to the light to examine it. Pen pressure, check. Letter spacing, check. It really was an authentic signature. You got yourself a deal! I exclaimed. First lesson, Parker showed up with coffee and colour coded notebooks. Adorable. Okay, basics first, I said. Konnichiwa genki desu ka no He leaned forward. Teach me how to flirt in Japanese. How to not sound like a tourist. I wanna talk to her about things she cares about. That was sweet. I expected him to want cheesy pickup lines. Start with pronunciation. Say Akira. Akira. No, you need to soften the R. Like this. Akira. He tried again. Failed. I sighed. Here. I took his hand and placed it on my throat, ignoring how my pulse jumped. Feel how gentle it is. Akira. His fingers spread against my neck. Akira, he whispered, and suddenly the room felt too small. Better? I stepped back. Practice that. Something in my chest fluttered. You're a really patient teacher, he said on Wednesday, after finally nailing a difficult phrase. You're a good student, really. He grinned, and I realized I never seen him truly smile before. Not the popular guy smile. A real one. By week two, we moved past basics. I caught him Haiku in his car after practice. He'd repeat lines about cherry blossoms while I tried not to notice how the sunset made his eyes look like honey. What does this mean? He showed me a line he found. When I think of you, I forget both time and place. Throat went dry. It means love makes you lose track of everything else. Huh? He stared at the words. That's beautiful. Thursday we practice traditional dance moves. I wasn't sure why, but he insisted that it would come in handy one day. Anything for a Taylor Swift signed vinyl, I guess. Terrible at this. He laughed as he stepped on my foot again. You're not. I adjusted his hand position. Just follow my lead. His mom walked by his room and smiled at us. Sorry about her, he said. She thinks we're. Never mind. What? Nothing. But his ears turned red. The final week, something shifted. He text me Japanese puns late at night. Bring me mochi because I mentioned loving it once. Stay after our sessions just to talk in English. You know what's weird? He said. Tuesday night, lying on his bedroom floor while we studied. I started this to impress Akira, but now I just really love the language. Yeah? Yeah. Like this. He sat up. How do you say I lose track of time with you? Key me to IRU to jikan wo suru tsuretsushimae. He repeated it, looking right at me. The air went thick. That's, um. That's good. Akira will like that, right? Then came our last session. He was fluent enough to hold conversations, quote poetry, even make jokes. He Learned an entire language in three weeks. Let's do one final practice, he said. Full romantic confession. My stomach hurt. Okay. He took my hands. I tried to memorize the feeling. Kimi to iru to subete GA imi WA motsu Kimi WA zutto bokunoko kocoron iita. When I'm with you, everything has meaning. You're like a song that was always in my heart. I couldn't breathe. Couldn't stop wishing those words were for me. Perfect, I whispered. You're going to sweep her off her feet. Something crossed his face. Think Akira will feel it, too? How could she not? Friday, the whole school watched Parker approach Akira at her locker. I stood by the water fountain, feeling sick. Oh, hi. You Akira San Yankee. Good morning, Akira. How are you? She turned surprised. Then he started speaking the Japanese I taught him.

I've got my daughter a hotel room entirely for herself after her stepsisters made her sleep on the floor. My ex husband remarried three years ago to this woman, Beth, who came with twin daughters Madison and Mackenzie. They're both 15, same age as my daughter Chloe. When Chloe stays there every other weekend, she has to share a room with both of them because apparently there's no space for her to have her own room in their four bedroom house. Last month, Chloe came back from her dad's place looking exhausted. I asked what was wrong and she just shrugged it off like usual. But when she fell asleep on the couch at seven PM, I knew something was up. My kid never goes to sleep early unless she's sick. The next weekend she came back looking even worse, dark circles under her eyes, cranky all day, complaining about everything. Finally, I cornered her in the kitchen while she was making cereal. What's really going on at your dad's place, I asked. She stirred her lucky charms for like a full minute before answering. The twins think it's funny to make me sleep on the floor. They told me their beds are too good for someone who doesn't really belong in their family. My stomach dropped. What do you mean sleep on the floor? She looked up at me with these tired eyes. They took my pillow and blanket the first night and hid them when I asked, dad. And Beth about it. Madison said I was lying and that I probably just lost them. Beth believed her instead of me. I felt my face getting hot. Where does your dad think you sleep in the bed with them. That's what they tell him. But every night after everyone's asleep, they wake me up and make me get on the floor. They say if I tell dad, they'll make sure he knows what a troublemaker I am and maybe he won't want me visiting anymore. That was it. I grabbed my phone and called my ex immediately. Your daughters are making Chloe sleep on the floor, I said as soon as he picked up. What? That's not true. She shares the bed with them. Ask them right now if that's what really happens at night. There was silence and I heard him calling for the girls. Five minutes later, he called back. They admit they've been making her get on the floor, but they say it's because she kicks in her sleep and keeps them awake. the solution is to make a 15 year old girl sleep on a hardwood floor with no pillow or blanket? Are you insane? We'll figure something out, he said. But I could tell he was already making excuses in his head. No, we won't. I've already figured it out. The next Friday when it was time for Chloe to go to her dad's, I drove her straight to the Hampton Inn down The street from his house. Instead, I walked up to the front desk with my credit card. I need a room for my daughter for the weekend, just her. She's 15. The desk clerk looked confused. Is there an adult staying with her? No, but her father lives two minutes away. If there's an emergency, here's his number. I handed over a piece of paper with my ex.

What's the worst thing your family ever did to you? The reunion was at Lake Tahoe. 60 relatives I hadn't seen since I was 12, all pretending we were some perfect family. My sister Katie had organized the whole thing, rented this massive cabin, matching t shirts with Henderson Family Reunion 2019 in cursive, a photographer, the works. I should have known something was up when they insisted I ride separately. Your car has better gas mileage, dad said. Follow us. We'll stop for lunch halfway. The drive from Portland was eight hours. I'd taken three days off from my job at the bookstore, or spent money I didn't have on gas and a gift for my grandma's 80th. Katie had guilted me for months about missing family events. You never show up for anything, she'd said. Just this once, please. Halfway through Nevada, they pulled into a Chevron outside Reno. Desert heat shimmering off the asphalt. I parked behind Dad's Escalade, went inside for Red Bull and trail mix. The cashier was counting change for some kid buying candy. Maybe three minutes total. When I came out, they were recording me on their phones through the windows, laughing as they peeled out of the parking lot. Mom was filming from the passenger seat. Even my teenage nephew Jake, had his phone up. The group text lit up immediately. 23 messages before I could even process what happened. Hope you brought a map. First one home wins. It's just a prank. Bro, don't be such a baby. Katie sent a gift of someone crying. They thought I'd panic. Panic, call them crying, beg for help. Classic Marcus. Right, the sensitive one. The theater kid who cried during Pixar movies. The one who still went to therapy. The one they called too soft at every family dinner. I sat in my Honda for 20 minutes, engine off, reading their messages. Dad posted a video to the family Facebook group. 67 likes, comments flooding in. Hilarious. Marcus will laugh about this later. Great prank. My aunt commented. He probably needs this. Toughen him up. That's when something shifted. This crystalline moment of clarity. They didn't leave me as a joke. They left me because they genuinely thought I needed to be taught a lesson. About what? Being myself. I turned my car around and drove to San Francisco. No dramatic goodbye text, no explanation. Just turned off my phone and drove west toward the bay. Found a hostel in the tenderloin that first night. Sketchy as hell, but it was 40 bucks and they didn't ask questions. Found a studio apartment that same week. Fourth floor, walk up in the mission. Bars on the windows. Radiator that sounded like it was dying, but it was mine. Bartending job at this dive called the Broken Clock. The owner, Tommy, was this ex Marine who hired me on the spot when I made him laugh during the interview. Deleted Facebook, changed my number the hardest Part was explaining to my old co workers why I needed my last paycheck mailed to a California address. For three months, I built a new life, made friends with the other bartenders, started dating this girl, Sarah, who worked at the coffee shop next door. Joined a community theatre group. Nobody knew about my family. I was just Marcus from Portland who moved for a fresh start. Then the email started. Six months after the Chevron incident, my cousin Derek sent an email to my work address. The one from the bookstore website, apparently

Proposed, and she said no. What happened afterwards with your life? I've been dating Sophia for four years when I finally decided to ask the big question. Her parents treated me like their own son, especially after they found out I grew up in foster care. Her little brother would literally follow me around their house, begging me to teach him how to fix engines. Someone who never had a real family, being part of theirs felt like everything I've been missing my whole life. I've been saving every extra dollar from my job at Murphy's Auto Shop for months. The ring wasn't fancy, just a simple band with a small diamond. But it was real, and it was all I could afford. I planned everything perfectly. Sophia's dad was turning 60, and they were throwing this big backyard BBQ. All her family would be there, plus her closest friends. She always said family was the most important thing to her, so I figured proposing surrounded by everyone who loved us both would be perfect. The party was going great. Sophia's mom made her famous brisket. Her dad was telling embarrassing stories about Sophia as a kid, and everyone was laughing and having a good time. After they brought out the birthday cake and saying happy birthday, I figured it was the perfect moment. My hands were shaking as I tapped my beer bottle with a fork to get everyone's attention. The whole backyard went dead silent. Sophia looked confused. At first. Then her eyes went wide. When I got down on one knee and pulled out the ring box, her mom gasped and started tearing up. Her dad had this huge smile on his face. Her friends were already pulling out their phones to record the moment. I opened the box and said all the things I've been practicing in my head for weeks. How much I loved her, how she changed my life, how I wanted to spend forever making her happy. The words just poured out of me. But Sophia just stood there, frozen. Not good. Frozen like she was overwhelmed with happiness. Add frozen like she'd seen a ghost. Liam, she finally said, and I could hear the panic in her voice, I love you so much, but I'm not ready for this. I'm so sorry. The silence that followed was the worst sound I'd ever heard. 30 people just staring at us, not knowing what to do or where to look. I stayed on one knee for probably five seconds too long, trying to process what had just happened. Then, and I slowly stood up, shoved the ring box back in my pocket, and nodded. Okay, I said, because what else could I say? Sophia reached for my arm, but I stepped back. I couldn't deal with her trying to comfort me in front of everyone. I mumbled something about needing to go and walked straight to my truck. The drive home was the longest. 20 minutes of my life. I stayed up all night staring at the ceiling, replaying every conversation we'd ever had. About the future. We talked about getting married, about kids, about buying a house together. How had I read everything so wrong? The next day, I was under the hood of a broken down Chevy trying to lose myself in work, when I heard footsteps approaching. I looked up expecting to see my boss, but it was so.

Oh, the education system is actually insane. Like, you want me to decide my entire future at 16 when I still Google how to boil an egg? They'll spend six months teaching us how to calculate the angle of a triangle on a moving train, but nothing, absolutely nothing on how taxes work, how to get a mortgage, or how to avoid getting scammed by a fake email that claims to be your bank. And don't even get me started on. Show you're working out, Buddy. I got the answer. Why do you care how I got it? You're a math teacher, not a detective. They give us seven hours of school, then three hours of homework. Like, why am I working overtime? Is this my job? And why do we have to ask to use the toilet like we're requesting Parole? I don't know, Bob. Can you go to the toilet? Yes. Yes, I can. That's why I asked. I'm not trying to escape. I just had water. Then exams pull up like, hey, remember this one topic we spent five minutes on back in September 2023? No. I don't even remember what I had for breakfast. And yet somehow we're judged on a few sheets of paper in a sweaty exam hall with a broken clock and a pencil. That's losing the will to live. But, yeah, tell me again how this prepares me for life.

Did you catch the guy who stole from you? Someone stole my mountain bike from my apartment's bike rack last month. This wasn't some cheap Walmart bike, it was a 2,800 dollar trek that I'd saved for months to buy. I filed a police report, but honestly I didn't expect much help. The bike had GPS tracking built into the frame, part of the anti theft package I paid extra for. Most thieves don't know about embedded trackers. So I pulled up the app to see where my bike ended up. It was moving through downtown, then stopped at an address about 3 miles away. I waited a few hours to see if it would move again, but it stayed put. The GPS showed it was in someone's garage. I drove over to check it out. Sketchy neighborhood, run down houses, and sure enough, it was my bike. In this guy's open garage next to about six other expensive bikes that definitely didn't belong to him. Here's the thing. I couldn't just call the cops and say my bike is in that garage. They'd need proof it was actually mine, and this guy would probably just deny everything. So I came up with a plan. I went home and printed out fake flyers advertising a cash for bikes business. Made it look like I was buying used bikes, no questions asked. The next day I knocked on the guy's door. Mid 30s, covered in tattoos. Looked exactly like someone who'd Steal bikes for a living. Hey, man, I saw you've got some nice bikes in your garage, I said, showing him the flyer. I buy bikes for cash. Interested in selling any? His eyes lit up immediately. Yeah, I've got some bikes. What kind of prices are you talking? Depends on the condition and model. Mind if I take a look? He LED me straight to the garage, where I counted eight stolen bikes, including mine. My Trek was right there. Still had the custom handlebar grips I'd installed. This Trek looks nice, I said, examining my own bike. How much you want for it? That's a good one, he replied. I'm thinking $800. Perfect. He was trying to sell me my own stolen bike. Tell you what, I said, I'm interested in this track, but I need to check with my business partner about the price. Can I get your contact info and maybe come back tomorrow? He gave me his name, Danny, and his phone number. I told him I'd call him later. As soon as I got home, I called the police and explained the situation. I had GPS evidence showing my bike at his

Hate how in school they be like, okay class, if there's a shooter, get under your desk and be quiet or get in a corner and don't make a sound like, bitch, what? This ain't hide and seek, teachers think. Yeah, if everyone in the school stays quiet, the shooter will surely think, oh, there is nobody here. It must be a bank holiday or something, bitch. No, ain't nobody gonna think that. And the teacher always got the nerve to turn off the lights like that's gonna stop bullets. Oh yeah, great job, Karen. Let's sit in the dark like a bunch of discount chicken nuggets and pray this dude forgets how doors work. Nah, bro, as soon as I hear one suspicious ass footstep in the hallway, I'm gone. I'm diving out the window. You'll see me rolling through the parking lot like I've trained for this since birth. And why is the plan? Always lock the door, stay quiet and hide? Bitch, this ain't Dora the Explorer. I ain't trying to sit there like, can you find the students? Like, no, you can't, bitch, cause I'm halfway to Canada. If y'all think I'm just gonna sit there criss cross applesauce while the apocalypse is happening, nah, absolutely the fuck not. I'm parkouring over desks, flipping through fire exits, Olympic level survival. You will not.

What happened when my mom demanded 24 7 access to my phone? When I turned 15, my mom went from strict to straight up paranoid. One night after dinner, she plopped down next to me with this weird smile and said she was installing a family safety app on my phone. I watched her tap away, giving herself access to everything, my location, photos, texts, even my drafts on social media. It's just to keep you safe, honey, she said, handing my phone back like nothing had changed. But everything had changed. It felt like having a stalker who lived in my house. At first I tried to be cool about it. Maybe it would calm her down, right? Wrong. Things got insane fast. She text me in the middle of conversations asking who I was with. She'd comment on memes I hadn't even posted yet because she was reading my drafts. Worst part, she started replying to my friends pretending to be me. My buddy Jake texted asking if I wanted to hang out. And my mom replied, sure thing, buddy, with way too many exclamation points. Jake called me laughing, asking why I was texting like a soccer mom. I had no idea what he meant until I checked my messages. Then came the day that broke me. I was in history class when Mrs. Wilson pulled me aside. She looked uncomfortable as hell. Liam, your mother called the school. She's concerned about some message you sent about Me? My stomach dropped. I knew exactly what she meant. I texted my best friend Kyle the night before, joking about how our history teacher's haircut looked like she stuck her finger in an electrical socket. It was just stupid, but friend stuff, not meant for anyone else. But my mom had read it and called the school to complain about my private joke. I wanted to disappear into the floor. By lunch, Kyle wasn't talking to me. Neither was Jake. Word got around that my mom was reading everything and suddenly nobody wanted to text me anymore. Some kids even blocked me. It was like my social life had a disease and the disease was my mom. That night, I stared at my phone feeling trapped. But then I noticed something. The tracking app worked both ways. It logged every time someone accessed the account. I spent hours studying those logs and what I found made my skin crawl. My mom wasn't just checking my phone during the day. She was logging in at 1:00am, 2:00am, even 3:00am. She was forwarding my messages to her laptop. She was screenshotting my photos. He was living inside my phone 24 7. So I came up with a plan. I created a fake friend named Daniel, made up this whole persona, gave him a backstory, even found some random photos online to use as his profile pic on a group chat with myself.

I got pulled over by a cop. He said, wouldn't you rather drive straight to the hospital? Is this some sort of joke? I asked when the officer said those strange words. Instead of asking for license and registration, the cop handed back my license that I'd already pulled out. His face had changed from stern authority to something softer and sadder. I just got radioed in about what happened. I'm terribly sorry for your loss, sir. Before I could ask what loss? He was already jogging back to his patrol car. He turned on his lights again, but this time pulled in front of me and blocked traffic so I could merge left immediately. Other cars moved aside as he created a clear path for me to speed the head. I sat there frozen for a moment before pressing the gas. My hands were trembling on the steering wheel as I tried to process what just happened. The cop knew something I didn't. Something bad enough that he'd let me go without even a warning about my speed. I fumbled for my phone while keeping one eye on the road. I just landed at LAX an hour ago after a three day business trip to see Seattle. My wife Carly hadn't answered when I called from baggage claim, but that wasn't unusual. She often had her phone on silent while teaching her kindergarten class. I called her again. Straight to voicemail. I tried our home phone. Nothing. My chest Started feeling tight as I scrolled to her sister's number. Voicemail. Her mom. Voicemail. My mom. No answer. The highway stretched ahead of me, but I wasn't really seeing it anymore. My mind was racing through possibilities. Car accident, house fire, something at her school. Each scenario worse than the last. The cop had said lost. That word kept echoing in my head. Finally, I called my brother Harvey. It rang four times before his wife, Paulina, answered. She was crying so hard, I could barely understand her. How can she do this? I don't understand why she would do this. Paulina kept repeating between sobs, what? What happened? Where's Carly? Is she okay? I was practically shouting into the phone. Paulina just cried harder. I heard Harvey's voice in the background telling her to give him the phone. There shuffling and muffled voices before the line went dead. I called back three times, but no one answered. I was doing 90 now, weaving between cars. Other drivers honked, but I didn't care. Something had happened to my wife, and no one would tell me what. The exit was coming up, and I took it without signaling. I knew that's where they take her. It was the closest trauma center to her school. The hospital parking lot was a maze, but I abandoned my car in the first spot I saw. Legal or not, I didn't care. I ran through the sliding doors into the emergency room lobby. The smell. Of disinfectant, and fear hit me immediately. I'm looking for my wife, Carly Munos. She was brought here. I didn't even know when or why. The nurse at the desk typed something into her computer. When she looked back up at me, her eyes were watery. She. I knew who I was before I'd even given my name. The security guard will escort you. Her voice was barely a whisper. A large man in a blue uniform appeared and gestured for me to follow. We walked through endless hallways, past rooms full of beeping machines and worried families. My legs felt like they might give out, but I kept moving. The guard didn't say a word, just kept glancing at me with that same sad look everyone seemed to have. We took an elevator to the third floor pediatric ICU. The sign said, why were we in pediatrics if Carly was hurt? My brain couldn't make sense of it. The guard LED me down another hallway, where I could hear crying. Multiple people sobbing behind a closed door. I recognized voices as we got closer. Harvey. Paulina. Carly.

Sister in law snooped and stole our baby's name, then announced it right after she gave birth. But her face immediately dropped when she realised that we tricked her. My sister in law, Maya, has always been competitive with me since the day I married her brother, Jake. She couldn't handle that someone else was getting attention and what she considered her family. When Jake and I got engaged, I tried to announce her own engagement at our party. When we bought our first house, she suddenly started house hunting, too. So when we both ended up pregnant at the same time, I knew the competition was about to get intense. Maya was due just two weeks before me and from the moment we announced became absolutely obsessed with finding out our baby name choice. At first it started innocently enough. She'd casually ask during family dinners, have you guys thought about names yet? When we'd flash, she'd push harder. Come on, just give me a hint. But then it escalated. Maya started showing up at our house unannounced, trying to peek at any baby books we had lying around. She'd walk through our nursery and comment on everything, clearly fishing for clues. She even asked my mother in law to pressure us into sharing our choice. The breaking point came when I caught her literally going through our mail when she thought we weren't looking. She was flipping through baby magazines and packages, desperately searching for any evidence of Our name decision. My husband thought I was being paranoid when I told him I suspected Maya wanted to steal our name and you first. She wouldn't do that, he said. But I knew better. This was exactly the kind of petty move Maya would pull. That's when I decided to set a trap. I created a blank interest boards filled with names I'd never actually consider using. I strategically left a notebook open on our kitchen counter with Final Decision written in big letters next to the name Aurora Rose. When Maya came over for dinner, I even coordinated with my mom to call me while Maya was within earshot, having a completely fake conversation about how Aurora fits so perfectly with your family naming tradition and I'm so excited you finally decided. Maya took the bait completely. Over the next few weeks, she started casually bringing up the name Aurora in random conversations, testing how we'd react. Aurora is such a beautiful name, don't you think, she'd say. Watching our faces carefully, I played along perfectly, acting slightly uncomfortable whenever she mentioned it like she'd stumbled onto our secret. Two weeks later, Maya went into labor. Within an hour of giving birth, she posted on Facebook, welcome to the world, Baby Aurora Rose. Our little princess has finally arrived. The whole family flooded the comments with congratulations. But I noticed Maya kept checking to see if I'd responded. She was clearly waiting for my reaction to her surprise. The next day at the hospital, Maya was practically glowing with smugness. When I walked into her room. She actually had the audacity to say, I hope you don't mind that we ended up using Aurora when she was born. It just felt so right for our daughter. I know you guys were considering it, too. That's when I pulled out my phone and showed her our real pic.

My brother kicked me out over his wife's lies. Now they're homeless with kids and I refuse to let them back in my life. When I was 22, I inherited our grandmother's house, a beautiful Victorian with enough space for my brother and his family to stay while they saved for their own place. They moved in with their two kids, promising it would only be temporary, just six months. My brother assured me, we'll be out of your hair before you know it. His wife despised me from day 1. She'd make snide comments about how I decorated, complained that I was too loud when I came home from my nursing shifts and acted like I was invading her space in my own house. She'd rearrange my kitchen without asking, throw away my mail, claiming it was junk, and lecture me about proper household management while I was paying all the bills. The passive aggression escalated weekly. She'd use my expensive shampoo, then deny it when confronted. My leftovers would disappear from the fridge and she'd claim she thought they were communal food when I started labelling everything with my name. She complained to my brother that I was being petty and territorial. I tried talking to my brother about her behaviour, but he always made excuses. She's stressed about money. She's not used to living with other people. You're being too sensitive. Every conversation ended with him defending her and dismissing my concerns. The breaking point came six Months later, I arrived home exhausted from a double shift to find her screaming at me in the hallway. She claimed I've been stealing money from her purse and eating her food from the fridge. Both accusations were ridiculous. I made decent money and kept my own groceries clearly labeled. You've been sneaking into our room, she shrieked, her face red with manufactured rage. I know you took $40 from my wallet last Tuesday. I stared at her in disbelief. I worked 12 hour shifts. When exactly would I have time to rifle through your belongings? Don't lie to me, she spat. I have proof. My brother stood behind her, silent as she launched into a tirade about how I was jealous of their family and trying to sabotage their marriage. When I tried to defend myself, she burst into tears and ran to their room. That night, my brother knocked on my door. His face was stone cold, a look I'd never seen directed at me before. We need to talk, he said. He told me his wife had been documenting everything. Times I allegedly took money, instances where I supposedly threatened her when he wasn't around, photos of missing food items. None of it was true, but he believed every word. She'd created a detailed log with dates, times and descriptions of my supposed crimes. You're toxic and you're tearing our family apart, he said. We're done enabling your behavior. I stared at him in disbelief. This was The same brother who'd cry.

Who woke up mid surgery? What happened? I woke up during throat surgery when I was 23. They had me knocked out to remove some polyps on my vocal cords, but something went horribly wrong with the anesthesia. When I first opened my eyes, I couldn't move a muscle. I was completely paralyzed from the medicine, but fully conscious. Everything felt muffled at first, like I was underwater. Then I started hearing snippets of conversation. The surgeon was discussing a baseball game with the nurse while he worked on my throat. I tried to scream to let them know I was awake, but my body wouldn't respond. I. I could feel everything. The cold metal of the tools sliding down my throat. The burning sensation as they cut away the growths. The metallic taste of blood pooling at the back of my mouth. But I couldn't even twitch a finger to signal I was conscious. My heart was pounding so hard, I thought it would burst. But the monitors didn't show any change. The paralytic they gave me was working perfectly. Too perfectly. I was trapped in my own body, forced to experience every excruciating second. At one point, the surgeon made a joke about my tattoos. Look at all this ink, he said. Wonder what her parents think. The nurse laughed and said something about kids these days. I wanted to cry, but couldn't even do that. Then things got worse. I felt this sharp, searing pain as something Went wrong. The surgeon swore under his breath. Damn it, we've got a bleeder. My throat was filling with blood faster than they could suction it out. The calm discussion about baseball was replaced with urgent commands. BP is dropping. Get me more suction. Where's that clamp? I. I could feel myself choking, drowning in my own blood, but still couldn't move. That's when the anesthesiologist finally noticed something was off with my readings. He rushed to adjust something in my IV, and everything started fading to black. The last thing I heard was him saying, she's fighting the paralytic. When I woke up in recovery, the nurse asked how I was feeling. I wrote on my notepad. I heard everything. The baseball game, the joke about my tattoos, the bleeding. Her face went white. They pulled my records and discovered my body had metabolized the anesthesia way faster than normal, but the paralytic had stayed at full strength. Apparently, it's a rare genetic condition that runs in my family, something my mom forgot to mention. The hospital tried to sweep it all under the rug. They offered to waive all my medical bills if I sign some papers promising not to sue. But that wasn't what I wanted. I just wanted them to document my case so it wouldn't happen to anyone else. The surgeon and anesthesiologist came to apologize later that day. The surgeon looked like he hadn't slept in days. He kept saying how sorry he was. About the tattoo comments, I wrote back the baseball game was more offensive. Yankees suck. But here's the crazy part. When they checked the surgery recording, apparently they film everything for teaching purposes. They found something disturbing during the bleeding incident.

If you want to bury a dead body, simply bury it 9 feet deep, then place a dead animal four feet above it. This way if a police dog smells something unusual, they will only find the dead animal. If you want to get rid of a crime weapon, the best way to do it is to melt it down into a block of steel, then throw it in the ocean. This way it will sink to the bottom and if someone finds it, they will never know what it originally was. If you want to trespass onto someone's property, bring a dog leash with you. If someone asks why you're there, just tell them your dog ran off and you're trying to find it. If your grandmother is racist, create a photo montage of your brother or sister in a situation that will upset her. She will remove them from her will so you will inherit a larger share. To skip class, wait for the break and hide your bag somewhere. Then when you have to go back to class, go to the teacher and explain that your school bag has disappeared and that someone probably took it as a bad joke. Now he will let you look for your things and you can even ask your best friend to accompany you in the search. So tag him in the comments.

Nine years ago, my whole family cut me off because my cousin claimed I got her pregnant. I was 22, living my best life when my phone exploded with calls from my entire family. My cousin Eve, who was 16, told everyone I'd been sneaking into her room and that she was now pregnant with my baby. The whole family believed her instantly. My parents screamed at me over the phone, calling me disgusting. My siblings blocked me on everything. Even my grandparents, who raised me, wouldn't take my calls. I had zero proof it wasn't true. Eve was the family princess, and I was just a black sheep cousin who barely came around anymore. The accusation spread like wildfire through our tight knit extended family. Aunts and uncles who used to invite me to barbecues suddenly acted like I didn't exist. My mom's sister, Eve's mother, posted cryptic Facebook statuses about protecting our children from predators in our own family. Within a week, I was completely erased from every family group chat, every holiday plan, every. Every graduation announcement. The next year destroyed me completely. I waited every day for police to show up at my door with handcuffs. Every knock made my heart stop. Every phone call from an unknown number sent me into a panic attack. I lost my job at the auto shop because I couldn't focus. Kept making mistakes, showing up late, calling in sick. My boss finally sat me down and said, whatever was Going on at home. Needed to stay there, but I was too broken to explain. Lost my apartment three months later when I couldn't make rent. Moved in with a buddy who let me crash on his couch. But even he started asking weird questions when family never visited or called. Started drinking heavily just to sleep and drinking to get through the day. Then drinking because breathing felt impossible without it. Dating became a nightmare. How do you explain why your entire family disowned you? First girl I tried to date asked to meet my parents. After two months, I made up some story about them being dead. Second girl saw through the lies when she noticed I had zero family photos, no childhood stories, no one to invite to anything. She asked Point Blank why I never talked about my family. And when I couldn't give a straight answer, she was gone by morning. The isolation was crushing. Holidays were the worst. Christmas, Thanksgiving, Easter. Everyone else had somewhere to go, someone to call. I drive past my old neighborhood and see all the cars in my parents driveway, knowing they were all inside without me. I finally moved three states away and started completely over. New job, new friends, new identity. Told everyone I met that my family lived far away and we weren't close. Simple, clean lie that people accepted. Got into therapy, got sober, worked my ass off to build something resembling a normal life.

You ever had to block someone all because your parents said so? My parents were so worried about me dating a skater boy, they couldn't imagine he'd be the reason I'm still alive today. A few nights ago, my parents found out about my skater boyfriend, Greggy, when his message popped up on my screen at dinner. I love you, too. Who the heck are you talking to? My mom shouted, glaring at the screen of my phone. You're 14. No dating until you're 30. We were very clear. Dad pulled up Greggy's Instagram on his own phone. Border, really? This is who you're risking your future for? I tried to reason with them, but they refused to listen and forced me to block him everywhere. Right there over dinner. You'll thank us when you're in college, mom said, while I sobbed. My friends tried passing messages between us at school, but my parents found out and threatened to call their parents. Eventually, everyone gave up except for Gregorius. Gregorius showed up mysteriously in my Valorant lobby. Hey, Mel, it's been a while, he said, his voice breaking. I miss you, Mel. I know we're not supposed to talk, but let's at least play like we used to. We started meeting in the lobbies every day after that, just playing and chatting about normal things, school friends. My strict parent, he never once tried to convince me to sneak around or meet up in person. He never complained about my Parents or tried to turn me against them when I vent about how unfair they were being, he'd actually defend them. Sometimes they're just scared, he said once my older sister got mixed up with some bad people in high school. Parents get paranoid. He still cared about me in all the ways that mattered. When I failed my chemistry test because I couldn't focus, he spent three hours teaching me balancing equations over discord. When my grandmother got sick, he stayed up until 3:00am just listening to me cry. You can always reach me here, he promised. I don't care what time it is. Mom almost caught us once when she walked by while discord was open. I clicked to my game lobby just in time. Homework break, she asked. I nodded and switched back to my essay. My heart pounding so hard I thought she'd hear it. After she left, Greggy messaged, maybe we should stop. I don't want to get you in trouble, but I couldn't lose him again. He was the only person who I could rely on and thank god I didn't lose him because a couple of days later, my friend Sarah and I got caught up in some shady business. It was supposed to be a normal Saturday night sleepover. Her parents went out for their anniversary, leaving us to watch movies and eat junk food. I was on the phone messaging Greggy on discord when Sarah's older brother Joshua came home from College, completely wasted with two other friends. Sarah immediately tensed up. baby sis and baby girl, he winked disgustingly. He and his friends sat beside us on the sofa, placing his arm over my shoulder, constantly whispering things like, I know you're not as innocent as you act and your parents don't have to know. I pushed his face away and stood up, glaring, can you stop? Sarah was almost crying, begging me not to make him mad. He gets mean when he's drunk, she whispered. Just ignore him and he'll pass out soon. But when Joshua grabbed my waist and tried to pull me onto his lap, I grabbed Sarah's arm and ran to the bathroom, quickly locking the door. He started pounding on it, laughing with his friends about how I was playing hard to get and needed to loosen up. Sarah hopped into the tub, hugging her knees to her chest. I patted my pockets, realizing I had left my phone in the living room. Soon the knocks on the door became angrier. Hitting the door harder, jiggling the handle aggressively, Sarah meekly handed me her phone. I'm so sorry. I had no idea he'd be home. She tried calling her parents, but they didn't pick up. And I didn't have my own parents number.

ich sagte meinen Eltern, sie könnten am Leben meiner Kinder teilhaben, wenn sie Mir Mein Erbe überließen. so ist es nun mal. meine Eltern halten das Geld meines Großvaters seit 8 Jahren in Geiselhaft. wir reden hier von einem sechsstelligen Betrag, den er Mir mit 18 vermachte. Mein Großvater war 1 unglaublicher Mann, der mich praktisch großzog, während meine Eltern ständig beruflich unterwegs waren. er besaß eine Baumarktkette in 3 Bundesstaaten, und als er starb, vermachte er Mir alles in seinem Testament, 150.000 Dollar plus 1 paar Aktien und online. aber meine Eltern griffen sofort 1 und sagten, ich sei zu unreif, um mit so viel Geld umzugehen. sie legten es in einen treuhandforms, den sie kontrollierten und sagten, ich müsste mich erst beweisen und zeigen, dass ich verantwortungsvoll mit Finanzen umgehen kann. ich verbrachte meine gesamten zwanziger damit, zu beweisen, dass ich verantwortungsvoll genug war. ich machte meinen Abschluss in Buchhaltung, aber arbeitete 4 Jahre lang ununterbrochen in derselben wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft und habe nie eine einzige Zahlung versäumt. ich hatte eine perfekte Kreditwürdigkeit, 1 Sparkonto und hatte sogar 1 kleines anlageportfolio mit meinem eigenen Geld angelegt. aber jedes mal, wenn ich das Erbe zur Sprache brachte, schimpfte Mein Vater Lange darüber, wie die jungen Leute heute den Wert eines Dollars nicht verstehen und Geduld lernen müssen. gleichzeitig fahren sie alle 2 Jahre in brandneuen Audis durch die Gegend, monatlich reisen nach Europa und posten Fotos von schicken Restaurants in Paris und ROM. schneller Vorlauf in die Gegenwart. ich bin 28. verheiratet mit einer wunderbaren Frau namens Sarah, die Lehrerin ist und wir haben vor 6 Monaten unser 1. Baby bekommen, 1 wunderschönes kleines Mädchen namens Emma, das genauso aussieht wie Mein Großvater. plötzlich wollen meine Eltern die besten Großeltern der Welt sein. sie tauchen unangemeldet auf mit teuren Kinderwagen, Designer Babykleidung Aus butiken und diesem riesigen handgeschnitzten Holzbett, das mehr kostet als meine monatliche autorate. Oma postet ständig Bilder auf Instagram und versieht alles mit Hashtags wie glückliche Oma. ich verwöhne Mein Enkelkind und Großeltern wissen es am besten. aber was mich wahnsinnig macht, sie behandeln uns immer noch als wären wir Mittellose College Studenten.

My girlfriend said, let's just be friends after two years together. So I treated her exactly like I treat my other friends. With boundaries. Tara and I had been together for two years, living together, for one. We were talking about future plans, her sister's wedding next summer, where I was supposed to be her plus one. Then on a random Thursday evening, she sat me down for the talk. I love you, but I'm not in love with you anymore. She said, I think we should transition to being friends. Get along so well, have the same friend group. We'd make amazing friends. But not amazing partners. Here's what killed me. She said all this while already having packed a bag. Her friend Marissa was picking her up in an hour. She planned this whole thing down to having somewhere to stay. You've already got an exit strategy? I said, we're adults. We're friends. We can make this work. I sat there processing two years living together, talking about kids someday. Now she wants to be buddies? Okay. I said, yeah, let's be friends. She actually smiled, relieved, like I just agreed to her perfect plan where she gets to dump me but keep all the benefits of having me in her life. The next morning, I did exactly what Tara asked. I treated her like a friend. That's when I Learned she had a very different definition of friendship than I did. First text at 7:00am. Could you Drop off my work laptop? Sure. I'll leave it at the front desk of your office Monday. Can't you bring it by Marissa's? I need it for the weekend. I've got plans. Monday works better. She didn't like that. But what was she going to say? We're just friends now. Week 2, Tara started cracking. She showed up at the apartment while I was at work. Still using her key. Helped herself to groceries, did laundry, took a shower. I texted her, I'll need the key back. My friends don't have keys to my place. This is ridiculous. We live together. We used to live together. Now we're friends. Different relationship, different boundaries. She came by that evening, furious. You changed the locks. You no longer live here. Here's a box of your stuff. I'm treating you exactly like I treat my friends. None of them have keys to my place. But I'm not just any friend. According to you, that's exactly what you are. The real kicker came at game night with our friend group. I showed up solo. She showed up with some dude named Connor from yoga, clearly trying to make me jealous. I shook his hand, welcomed him, then needed to destroy everyone at code names while paying them zero attention. Halfway through the night, Tara cornered me. You don't even care that I'm here with someone else? Why would I? We're friends. Friends date people. She couldn't answer because there was no answer that didn't Admit she wanted me to pine for her while she found herself. But the best part, her bestie Marissa had been extra friendly all night. Kept finding excuses to talk to me, laugh at my jokes. This morning, Tara texted. What was that with you and Marissa? We were just talking. Friends talk. She's my best friend. And I'm your friend, too, right? Friends can be friends with each other's friends. By week three, Connor from yoga had ghosted Tara. Meanwhile, Marissa invited me to a comedy show. The date was fantastic. She was actually hilarious. Something I'd

What's the coldest, most calculated, petty move you've ever pulled off? I work in semiconductors, where precision matters in circuits and apparently not in HR complaints. This started when management moved a new girl, 22, to my department, and I, thirty four, had to train her. This woman had quite the reputation around our facility. Multiple guys had mysteriously disappeared from the company after working with her, with whispered break room stories about false reports and HR drama following in her wake. Her personnel file probably needed its own storage cabinet at this point. From day one, her behavior was off. At first, she was oddly shy around me, but that quickly evolved into something else entirely. As the days passed, she got increasingly flirtatious and super hands on. All touchy feely. She'd even mention how cute she thought I was and so on. I'll admit I did play along with her, but never in any kind of inappropriate way. She added me on social media and we swapped info since she'd mentioned wanting to hang out. So I guess one weekend she saw on social media that I'd gone to the park. When Monday rolled around, the atmosphere had shifted dramatically. She barely spoke to me, slammed equipment down, and gave me death glares across the clean room. Turns out she was mad that I didn't call her, which felt really immature and honestly just nuts. Especially since we never actually made any real plans or anything. A few Weeks later, that same flirty energy was still going strong. Then I ended up out sick for a few days with a nasty stomach bug. I couldn't keep anything down, not even water. So I stayed home.

How did someone think they were completely immune to consequences? I'm a courthouse security guard. And last Tuesday, this guy in a three thousand dollar suit storms past metal detector, setting off every alarm. When I try stopping him, he shoves me aside hard enough that I stumble backward into the well. I'm late for my hearing. Touch me again and you're fired. Do you know who I am? Turns out he's Marcus Wellington, tech CEO whose company Data Vault got sued for stealing employee pensions. The guy's been all over the news for months, but apparently thinks rules don't apply to billionaires. He barges into courtroom 3 where his case is being heard. Designer shoes clicking loudly on marble floors. But he's so entitled and distracted by his platinum iPhone that he doesn't realize something major has changed since last appearance. The judge stops mid sentence and stares at him over her glasses. Mr. Wellington, you're 40 minutes late to your own criminal trial. Traffic was absolutely terrible, your honor. My driver took some ridiculous detour. Anyway, let's get this pathetic joke over with. How much do I need to pay these losers to make this frivolous lawsuit disappear? The entire courtroom goes dead silent. You could hear a pin drop. His own defense attorney, some fancy lawyer in an Armani suit, is frantically making shut up gestures and sliding urgent papers toward him. But Marcus waves him off without even glancing down. Honestly, if these people were actually Smart enough to read their employment contracts properly? They wouldn't be working minimum wage jobs for me in the first place. This is basic business literacy. A middle aged woman in the gallery, clearly one of his former employees, starts crying quietly. Marcus notices her tears and actually laughs out loud. Oh come on, Karen, you worked at Data Vault for three years. You absolutely had to know what you were signing when you handed over your pension contributions. He pulls out his latest iPhone Pro and starts casually scrolling.

What's the darkest place you ever found yourself in? I was 19, sitting in a police station at 3:00am with bloody knuckles, watching my best friend's dad walk through the door to bail me out instead of my own father. The fluorescent lights made everything look worse. Swollen eye. The dried blood on my white T-shirt. The disappointment in Officer Rivera's eyes as she processed my paperwork. She'd known me since I was a kid, shooting hoops at the community center where she volunteered. Two hours earlier, I'd thrown the first punch at a guy who wouldn't stop harassing a girl at a party. I didn't know her. Didn't matter. She'd said no 14 times. I counted. And when he grabbed her wrist, something in me snapped. My fist connected with his jaw, and suddenly five guys were on me. I remembered the crack of my head against the coffee table, the taste of blood, someone yelling to call the cops. My parents hadn't answered my call. They never did when it was late. Their way of teaching responsibility. Three missed calls to my dad, straight to voicemail. So I called Mitch, my best friend since fifth grade. The guy who shared his lunch with me every day in middle school when my parents got to give me lunch money. When I saw his dad walk in, still in pajama pants, with his hair sticking up on one side, exhaustion in his eyes, shame hit me harder than any punch. From the fight, Mister Davis signed papers without complaint, noted respectfully to Officer Rivera, and motioned for me to follow him out. He didn't lecture me during the silent drive, just asked if I was hungry and pulled into Denny's, the only 24 hour diner in our small town. The waitress, Shelly, knew him by name, brought his coffee without asking. Your dad called me back, he said, finally, stirring his coffee methodically, the spoon clinking against ceramic in the empty restaurant. Told me to let you sit in jail until morning. Build character, were his words. Stared at my untouched pancakes, eyes burning with tears I refused to let fall. 19 years old and still hoping for a father who would show up. I'm sorry, I managed to say.

When did you use someone's exact words from 20 years ago to destroy them? I became a parent at 7 years old, the day I realized my sister Eve would starve if I didn't learn to cook. Our parents worked 18 hour days and treated the office like their real home, while I Learned to pack Eve's lunch in the specific blue container she needed and her sandwiches into perfect triangles. By 9, I could forge their signatures perfectly and knew exactly how to calm her meltdowns. By 16, I scheduled her doctor visits and set alarms to give her medicine on time. Eve would fall asleep by the front door waiting for them to come home, rocking with her weighted blanket. And I'd carry her to bed at midnight, whispering that I'd always be there, even if they weren't. So when Stanford accepted me, I stared at the letter, knowing I couldn't leave her alone for two more years of high school. She caught me crying and grabbed my shoulders. You have to go. I don't like when you're sad, she said, rocking slightly. Parents suddenly appeared when they heard Stanford's name, actually proud for once and lecturing me about opportunities I couldn't pass up. But I told them I couldn't leave Eve alone, not when she needed someone who understood her routines and could advocate for her at school. For the first time in years, they actually look at me, and I watched something break in Mom's face. Oh, god, she whispered. You've been doing our job since second grade. All this time working to afford the best life for you two, and we haven't even been here to live it with you. Dad couldn't look at me when he finally spoke. Starting tomorrow, being here comes first. And for three beautiful months, they became the best parents. Dad Learned Eve's morning routine, mom attended parent teacher conferences, and they both showed up to her sophomore year orientation. Eve called me at Stanford listing every dinner detail they used. The smooth plates. Dad didn't mix her foods. Mom turned the TV volume to 16, not 17. They and photos of themselves at her art showcase. And Eve's smile in those pictures made the homesickness worth it. She even called one night. Very serious. I have a boyfriend, mom, and dad like him. He helps me at school. I felt grateful hearing her sound happy about normal teenage things. But when I came home two years later for her graduation, I realized she was living anything but a normal.

On my first day of high school, my teacher asked me, do you have your middle school diploma? I told my teacher, not on me right now. Do you keep yours on you? I said with a grin while sliding into my seat next to my boy Donnie. A few kids laughed and I felt pretty good about my comeback. First day of high school and I was already making people laugh. Missus Corillo didn't smile, though. She looked down at her attendance sheet and then back at me with this confused I'm sorry, what's your name again? Moises Cabrera, I said, even though I literally just told her two minutes ago. When I walked in, she scanned her paper again and shook her head slowly. I don't have a says Cabrera on my roster. Are you sure you're in the right classroom? Donnie looked at me like I was about to get in trouble already. I pulled out my schedule to double check, even though I knew I was right. Yeah, statistics 1A with Missus Corillo. Room 2 0 4. This is 2:04, right? She walked over to my desk and looked at my schedule. Then she said the words that ruined everything. You need to go to the main office. You're not supposed to be here. The whole class was staring at me as I grabbed my backpack and walked out. My face was burning with embarrassment. Kids were already whispering and pulling out their phones, probably to Text everyone about the kid who showed up to the wrong class like an idiot. The main office was packed with confused freshman trying to fix their schedules. I waited in line for 20 minutes before finally reaching the front desk, where this tired looking lady with glasses asked what I needed. My statistics teacher says I'm not on her roster, but this is definitely my schedule. I showed her the paper I'd gotten in the mail two weeks ago. She typed something into her computer and frowned, then typed more and frowned deeper. Moises Cabrera. You're not enrolled at this school. What do you mean I'm not enrolled? I literally live three blocks away. I went to the same middle school as everyone else. I graduated in June. My voice was getting higher and people were starting to stare again. She turned her monitor toward me and pointed at the screen.

He said that he needed something to eat with his drink and thought it was out there for everyone to snack on. I was sort of interested by this and asked him if he could give me some tips to start myself. He replied, I don't really know what I'm doing. Just get bloom.

What types of bad parenting do kids not recover from? When I was 12, I called CPS, but not to protect myself. I just been adopted by a couple who could never have their own kids. And they seem so nice. At first, they never yelled at me like my bio mom or dad did. They gave me ice cream just for existing. And they tucked me into bed with hot chocolate by my bedside every night. I was convinced any kid would be lucky to have them as parents. That's why when I found out they had miraculously gotten pregnant, I cheered. However, that's when things changed. It was like a switch. But not in the way they treated me, rather, in the way they treated him. My adoptive parents instantly became obsessed with Raising Jacob as this perfect and gifted child. They hung this huge chart in the kitchen marking every milestone the day they took him from the hospital. If Jacob didn't sit up, walk, or talk exactly when the internet said he should, they get this anxious look and start whispering to each other. By the time Jacob was nine months old, they were already making him do these daily flashcards. I watched from the hallway as my dad sighed heavily whenever Jacob got distracted or confused. It felt weird and uncomfortable, but I thought maybe they were just stressed out about being new parents. It got worse when Jacob turned 2. They signed him up For these advanced toddler classes, trying to teach him Latin on top of English at home, they spent hours drilling him on letters and numbers. If Jacob got something wrong, they tense up, their faces showing clear disappointment. Sometimes Jacob would cry at night. Instead of comforting him, they'd stand over his crib with their arms folded until he stopped. They said it would build character. I started noticing how anxious Jacob got all the time. He'd pick nervously at his fingers. His eyes always looked like he was waiting for someone to yell at him. One night after a preschool meeting, I heard his teacher mention that Jacob was struggling socially. On the drive home, my parents lectured Jacob non stop about embarrassing the family. He sat silently in his car seat, tears rolling down his cheeks. From that day, dinner became a nightmare. Jacob was no longer allowed to eat until he perfectly recited whatever they drilled him on that day.

I felt my heart sink when I scanned the crowd and didn't see his face anywhere. After walking across that stage, I gripped my phone, waiting for something. No texts, no calls. Complete silence. Mom couldn't look me in the eyes when I found her afterward, she hugged me way too tight and whispered, he really tried, sweetheart. My chest burned with anger. I couldn't hide anymore. At my graduation party, relatives kept asking about dad. Mom cycled through increasingly desperate excuses. Traffic jam, work emergency, car trouble, each lie more pathetic than the last. I watched her stumble through explanations while my shame grew deeper. My friend Jake pulled me aside and asked, you doing okay, man? I just laughed and said, he's been doing this since I was 7 years old, because it was absolutely true. He missed my championship basketball game where I scored the winning shot. Missed my debate team finals when I took first place. Even missed my 18th birthday party last year. Said he had to work late again that night. After everyone finally left, I sat alone staring at my diploma. Mom tried approaching me, but I cut her off immediately. David, I said, grabbing my car keys, I've heard every excuse before. Coming home at 2:00am, something inside me finally broke that night. All the anger I'd bottled up for years spilled over at once. I pulled out my phone and texted him. Congratulations on showing me exactly where I rank in your priorities. Message delivered. Read immediately. When I got home after midnight, Dad's car was sitting in our driveway. I found

My grandma left me a diary in her will. And in it she admitted she'd lied about who my real father was. My dad Trevor, had always been this gentle guy who worked nights at the factory and came home smelling like metal and machine oil. Mom would heat up his dinner plate at 2:00am when his shift ended. He'd kiss my forehead before I went to school, even when I pretended to be asleep. Normal dad stuff. But I always wondered why I looked nothing like him. I'm tall with dark hair and green eyes. Dad's short with blond hair and brown eyes. Mom always said I got lucky with the gene pool. That sometimes kids just look different. I believed her, because what kid questions that? When Grandma Rose died last month, she left me this speed up leather diary from 1987. I almost threw it away until I found the page with my name on it. She'd written about the night I was born. How mom was crying in the hospital room, begging grandma to never tell anyone the truth about who my real father was. Turns out my actual father is Mom's boss at the insurance office where she worked before I was born. His name is David Walsh. Grandma wrote that mom had an affair with him for six months when she got pregnant. He wanted nothing to do with it. He was married with two kids of his own. Mom was terrified and ashamed. So when Trevor asked her to marry him three months later, she said yes and never told him I wasn't his. I sat in my car outside Mom's house for an hour, holding that diary, trying to figure out what to say. When I finally went inside, she was folding laundry in the living room. I just put the diary on the coffee table and watched her face go white. She didn't even try to deny it. She just started crying and said she never wanted me to find out because Trevor had been such a good father to me. She begged me not to tell him because it would destroy him. The weird part was, I wasn't even angry at her. I was angry at this David guy who basically abandoned me before I was even born. So I looked him up online. He still works at the same insurance.

Has someone ever asked you, do you know who I am? I'm a night janitor at the courthouse downtown. Been doing it for six years now. People don't really see me, you know. I come in after hours, empty trash, mop floors, wipe down the judges benches. I know everyone's name, though. Judge Miller likes his coffee mug left on the right side of his desk. Judge Walsh always spills sugar on her paperwork. I clean up after all of them. Friday night around 9 p m, my daughter Amy falls out of the big oak tree in our backyard. She's 12 and tough as nails. But when she hit the ground, I knew something was wrong. Her arm was bent weird and she was crying hard. Real hard. Scooped her up and drove straight to the ER. Place was packed like always. Screaming babies, drunk college kids, people holding bloody towels to their faces. We got there around 9:30. By midnight, Amy was still sitting in that plastic chair, arm in a makeshift sling I made from my jacket. Her face was getting pale, and she kept saying her arm felt tingly. That scared me. I walked up to the front desk where this tired looking nurse was typing on her computer. Excuse me. My daughter's been waiting almost three hours. Her arm might be broken pretty bad. Could someone just take a quick look? Before she could answer, this guy in a gray coat comes storming through the Automatic doors. He's got silver hair, expensive shoes, and this look on his face, like the world owes him something. He marches right up to the desk and slams down his I D. I need to be seen immediately says, not even looking at me or Amy. The nurse glances at his ID, and her eyes get wide. Sir, we have a pretty long wait tonight. He cuts her off. Do you know who I am? And that's when I recognized him. Judge Reinhardt. Same guy who sits in courtroom B every Tuesday. Same guy who drinks fancy coffee from that blue mug I wash every night.
