And for the record, she didn't wear any makeup nor did she wear anything special that might explain the sloth pace. Just basically talking my ears off and spending an eternity tying her shoelaces. It even left me with a small existential crisis, wondering if I would even be cut out for children. But choosing a life like this with an adult, I have way too little patience for that. Sorry. 3. This girl was beautiful, driven, intelligent. We got along well. She was perfect except that she would snap her fingers whenever someone would say something she liked. Every conversation peppered with snaps, she'd do it instead. Of applauding at concerts, too. Eventually I realized that this couldn't be my life. 4, the guy I married goes by his first and middle initials. Think J, C, L, J. And when I found out his actual first name about six months into dating him, it legitimately made me upset because it was such an old fashioned name. It didn't make me end, but I sure thought about it. To this day, 10+ years together, I avoid saying his proper name like the plague. I feel super petty about my feelings, but all these years later, I still really, really dislike it. I'm just used to it. Five, I once broke up with a girl because her teeth were small and the gaps between all her teeth really freaked me out. 6, I went on a first date with a guy at a coffee shop. I got there before him and was sitting at a table waiting. He walked up and instead of approaching and saying, excuse me, are you so and so, he very loudly yelled my name and everyone around turned and looked at him while I homered back into the bushes. It was over then and there. I think he thought he was being manly and dominant or something, but I'm a private and introverted person and that made my skin crawl. Seven, I swear to you, the day we got married, my wife started swallowing loudly like she knew it was a thing she did. She intentionally hit it and then stopped trying to hide it five seconds after our vows. 8, was married to someone. Then when that ended, I dated someone who had the same name. Years later, I was flirting with someone and when I Learned they had the same name, I just turned and walked away. 9. I won't date them if they don't use their turn signals. If you can't communicate on the road, you can't communicate in a relationship. 10. I dated a really cute lady in my early 20s. Pretty much my type, super sweet, but she did this weird exhale, scoff thing consistently in conversation when she didn't like something. And it became so noticeable I was going to lose my mind. I finally was just like, yeah, this isn't going to work. Eleven. They drag their feet when they're walking. 12. This was years ago, but I would swipe left on any dude holding an iPhone without a case on it cause I didn't need that kind of stress in my life. 13, allergies. I love animals and I'm not going to date a man who might pass away if I come around him after eating a peanut or shrimp.

People who bought a house, what is the weirdest thing you have found left by the previous owner? One first time I took a hot shower in our new home, the steam covered the mirror only to reveal the phrase, hello, I see you in large finger drawn writing. It freaked me out for a second but made me laugh soon after that. It was such an inconspicuous yet obvious thing to leave for the new homeowner. Me. Two, wasn't a purchase, but I was showing a house to a couple and we couldn't believe the reported square footage. It looked like a nice 1,700 square foot house in a semi rural community, but the square footage on the listing said about 4,500. I was sure it was a typo. Turns out most of it was in the basement. Think Buffalo Bills basement. That just goes on and on with random rooms. The place was vacant. The lighting wasn't great. We got to a dead end room down there and turned on the lights and there was this porcelain doll just chilling in the middle of the room. Only thing left in the house. Husband yells, screw this, and we all run out. We ruled out that whole neighborhood as an option for obvious reasons. 3, $1,200 in cash above the door on the inside of the closet. I found it while painting. 4, we bought a house being foreclosed on. We gave him an extra month after closing in. 2000 to help with his move. Still had to have the sheriff come to remove him. Anywho, I was doing some clean up and remodeling before we moved in. The whole house was carpeted. When I started ripping it out, there was a giant blood stain that started in a downstairs spare bedroom and then trailed up to the master bath where there was another stain. His wife had left him. So I had to call the realtor to find out if anyone knew where she was. Turns out he had taken out a deer in the yard and gutted it in the house. What a hassle. Had to rip up and install new sub floors. My vegan ex wife was not thrilled. 5. The property my wife and I moved to three years ago had a bucket full of wrapped Dinosaur bones. Took them to our local museum where they confirm they are roughly 68 million years old. Hadrosaur. Pretty cool. 6. We bought the house from the CEO of the company which we franchise from. It was her childhood home where her mother lived until the day she passed. In true rich person fashion, they didn't care to clean out the house before selling it. They just told us we can do whatever we want with the old lady stuff that was there. We found a hidden box of spicy letters from the old lady to her secret partner spanning many years. That was fun to give to the CEO 7, my uncle was renovating the house that he bought for his chiropractic practice. And when he knocked down a wall to enlarge a room, a few dozen pill bottles fell to the floor. They were each filled with about 25 US silver dollars, which at the time were worth more like $6 in silver each. So it was about $5,000 in vintage coins. 8, that they wired a room by connecting the outlet with an extension cord inside the wall. 9, a diary of an American soldier in World War 2 South Pacific Theater found it above a door when remodeling 20+ years ago. My wife and I tried everything we could think of to find a descendant, but to no avail. Ten, a basement room that was fully decked out as a dungeon. Fake stone walls, a stocks like where you lock your head and hands in Old England. Candle scones on the walls, a metal barred cage in the corner from floor to ceiling. Oh, and the closet had a load of toys, some normal, some not so normal. 11, an entire tribe of raccoons living in the attic.

What loophole did you exploit before someone found out? 1. My old apartment complex had a soda vending machine at the pool that was broken. If you put in 50 cents and press the button, nothing happened. If you put in another 50 cents and press the button, nothing happened. But if you put 50 cents in a third time and press the button, you'd get three sodas. I could see the vending machine from my couch, so I would watch for someone to try and then try again and then give up without trying a third time. And then I'd head over and get three sodas for 50 cents. Two. Not me, but my roommate. In college, whenever you paid for anything on the university's website, you'd earn college bucks, each year's tuition, pay for something small like a beer, koozie, fold up lawn chair, or if you somehow spent an absurd amount, an official school branded kayak. Well, my buddy found out that the points were added to your account before payment went through on the website. So he just refreshed the page over and over and got millions of points. I only found out about his scheme when I came home to an entire living room filled with boxes from our school. There were shirts, coolers, chairs, cups and, of course, the kayak. We opened all of it like idiots and had a giant laugh at the school's expense. All of the guys living in that house. Were having a great time until we opened the smallest box which had 1,100 dollar visa gift cards. Then we got scared. A bunch of school branded crap from a warehouse was probably unusual, but not something that would bother the person loading all that up for delivery. The gift cards though, that was where he got caught. The gift card issuer called the school to verify such a large amount before activating the cards and that raised a lot of red flags in the accounting department. They traced it all back to my roommate and came and took everything back. They left the opened items in the worthless gift cards and suspended him during his final semester of college. He had to write an apology letter and do community service for the school for that whole semester in return for not pressing charges for fraud. It makes for a great story though. We had a ton of beer, koozies and gift cards that we threw at each other like Ninja Stars 3. When in high school, there was a company that offered money to run an advertising window at the top of your screen would monitor mouse movement to track whether you were at your computer and pay a small amount per hour. A buddy and I downloaded it and a mouse moving software and it would run both 24 7 except when we were on the computer. Made a few hundred dollars off of it before the company Closed down 4 Coca Cola did a campaign where you register a code from the bottle cap and earn prizes I worked at a store with a bottle deposit and earn myself a sweet MP three player with room for five songs or something. It was pretty sweet at the time. 5 had a college professor who insisted on doing all tests and quizzes online. If you looked at the page through view page source all of the answers for each multiple answer question had a marker on which one was correct. 6 free sandwiches from CFA based on location I used GPS spoofer and got tons of free sandwiches a week on multiple accounts. I think I got about $5,000 worth of sandwiches and nuggets before they banned me. 7 I received thousands of dollars of stock certificates in the mail. Some intern messed up so badly that my broker said to hold on to it I I held the stock for years before selling it at a profit. 8 I Learned before my USAF basic training to say that I played an instrument whenever they asked the group on the first day I raised my hand and lied and said the symbols so most days I got to angrily smash symbols together in the air conditioning band trailer.

Which memorable Reddit post slash comment can you still not get over? One. The grandma who used coconut oil on her granddaughter who was extremely allergic and passed from it. As someone who works with toddlers, that story is a nightmare. Grandma nonchalantly caused the passing of her granddaughter. Not because she didn't know about the allergy, because she just didn't think it was a big deal. And in no time flat, a toddler is gone and two parents and two surviving siblings are forever traumatized. And grandma can't figure out why her daughter won't see her two. It wasn't as memorable or as big as most Reddit comments, but one has stuck with me. I forgot what the question was, but this guy commented that he was asked to bring like two gallons of milk to his girlfriend's family dinner. He thought, oh, they must really like milk. When he arrived, each family member had their own gallon of milk, and when dinner was served they all just started guzzling their own milk like animals. I need to try finding that. It was hilarious. 3 the one where the guy had an imaginary girlfriend, later wife, who was a giant cockroach, and his coworkers eventually found out that he had a whole fantasy life with his life size cockroach girlfriend slash wife. Four people seem to regularly post what Reddit post can't you get over? And I always drop in to say the pregnant woman whose husband and father In law decided she'd pass in labor and we're doing all the planning for that to happen. She never updated and I always wonder and worry a little. Wish I'd save the post. 5 the guy who was looking for legal advice because his landlord was sneaking in and leaving him notes while he was sleeping and someone in the comment section saved his life by realizing he was actually suffering carbon monoxide poisoning. Six the lady on ADA who unplugged her fridge to deep clean it while her husband had a box in there who told her to not open the box. I frequently wonder what was in the box. 7 the dude that bought a house with his GF and wasn't allowed upstairs. I want an update to this more than any unsolved mystery. 8 the guy who caught his wife cheating thanks to his Dyson fan epic. 9 the guy who Rick rolled Rick Astley.

What is the longest you've gone without knowing a person's name? 1. I moved into my condo in 2011 and I introduced myself to my one neighbor next door to me but instantly forgot his name. We would see each other in passing for years and I would always just say hi and the casual conversation. I met my wife in 2018 from a long distance relationship. When she finally moved in with me, there was an awkward moment when I introduced her to him. I said this is my fiance and we're getting married next month. He said congratulations and nice to meet you, then walked away. She asked me what his name was and I said I have no clue. Later that day she said his name was Brad. And I was like, oh, he looks like a Brad. And she said he had no clue what my name was either, so no big deal. 2. 2 years. I used to be a club promoter and I had a guy that bought tickets for me for every event he went to. He told me his name when I first met him, but I forgot it soon after he told me. Meeting lots of people makes it hard to remember names, especially when I don't even know if I'll ever see them again. So what's the point of remembering everyone's names after a certain point? I saw him out partying often enough, but it was past the point where I could ask him his name without it being awkward. I had him saved in my phone as Sir Prince Albert since he told me about his piercing so that I'd know who was texting me if we ever texted each other. But I didn't think to add his name since I wasn't sure what it was. So that was no help. Eventually we ended up at a party together and some people walked in and asked, hey, have you seen Phil? After not remembering meeting anyone that night named Phil, I said, no, I don't think there's a Phil here. Then that guy whose name I couldn't remember came up and joined the group and said, I'm right here. Don't worry, these guys are cool. I invited them. At that moment, I finally found out his name and I played it off as, oh, okay, well, if they are your friends, then I guess it's cool if they stay and just went with it. 3. A whole school year I knew their names. I just didn't know which twin was which and they weren't identical. 4. My name is apparently Darren to this nice couple who own a restaurant in my town. My name is not Darren. I've known them for two years. We're even FB friends. They can literally see and read my name. But it's cool. I always wanted to try being a Darren. 5. I've lived in my townhouse for almost five years now and I Don't know the name of the guy who lives directly across from me. I have pretty regular interactions with most of my neighbors, but I've never talked with this one guy beyond just exchanging pleasantries while passing each other. When I moved in and first met him, I immediately forgot his name. I was almost positive he said it was Mike. So I went about four years just assuming that was probably his name, but not quite confident enough to actually call him Mike. Then a few months ago, I was talking to some other neighbors in the parking lot when he walked by and my other neighbors called out, hey. So it was confirmed that this guy's name is not, in fact, Mike. And I was relieved. I hadn't been calling him that for the past 5 years. But I immediately forgot again what his name actually is. So now all I know is that it is something other than Mike. Maybe I'll learn his name by the time I've lived here 10 years. Six, a whole date. Someone fixed us up, but my dude never told me her name, just the address. She wanted me to pick her up. I didn't have the guts to ask her name between the date. She became a longtime GF after that date and we laughed about it. 7. My nickname in college was the mayor and I had people I had known for years coming up to me at my graduation. Saying, I had no idea your name was actually Dan.

What caused you to think I'm never visiting again after being in someone's home? One, a work friend invited me over to his house to watch a hockey game. So I said, sure, why not? I bought a six pack of beers and he said, sweet. He just put them in his fridge. He proceeded to pour himself scotch but never asking me if I wanted to have a drink. Then he pulled out some leftovers and made himself a dish and again, never asked me if I was hungry. Then I just asked for a beer that I had bought and he said, I guess, but I was going to save them for another time. I left after the game and it's been really awkward at work. 2. Oh yeah. Did we mention we've got bed bugs? You should be okay, though. My girlfriend's mom did this to us last year for Christmas. We had plans for three days worth of celebrations with various family and friends. We knew going in that they had bed bugs as in past tents, but they didn't bother to mention that it was still an issue until we had arrived. I was livid. It wasn't as bad as it could have been because our sleeping arrangements were elsewhere due to my cat allergy, but I was still worried about bringing them home with us or even transferring them to the hotel after they told us. I bought trash bags, everything we wore, all Our gifts, everything went into a trash bag to bring it home once we got here. We put what we could in a high heat cycle in the dryer and I inspected everything else on our tile bathroom floor with a flashlight. I was nervous for days afterward thinking I'd missed one and we'd have issues at our place, too. 3. A failed scorpion farm made the horrendous mistake of spending the night at my ex's parents house. I woke up to the feeling of something crawling on me. I soon realized there were three somethings. I flicked on the light and discovered scorpions. There are no scorpions native to our area. I freak out, SWAT them off and then run to the bathroom to strip and check for more. And when I turn on the light, several scorpions on the wall scattered like roaches. I wake up the ex. Apparently when he was younger, he thought ant farms were boring and decided to order scorpions on the internet and make a scorpion farm instead. The survivors of his arachnid Mad Max setup escaped into the house where a few turned into an insane amount. The very wealthy parents chose to live with the scorpions rather than call an exterminator, never went back. 4. Their bathroom floor was carpet and it was always wet. It went through my shoes and got my socks wet. First time, maybe someone just showered. Second time, nope. I can't live like this. 5. I Had a buddy I visited who played cat turd golf in his house because there were cat turds caked onto the carpeting everywhere. Believe an 8 iron was the club of choice. 6. I once went to a party at someone's house in Florida at night. We were all hanging out in the backyard. So the house looked okay from the outside. I asked the host if I could use his bathroom and I noticed the wallpaper looked kind of fuzzy, but I chalked it up to being tipsy. It wasn't until he flicked the light switch on that the fuzzy wallpaper was in fact a huge roach infestation and they scattered everywhere and even more ran away from us. When he put the toilet seat down for me and left, I was too scared to move, let alone sit and pee. So I just sped walked right up out of the whole house and held my pee in until I got home. I have no idea how they were okay living in that house with a trillion roach roomies. Seven was not offered any form of bedding. I slept on the floor while they slept on the bed. There were three of us and we were both invited. Both guests slept on the floor. This has happened multiple times and I swear I will not go back now that I can drive.

What is not a bullet you dodged, but a huge tactical nuke? You dodged one. After a night of partying, a bunch of us wanted to go watch the sun come up at a local beach. When we had just graduated high school, there wasn't a single logically thinking one amongst us, and one guy volunteered to drive in his minivan. A few of us said, no, let's watch it from the deck. But he said he was sober enough. I just had a bad feeling, and a bunch of us stayed back and slept it off at the house. We were all woken up a few hours later at about eight to a phone ringing off the hook. Cops and freaking out parents. It's pre cell phone days. They were in a really bad single car rollover accident. Four out of the six didn't make it. No one was wearing seat belts. They would have had to have taken a curve at about 90 miles per hour. 2 Yesterday I was driving and waiting for the left turn arrow to turn green. I kind of spaced out and then realized the arrow turned green about a second ago. Took my foot off the brake. As soon as I did that, a huge pickup truck ran the red light from my left and didn't even tap the brakes. If I hadn't zoned out, the truck would have hit my door right where I was sitting in my car. And I Probably wouldn't be typing this right now. 3 I, a 24 year old, had a pesky sore on my tongue that was really bothering me. My boyfriend's dad was a dentist, so when I was over at his house one night, I asked him to take a look. He recommended I go see an oral surgeon the next day for him to check it out. The next day I decided it was feeling better, so I tried to cancel my appointment, but my boyfriend's dad insisted I go. I went, and the oral surgeon pretty much diagnosed it as cancer on the spot. It was aggressive, and by the time of my surgery to remove it, it. It had already spread to multiple lymph nodes. They ended up removing over half my tongue, followed by chemo and radiation. Given how aggressive it was, I often think that if I had put off the doctor's visit any longer, I probably wouldn't have survived. I'm coming up on my 10 year anniversary in January. Four. I was driving home from visiting my brother in Vermont when a snowstorm started. I didn't have much experience driving in serious snow, and I completely lost control. The car careened off the road and I was heading for a giant boulder at around 50 or 60 miles per hour. I literally felt time slow down, and I reflected on my life for a moment and then said goodbye to my body. I was jolted out of It by an impact, but I could see that the boulder was still 20 or 30 feet away. When I got out of the car, I saw that I had hit a little skinny tree that I could have easily grabbed with one hand. It had a giant root system that lifted the car off the ground and stopped me. The car was totaled, but I was completely fine. Because of that little tree, there is no way I would have survived the other impact. 5 my wife dragged my behind to the dermatologist for a cyst I have had for years. While there, the DOC noticed a mole on my ankle that he didn't like. Turned out to be melanoma. Would have never gone if my wife didn't force me. 6 on a road trip in college with four friends, we stopped halfway for a pit stop because I had explosive diarrhea and was getting sicker by the minute. Friends carried on to Vegas and left me with one of the guys who rented us a car to return home. Friends that carried on got into a rollover. One didn't make it, and two will be injured for life. Seven my wife and I were prepared to buy a nice river front property in 2019, but the owners, her dad and uncle, were dragging their feet. We had our down payment, we were approved for the mortgage. Then the river rose 30 feet, so we didn't buy it.

What's a women's thing? Men should absolutely start doing one. As a former cook and current welder, hand motioning. My dad refused to use hand lotion for a while and he kept getting big cracks in his knuckles. The cold would destroy his skin. He would only put lotion on when it was basically bleeding, by which point it can't really do much help. Moisturize. To steal from Bill Burr, guys, you can put lotion on places other than your weapon. It still looks brand new while the rest of you looks like an aging pirate. You need to increase the circumference of the lotion distribution. 2, going to the doctor before it's too late. I am a doctor and seriously, the wives are always dragging them in there. That was my mom with my dad. He got sick, wasn't eating enough, didn't want to go to the doctor, collapsed in the kitchen and then she had to call 911. Turned out to be sepsis and he almost passed. Married men live like five years longer than unmarried men or something like that because of their wives forcing them to be seen. 3. Squat in the shower and reach under my dude. Pro tip, use hair conditioner when shaving any body part that isn't your face. It's much better than shaving foam but does make things slipper. So be careful. Also, if you shave your butt, prepare for an unholy swamp butt. I refuse to shave my butt anymore because The grow back is horrific. Four, my husband never really did pedicures before we met and the first time I did one for him, he was in love with it. I used a scraper to get the dead skin off his heels. He calls them hooves. Haha. And he was horrified at how much came off. He'll even inspect my work now and say this toenail is a little jagged. Do want me to look a messy? He likes being pampered. I'm happy to do it for him. 5. I was trying on jeans for work the other day and I found this magical material that stretches but looks like denim. I was gushing over them and my wife laughed and said a lot of women's jeans use that material and a lot of hers are the same. Men should discover these jeans. 6. A man started carrying a satchel years ago and never looked back. I mean, Indiana Jones has one. I'm a new man. Breath stinky. Boom. Here's some gum. Headache, boom. Here's a pill. Phone dead. Boom. Here's a charger. My little bag carries so much and has saved me so many times. 7. Separate shampoo, conditioner and body wash. 8, making an effort to make their home smell nice. The way you clean, taking a shower does not actually clean your shower. Washing your bedding with more frequency, buy a few candles, etc. You will feel more relaxed at home. And clean sheets are better for Your skin and health. 9, buying clothes when they should be replaced. I see so many men with holes in their socks and shirts with stretched collars. Please just get new ones instead of putting it off. Lol. 10. Prior girlfriends and now my wife have said I should sand my feet. Calluses off his office office. I'm in work boots all day and they get dried, crack and bleed. Now I have this cheese grater thing that I use occasionally and rub lotion on my feet a few times a week. I'm happy to no longer bleed from my feet as it is quite painful to work with open sores on my feet. I do miss having Spider Man feet that had these little Velcro like hooks on them that I'd rub on her legs to annoy her while in bed. I could attach to the sheets and move them with the bottom of my feet. Hey, 11 p. Sitting down.

What's one thing your partner doesn't know? 1, she left her toxic ex boyfriend for me. He was always showing up in places she would be or randomly showing up at her house with no good intentions. She asked me not to get involved, so I respected her wishes for a while. he tried to break into her home one night while everyone was asleep. He got caught, made a run for it and keyed her car on the way out. Shortly after it happened, I was informed by a witness to the events. The witness expressed to me that at that time they were scared because they knew the ex boyfriend had been physically aggressive in the past and had recently tried to do it again as well. My girlfriend called me that night also but told me it was okay now and not to worry. For the next week, I staked out her house at night in case he tried again. I also found out where he lived and hung out and his routes to such places. I observed him and tracked his schedule. I waited for him to try something again and he came back to try and break in. Added security measures prevented him and after trying other ways, he left. He rode his bike down an isolated dirt path every morning as a shortcut to work. I waited and when I saw him, I blocked off his path with my vehicle. I did what? Had to be done and destroyed his bike. I told him if he even came near her again, even by accident, he wasn't going to walk away from it. An empty threat. I would have just roughed him up more at best. I also told him I recorded him trying to break into her house and damaging her property. I also read out to him in explicit detail his schedule and routines. I told him if I even thought he was sniffing around her again, I would find him. We never heard or saw from him again. We have been together for nearly 2 decades now. Very happy, successful and much so in love still. I swear I'm not a psycho, lol. I'm not possessive or an aggressive person. Everyone calls me a big teddy bear or a big softie. I grew up in a home with that kind of behavior and have zero tolerance for any of it. 2. Every time we go into a restaurant or place of business, I make sure to identify all the exit points in case something bad were to happen. Also never have my back to the doors. 3. I pretend to be asleep when he wakes up because I love how sweetly he wakes me up. 4. That I knew he was planning to propose to me, but I still acted surprised. We've been married 14 years now, but I still haven't told him. He is so proud of the idea that He managed to surprise me. 5. That I know their Reddit account. 6. That her mom called for her the moment before she passed when her mom was passing. She was in the room with her for almost 24 hours straight and left for 30 seconds and I was there in those 30 seconds. Her mother passed, but not before calling for my wife. I don't know if it will haunt her or not, but I just don't think it's something she needs to know. 7. He does not know that he was my teenage crush since I was 12 and I wrote so many beautiful poems about him. We have been married for six years and have a child together. I don't know if I will ever have the courage to tell him that I have always loved him. Eight. 8. That I have a folder of photos on my computer called Places I Have Found My Wife's Shoes that is legitimately filled with thousands of pictures of my wife, shoes that are neither in the closet or shoe rack. 9. That she's my partner. We rent together, go on dates, laugh together, cook together, eat together, and talk about each other's day every evening. But she doesn't want a relationship right now. Before anyone says anything, I know how it sounds. And I'm slowly making my way out of the situation. 10. Out of grocery shop efficiently. I can't stand going into the grocery store with her. She. Makes a list and then follows the list order through the store, back and forth. She visits the same aisle three to four times.

What is the most inoffensive thing you've seen someone get offended by? One, maybe 22 years ago, I had a phone interview with a baking company. I didn't care to have my peers know what I was up to, so I took the call on my cell phone in my car. The call was crystal clear and no technical issues. At one point, they had mentioned the weather and asked how it was where I was. I told him that I was sitting in my car and I could see that it was actively snowing and what not. The interviewer asked me, are you taking this call on a cell phone? I told him I was. Then he asked me if I thought that was appropriate. I asked him what he meant by that. he thought it was kind of rude to take a formal call on a cell phone. I told him I would be more than happy to conclude the interview if talking on a cell phone was an issue. If he was interested, I, I'd be happy to continue it the next day when I'd be at a desk. He again repeated how rude he thought it was that I had called from a cell phone and that there was no need to continue the interview process. I disagreed with the first point, but did agree with the second. To this day, I wonder what in the world he was talking about and where he Was coming from. Two, at my wedding, we marked the vegetarian items as vegetarian. This made the one vegetarian at my wedding sister in law who hates me fly into a catatonic rage because we are singling out the vegetarian food as vegetarian and not treating it as normal food. Then how the heck are they supposed to know it's vegetarian? Guess she wanted to be able to ask so then everybody knows they're vegetarian. Lol. Three. I once listened to my boss try to lecture the fire marshal because he was talking about something being flame retardant. Her reasoning was you should just call it fireproof because retardant was an awful word. It was one of those times where I really should have tried to stop her, but instead I just stood off to the side making a surprise Pikachu face. 4, this guy at a Halloween party I was at was dressed in a giant bacon costume. Some girl was yelling at him for being so offensive toward those who didn't eat bacon for various reasons. Mind you, she ate pork. One of the guys who didn't eat bacon at the party asked her what the heck she was talking about, but she didn't back down. Lol. I have no idea why people feel they need to go out of their way to be inaccurately offended on behalf of other people. 5. One time someone got offended when I put on my seatbelt. She thought I was commenting. On her ability to drive. The same thing happened to me when inside a taxi. He asked, do you wear your seatbelt when you're with your dad? I said yes. 6. My seven month old was wearing a shirt that had a rocket ship and the NASA logo. And some middle aged woman in the shop said he shouldn't be wearing that because he's clearly not an astronaut. I was dumbfounded. 7, at school, someone didn't have a calculator and asked if anyone had one they could borrow. Someone offered them a pink calculator and they refused saying that they were offended. They try and give them something less masculine. Clearly they didn't need a calculator that badly if they're just gonna whine about the color. 8, I'm a nurse at a children's hospital. I was wearing Mickey Mouse Halloween scrubs which have little dancing skeletons on it. A visitor for one of my patients complained that I was wearing scary and inappropriate scrubs. Nine, people get very offended that I don't like being touched. And this happened just last week. I work at a bank in an affluent part of Atlanta and a woman called in to let us know she was offended by the security questions for her online banking. The security question she set up herself. 11, wearing a mask in public.

Tellers who work in retail, what's the saddest thing someone ever returned? One, I used to be a manager for a Disney store. We had a regular old man come in with his wife regularly. Super cute couple. I mean, matching outfits, holding hands, just cute as could be. We used to sell these huge stuffed animals, like ginormous. The couple came in about once a week and would just walk around, laugh and smile things here and there. One night he came in on his own and bought one of these gigantic Mickeys we had. It was $300, I think. He was so excited. He told us all about how he was going to take her out to dinner and it would be sitting there on the bed to surprise her when they got home. Anyway, two days later, he walked back in carrying the gigantic Mickey Mouse plush to return it. He had bought it to surprise her for her 75th birthday. She passed away in her sleep the day before her birthday. Thanked us and said goodbye and that he would not be coming back because our store reminded him too much of his wife. We found out he passed away a week later. It was just seven days from the day his wife passed. We found out all the details because one of our employees went to the same church they attended to. Customers regularly come in with large amounts of baby supplies, returns they get The wrong gender items or duplicates. An older woman came in with a cart load so I asked about the new baby. She slowly and through tears explained that her only child and grandbaby didn't make it during childbirth. 3. Not a return, but I worked in a jewelry store and the saddest sale we ever had was a labor. The guy had this ring on labor for 12 months but passed in a car accident. His parents came in and picked up the ring so his girlfriend could keep it. I don't think she had any idea he was going to propose. 4, I work at a store in a college town and one night some younger guy was returning a keg barrel only was still half full. I jokingly asked the guy if it was a trash party or something along those lines and he responded with, yeah, it was a party for one of our friends who passed the day of the party. Five, I was working at a large pet store in the tropical fish department. One busy weekend a very well dressed, rather snobby woman came in and bought six baby angel fish, each about the size of a dime plus the fins. The store I worked in was inside a huge high end shopping mall. So we had a holding service where we would bag up fish, cash the customer out and float the fish in their bags in a warm tank until the Customer was finished all their shopping and was ready to leave for home. As a matter of course, I offered to hold this lady's baby angel fish. She said she was all good and left. Four or five hours later, she stormed back into the store demanding a manager and a refund. She was shaking the bag in our faces for emphasis, yelling that her gorgeous angels were all deceased. On close inspection, we discovered that the silly woman had put the poor fish in her car, presumably so she didn't need to carry them while she shopped for other things or returned to the store to pick them up. Unfortunately, because it was January and the temperature outside was extremely cold, the tiny babies had frozen. 6. A guy was returning baby formula and he was looking pretty down. I asked him how his day was and he said that he has been having a long day and that he's been having a long month too. I thought he just had a baby, so maybe he just got the wrong formula. I asked if he just had a baby and he said he used to have a baby. I told him I was sorry and he said it was okay. There were a few minutes of silence and he said he was a fun little guy, seen a lot of things, but that one broke my heart.

I refused to wake up my husband when my parents visited. And kicking them out when they insisted. My husband Tyler, had been working 18 hour days for three weeks straight. Some department at his company completely screwed up and cost them $50 million. So his team had to fix everything. I'm talking coming home at two in the morning, eating cold leftovers, showering and passing out. Some nights I'd find him literally sleeping face first in his dinner plate or passed out on the bathroom floor with the shower still running. Two nights ago, he finally stumbled through the door around midnight with this huge grin on his exhausted face. We did it, he said. Boss gave us the rest of the week off. He ate some leftover pizza, took the world's quickest shower and was snoring before his head hit the pillow. Next morning around 9, I made breakfast but let him sleep. Poor guy looked like a zombie for weeks. Around noon, my parents showed up unannounced. I'm six months pregnant, so they visit sometimes to check on me. We're sitting there having coffee when my mom asks where Tyler is. Since his truck's in the driveway, he's still sleeping, I said. My mom's face went all pinched. It's past noon. That's unacceptable with a pregnant wife. Wake him up. I explained the whole situation. Three weeks of hell. Fifty million dollar crisis. Barely any sleep. My dad just shook his head like Tyler was some lazy bum. I'm not waking him up, I said. He needs to rest. Well, if you won't do it, I will, my mom said, standing up and heading for the stairs. I jumped up and blocked her path. If you can't respect my husband getting proper sleep after three weeks of torture, then you need to leave our house now. Are you kicking us out? My dad asked, all shocked. Yes, get out! They left, all huffy and dramatic. Within an hour, my phone was blowing up, my sister texting me, I'm an ungrateful bitch. My bro

I lost my shit and screamed at my girlfriend to get out of my house after what her stepbrother did. My girlfriend Taylor and I were both 20, and things had been going pretty solid between us for about eight months. She had this stepbrother, Ethan, who was 23. And honestly, the few times I'd met him before, he seemed like a normal dude. Maybe a little too friendly, but nothing that set off major alarm bells. Two weeks ago, Taylor asked if Ethan could come hang out at my place for a few hours. She said he was bringing pizza and beer, and since my parents were visiting my aunt for the weekend, I figured, why not? My little sister Mia is 15, and she was just gonna stay upstairs doing homework anyway. So they showed up around 7. Ethan had this huge grin and two cases of beer. We started drinking and playing video games, just chilling on the couch. Everything was normal for, like, an hour. Taylor was curled up next to me. Ethan was cracking jokes about the game, and I was thinking, this was actually pretty fun. Then Ethan said he needed to use the bathroom. I pointed down the hall to the one on the first floor. Taylor and I kept playing, and I didn't even notice how long he'd been gone until we heard yelling upstairs. My blood went cold. Mia never yells. We both jumped up and ran upstairs, and I found My sister standing in her doorway crying, like full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway looking all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia what happened and she could barely get the words out between sobs. She said Ethan had walked into her room even though her door was only cracked open a little. She thought maybe he was lost looking for the bathroom, so she tried to be polite and tell him it was downstairs.

What happened when my parents blamed me for my brother's chaos? When I turned eighteen, my parents sat me down for what they called a long overdue conversation. You need to move out, mom announced. Every disaster in this house happens because you're constantly provoking Gonzales. I stared in disbelief while my 14 year old brother Gonzales sat there looking innocent. The kitchen fire last week, the destroyed laptop, the hole in the garage door. It's always when you two are together. We need peace. You have two weeks to find somewhere else to live. Gonzalez smiled sweetly. I just want our family to be safe, he said, hiding behind my parents backs as he mouth goodbye. Fine. If they wanted me to stop protecting them from Hurricane Gonzalez, I'd wish them good luck. The day after I moved out, Gonzalez decided to upgrade the house's electrical system. Every light in the neighborhood now flickered in rhythm with our toaster. When mom tried to make toast. It activated the garage door, the ceiling fans, and somehow started Dad's car. The power company had to shut down our entire grid and rewire our house. The Bill was $3,000. It's synchronized living, Gonzalez explained proudly to the electrician. Next, he discovered online chemistry tutorials without me. Secretly replacing his chemicals with baking soda, he created what he called rainbow smoke bombs in the kitchen. But they were actually just straight up acid that ate through the tiles and corrupted all the food. Hazmat had to gut our kitchen entirely. Total cost $8,000. Why didn't you tell us this would happen? Mom yelled at me through the phone. I did. You just never listened. I reminded her. Then Gonzales revealed he'd been training squirrels in the attic. They're my army, he explained, as 20 squirrels wearing tiny tin foil hats ended through the ceiling during Dad's Zoom meeting with his boss. Dad got fired on the spot. Then came the car improvement incident. Gonzalez filled Dad's gas tank with what he called Super Juice, a mixture of energy drinks, lighter fluid, and glitter. The car made

My girlfriend's dad said I couldn't appreciate their Italian family values, so I showed him real tradition. The first time I met Angela's father, he served everyone homemade wine, but handed me store bought beer. He said something in Italian to his brother while smiling at me, and Angela told me he was praising my manners, but I caught one word I recognized. Americano. American. My stomach dropped because his tone didn't match Angela's translation at all. That night, I downloaded a language app. We've been dating two years. I figured I had time to prove myself. Three months later, I understood basic phrases, but sounded terrible trying to speak. Easter dinner, her father kept switching between English and Italian. He'd say something nice in English, like he seems responsible, then immediately say something in Italian that made his brothers laugh. I understood non capisce niente doesn't understand anything. Then Mangia come un Bambino eats like a child. I just sat there pretending I didn't understand. Angela asked me later why I was so quiet. I told her I was just overwhelmed. She's squeeze my hand and said her dad was warming up to me. I wanted to laugh, but I needed him to think I was clueless. By month six, I understood most conversations, but sounded awful when I tried to speak. My tutor kept making me repeat the same phrases over and over. She told me my comprehension was great, but my accent was rough. Angela worked Saturday Mornings, I was actually at the Italian American Center learning traditional cooking from this nonna named Rosaria. She was tough but honest. Told me I understood like an adult, but cooked like a child. Month eight, almost ruined everything. Angela found my Italian workbook with hundreds of pages of notes. The worst part was that I've been documenting phrases I heard. Vocabulary practice. She went through them excitedly. She suggested maybe I could say Grace in Italian at Christmas. I agreed, knowing I was planning way more than that. Month 10, her father started switching to Italian mid conversation. Whenever I walked in the room, he'd wave and say it was family business, but he was getting more dismissive. He told his brother, America

When did watching your kids walk to school become stalking? My son Leo just started walking the four blocks to school by himself. He's eight. I'm a nervous wreck, of course, so I did what any normal, tech savvy, slightly too anxious parent would do. I have this tiny little drone the size of a Robin. Every morning, I'd fly it up just high enough to keep an eye on his little blue backpack until he was safely at the school gate. It was my secret, my little piece of mind. This worked perfectly for two weeks. Then I get a knock on my door. It's my new neighbor, Carol. She moved in a month ago and immediately put up about six security cameras, all pointed outwards at the street. She's holding a clipboard and has a very serious look on her face. Says, I've been documenting your surveillance activities. You've been operating a drone every morning at 8:00am? It's a clear violation of privacy. You're stalking the children. I tried to explain I'm not stalking anyone. I'm just watching my son walk to school. She wasn't having it. She said she'd already reported me to the neighborhood watch and was considering calling the police for unlicensed aerial surveillance. The next day, I see her outside with binoculars watching my house. The day after that, a letter from the homeowners association is taped to my door. A formal complaint. My stalking drone was causing distress to the community. This was Ridiculous. My little peace of mind project had turned into a. A neighborhood incident. But calling the police for watching my own kid? So I decided to give her something real to watch. The complaint was about the drone, not about why I was flying it. The letter said I couldn't fly it over other people's property. It said nothing about my own.

The courthouse security kicked me out for looking homeless, not knowing I was the new presiding judge. It was my first day. I'd spent the weekend moving into my new house, and my old pickup truck, the one I use for hauling lumber and garden supplies, was the only car I had moved from my country place yet. My good suit was on a hanger in the back. Of course, halfway to the city, the truck's engine starts smoking. I pull over and the thing just dies. Cell service was spotty, and the only Uber that would even consider the pickup was an hour away, so I started walking. Three miles later, in the humid morning sun, my dress shirt was soaked. I I tried to cut through a small patch of woods to save time, snag my slacks on a branch, leaving a nice tear down the shin. A passing car splashed muddy water all over my pants. By the time I finally saw the courthouse, I looked like I've been sleeping in a ditch. I was just tired, sweaty, and wanted to get to my new office. I walk up the main steps, and a security guard, a guy with a thick neck and a bigger ego, steps in front of me, blocking the door. Whoa, hold on there, buddy. You can't come in here. I tried to smile. It's alright, officer. I work here. He looked me up and down, a smirk playing on his lips. Work Here. Doing what? We don't have any janitor positions open right now. I felt a flash of anger, but I kept my cool. I just need to get to the judge's chambers. That made him laugh. A full, deep laugh. The judge's chambers. Sir, this isn't a shelter. You need to leave the premises now. He put a heavy hand on my chest and started pushing me backward. I'm telling you, I'm the new. He cut me off. You're the new guy who's about to be arrested for trespassing if you don't get off.

When did your in laws realize you weren't a broke construction worker? I'm 34 and my wife's parents still think I'm just some dirty construction worker. her father cornered me at dinner while my wife was in the bathroom. He pressed $500 into my hand and said, A real man should be able to provide for his wife without help. My wife grew up with money and I grew up in a trailer park. Her parents never let me forget where I came from. We lived across the country from them and only visited twice a year. But those visits were torture. Last week was their anniversary party. 5 hundred guests in a massive ballroom. At the entrance, her mother looked at my suit and sighed. They have a spare jacket and coat check if you need one. It was a thousand dollar suit. During cocktail hour, her mother grabbed my arm. Come meet the Johnsons. She introduced everyone else by their careers. This is Doctor Johnson, Professor Williams, then me. This is our daughter's husband. He does manual labor. Her friend Patricia asked what kind of work I did. Before I could answer, her mother said, small jobs, fixing toilets, that sort of thing. Patricia made a sympathetic face and changed the subject. Her father pulled me aside next. Your truck is parked out front. The valley lot is for luxury vehicles only. Maybe move it to the street. I drove a 70,000 dollar truck. He assumed It was worthless because it had dirt on it. Then he showed me his phone. Look at this article about successful people under 40. This man built an empire from nothing. Maybe it'll inspire you to aim higher. The article was about me. My photo was just blurry enough that he didn't recognize. At dinner, they seated us at table 19 by the kitchen doors. Her parents table was at the front with a spotlight on it. Her father stood up to give a toast. He thanked everyone for coming. Mentioned his successful children, their careers, their achievements. Got to my wife, he said, and our youngest daughter, who were still hoping will find happiness. He looked directly at me when he said it. After his toast, her parents cornered us by the bathrooms. Her mother had a folder with job applications she'd already filled out. Garbage collection, city benefits. 30,000 a year. It's honest work. My phone started buzzing. 20 calls, then 40. Emergency at the waterfront project. We've arranged an interview, her father announced. Tomorrow morning, nine sharp. My

My brother said my scars made me undatable, so I made him eat his own words. I had burns from a kitchen accident across my left cheek and jaw, and my brother Brian had turned them into his favorite punchline. Every time we argued, it ended the same way, with him saying, at least I'll have someone at my wedding besides our parents. No girl will even look at you for more than a second. Hurt me every single time. But my parents had taught me to learn how to live with the insults. Then, when I was 20, something shifted. I was working at the bookstore near campus when a woman asked about a photography book. She was so beautiful and perfect that I forgot to turn my scarred side away. But surprisingly enough, she didn't look disgusted or turned off. We talked for an hour straight about art and composition. Before leaving, she handed me her card that said she was a model doing a local shoot. I'm Adrian, she said. Coffee tomorrow? That's when everything changed. I started seeing Adrian in secret. Every weekend she wasn't traveling for shoots, we'd meet at quiet cafes, go hiking where no one knew us, cook dinner at my apartment. She asked why I never introduced her to my family. I told her about Brian, about the comments, about how I wasn't ready for him to poison this, too. She understood. For three years, we built our relationship away from everyone. Meanwhile, Brian was busy dating Jessica, this girl from his finance firm. He constantly brag about how sophisticated she was, how she'd studied abroad in Paris. He'd make snide comments like, people like you, people with scars are just meant to be alone, bro. It's actually noble living for other things besides romance. Made it worse was our parents seemed to buy into it, too. They'd stopped asking if I was seeing anyone, stopped mentioning their friends, daughters. It was like they'd accepted Brian's version of my future. Jessica would come to family dinners and talk about her travels, her NBA program, while Brian would smirk at me across the table. Don't worry. When Jess and I have kids, you'll be the fun uncle. Every family needs one person who's totally devoted to their nieces and nephews since they don't have their own children.

My mom broke her leg and I couldn't have been happier. When I was 10, my dad told me I couldn't ride my scooter in the garage, but when they went out for dinner one night, I decided I was gonna do it anyway. My dad had just bought his dream car, but it wasn't like I was gonna scratch it or anything. I was literally having the time of my life until I tripped and fell face first into the car, putting a huge dent in the side. My heart was racing so fast, I started crying and knew I'd be dead as soon as they saw it. I tried to cover it up, but I just ran to my room and hid under my blanket. They came home a few minutes later and someone knocked on my door. My dad walked in and as soon as he opened the door, I could see how mad he was. I was ready to get grounded and didn't make eye contact, but he said he just had to give my mom a ride because she forgot her purse at the restaurant. They went into the garage and by some miracle didn't see the dent. However, I knew they'd for sure see it by the time they got home. I tried thinking of an excuse, but eventually just accepted my fate. I waited for them to come home, but they didn't, which was really weird. An hour went by and our phone Rang, I answered it and it was my dad. He told me he was at the hospital and wouldn't be back until later because right after they left the house, someone ran a red light and totaled his car. My mom broke her leg and couldn't walk on it for months. But they never saw the dent. Bullet dodge.

My mom almost ended my life, but her gut feeling saved me. I remember sitting in math when the bell rang, and I started walking towards the library to eat lunch. I was starving, but there was nowhere to sit except the very back. As soon as I sat down, I remember hearing a sound from the hallway that sounded like a door slamming onto the ground. Nobody really reacted, but then we heard a girl screaming outside the library. She came running down the hallway, and we heard the noise again. It was so silent in there until she yelled, somebody help! He has a gun! And everyone completely panicked. I remember freezing up because I didn't know where to go. The room was all windows, and everyone started flooding out the back door. I couldn't move, and another guy went to hide in a utility closet behind us. He told me to come inside, so I did. We sat there silently crying for about five minutes, slugging our ears. It felt like hours. And everyone screaming was gone. It was so quiet. So we opened the window on the door slightly to see out. As soon as I did, I saw they were inside the library. We stayed as silent as we possibly could, and my mom wouldn't stop texting me. We couldn't move, but I realized if my mom calls me, my phone would go off. If she called me, we probably wouldn't survive. We sat there With our hands over our mouths, trying to breathe as quietly as we could. And I was praying they wouldn't look inside. We could hear them right outside the closet we were in. But they started running out, and we heard the police in the school. We sat there for another hour until the police found us, and we made it out safe. When I asked my mom why she didn't call me, she said she didn't want it to ring in case I might be hiding

Has your child ever done something illegal? My son was 14 talking to a girl he really liked after class one day. Then another obnoxious kid who thought he was funny saw them and walks up to them. He just wraps his arms around her and hugs her. She shoved him away and told him to stop. And I think he was embarrassed, not knowing what to do. I think he tried to play it off as a joke and went back in for another hug. She again shoved him harder this time and said, seriously, don't do that. She wasn't smiling anymore and my son was really uncomfortable, unsure if he should do something about it. He didn't want to say anything since this kid was like twice the size of him and was known for fighting, he thought the girl could handle him anyways. He went back in for another hug, but this time my son stopped him. He stepped in the way, not letting him touch her and said, do, dude, she doesn't want you to touch her. Just stop. This kid really didn't like this at all and started to get mad. He shoved him and said, what are you gonna do about it? He had never been in a fight before, but he said, if you touch either of us again, I'm gonna lay you out. I guess he thought my son was just lying because he went in for another shove. This kid ended Up on the gym floor 10 seconds later, out cold. He had a concussion and broken nose. And of course, I had to go meet with his parents. When they got there, they were furious. But when they found out what really happened, his mom told him that it served him right.

Has quick thinking ever saved your life? When I was 4, my mom took my sister and I on a road trip and had been driving for a few hours when we stopped at a gas station. While she was filling up our car, a man I'd never seen before came up to her and I opened the window a bit to hear what they were saying. He told her, I hate to see a single mother traveling alone. Do you want me to follow you just to make sure you're safe? My mom just smiled and told him it was okay. And he honestly seemed annoyed. He asked again, but she told him it was fine. A few hours later, we pulled over again and the same guy came walking up to her. He told her he was just checking on us. But while he was standing there, the wind was blowing his jacket. I could see the gun he was hiding on his waist. And when my mom got back in the car, I told her what I saw. She told me she saw it, too. And I could tell something was wrong. I think she was just trying to stay calm so my sister and I wouldn't start to worry, but told me to hold the steering wheel. She started writing something on a piece of paper and we pulled over again at the next gas station. She literally ran inside and then came back out to Keep driving. Turns out she wrote down what hotel we were staying at, gave the cashier some money and asked him to call them and have the police waiting there for us. The man was still following us. And when we got to the hotel, she rushed us inside. The manager was waiting and told us to go to our room. The same man apparently showed up right after us and asked if his wife and kids had checked in yet. He asked for a key. And when he gave it to him, he was ready to walk into our room. However, the key he had was actually to a different room. And when he walked in, the police were waiting inside. This guy was actually a convicted stalker and was arrested on the spot.

How long has she been seizing? She's not seizing. She's faking because I caught her cheating. Rodriguez checked Anya's pulse. She's in status epilepticus. This is a medical emergency. He pulled out his radio. Code blue, room 2:03. Shepherd grabbed his radio. Cancel that. I'm telling you, she's faking. Mrs. Shepherd, I'm a registered nurse. If you prevent me from treating the student, that's criminal negligence. She was cheating. I saw her looking at Lucas's paper. Rodriguez checked his watch. Four minutes, 30 seconds. She needs out of here now. He ran for the door. I'm getting my medical kit. Shepherd blocked him. You're not leaving until you admit this is fake. Rodriguez pushed past her and returned with Principal Wells and security. They saw Anya seizing in blood. Six minutes, Rodriguez said, pushing past Shepherd with his kit. Wells looked horrified. You said on the intercom it was a disciplinary issue. She was cheating. Check the cameras. Wells pulled up the security feed on his tablet. We watched the last 10 minutes. Anya had been looking at her own paper when her pencil started trembling. Then her hand, then the seizure. She never looked at Lucas once. Check Lucas's paper, Shepherd demanded. Lucas held up his completely blank exam. I hadn't even started. The paramedics arrived to. Shepherd still insisted Anya had cheated. They immediately administered emergency medication. We need life flight. Status epilepticus, seven plus minutes with head trauma. Anya was airlifted to the Regional Medical Center. Coma For six days when she woke

What was the most illegal thing that happened at your school? A few students decided to play a senior prank on the principal by writing on his car. And it made him so mad he decided to cancel the entire prom for the year. Everyone was pissed. So at the homecoming game the week after, we were chanting to bring it back. Eventually at the end, some kid with a banana suit jumped over the bleachers and ran across the field. Everyone screamed as he was being chased by coaches and teachers, and even the players loved it. Eventually, they tackled him hard and he ended up breaking his arm and had to go to the hospital. They had to cancel the game and the staff were so mad they suspended him for the rest of the year. He was probably gonna get expelled, but the students loved him so much, they decided they were gonna do something about it. That day, free Banana Man was born and everyone started chanting it in the halls. Few guys sold t shirts that said it and they wrote it all over the walls. At our school, there were bananas everywhere. And this made our principal so mad, he banned the phrase entirely. However, he didn't just stop there. He decided to go as far as to ban the actual fruit itself and even the entire color yellow. You literally weren't allowed to wear yellow to school. And if you were caught eating A banana, you were sent home for the day. This rule made the entire student body so furious they pretty much declared a war on the administration. Hundreds of students were getting sent home because they decided to bring bananas and wear yellow. And when they tell them to take their yellow shirts off, they'd walk around shirtless to class. I even saw a guy come to school in all yellow, and when they made him take it off, he tried to go to class only in his underwear, which was also yellow. It got so crazy that one kid who literally needed to eat bananas for the potassium couldn't for the week and ended up passing out in the middle of class. He went to the hospital and his parents threatened to sue the school. The very next day, we watched our principal walk out for the last time and the banana guy returned wearing his costume.

What was the hardest time you've had to hold back tears? When I found out what Smurf Day was when I was in college, everyone told me they were really jealous of me because of one of my teachers. But I didn't really get why. He was old and quiet and just seemed like a normal guy to me. I heard a few people call him Mr Smurf, which really confused me. But eventually one guy asked if I had seen Smurf Day yet. I had no idea what he was talking about and thought it was a joke. When I asked him what he meant, he just said, you'll see. Apparently this guy had a three year old daughter and a few years, years before she was diagnosed with a rare brain disease, she was bedridden in the hospital. And after he was done teaching, he would go sit with her every night. And since the Smurfs was her favorite show, he'd always watch it with her. Apparently it got worse and she didn't have much longer. Since he was a single dad, he had to keep teaching to pay for everything. He'd come to class completely broken. However, eventually some students found out about this and started a gofundme for him. They raised over $15,000 so he could take time off work. And because of them, he got to spend her last few days with her. And since then, every year he shows up like this on her. Birthday.

Teachers, can you tell when a student has had a rough childhood? I promised my entire third grade class that if they all got A's on my test, I'd do whatever they wanted me to. Well, they all decided on me eating a live worm in front of the entire school, so I hesitantly agreed. That weekend, I was completely shocked to see that not only did my class all get A's, but almost all of them got 100%. All except one. This girl really struggled in my class, but I could see she really tried. So I changed her grade to an A and told them they won. I found the most real looking fake worm I could, and that day during an assembly, the school told everyone I had a presentation for them. I ate it in front of the entire elementary school and they all screamed and laughed. They all bought it. And that same girls to enjoy seeing me do that the most. She thought it was so funny. She burst out giggling every time she saw me. Whenever I'd walk by her, she'd say, you ate a worm! You ate a worm! And we'd laugh together. She said it one time during lunch, and shortly after, I noticed another teacher was crying. She asked me if I could take over lunch duty for the day because she couldn't stop herself from tearing up. I asked her what was wrong, and she told me it was Because of that girl had absolutely no idea. But she had been abused by many of her mom's boyfriends and was severely traumatized by it. They tried everything for years, but this was the first time she ever actually saw her smile and laugh. We both had to find someone else to supervise lunch because I didn't want them to see me crying either.

People who've been in a coma, what shocked you the most when you woke up? When my daughter was 5, she begged me to put up Christmas lights for an entire day. She was literally crying because I was leaving for a work trip the next day and she told me Santa wouldn't come if our house wasn't decorated. It was really icy and snowing that day, but my wife told me to just do it. So I told her fine. I got the ladder and climbed up and my daughter passed me the lights and the colors she wanted. Right before we were almost finished, the slipped out from underneath me. I fell and hit my head on the concrete hard and remember the sound of her screaming. I didn't wake up until I was in the hospital later that day and felt the worst pain in my neck and back. I tried to feel for the bandages on my head, but strangely I didn't feel anything. I was really confused but barely managed to sit up and noticed I couldn't move my legs. I looked up and saw a nurse walk in the room and she looked really surprised. Five more people came in and all started asking me questions. I was really worried because I still couldn't move my feet no matter how hard I tried. I didn't know what was going on until an hour later when my wife finally got there. I was so happy. To see and didn't think anything about her. In tears, I asked who the girl she was with was because she was also crying. And when she walked closer, I made the most shocking realization of my life. This 13 year old was my daughter. And they broke the news. I was in a coma for almost nine years. I realized I had missed her entire childhood. I was paralyzed. My wife had remarried. But what hurt the most was when I went home to our house and I looked up at our roof. I broke down because those lights were still up.
